questions.Question: The First World Conference on Women in __________, generated a new interest in and debate on women's issues
questions.solution: Solution:		The First World Conference on Women, which launched the UN Decade for Women, was held in Mexico City.

questions.Question: Who of the following was for the first time designated as the Governor of India
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Governor-General was Warren Hastings.

questions.Question: The English established their first factory in Bengal in 1651 at __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Hooghly(Hugli) was also the first English settlement (1651) in Lower Bengal; it was abandoned in 1690 for Calcutta (now Kolkata). Chinsurah was an important 17th-century settlement of the Dutch, who built a factory (trading station) there in 1656.

questions.Question: 'Swaathanthrya gadha' – was written by the great poet __________
questions.solution: Solution:		'Swaathanthrya gadha' – was written by the great poet Kumaranaasan.

questions.Question: The year of the foundation of the Women's Indian Association (WIA) is
questions.solution: Solution:		On 8 May 1917 in Adyar, Madras, a multiethnic group of women established the Women's Indian Association (WIA). The WIA was one of the first organizations to boldly connect Indian women's social and sexual subjugation with patriarchy, poverty, and political disenfranchisement.

questions.Question: By the Act of 1858, India was to be governed
questions.optionB: In the name of the Crown
questions.optionD: In the name of Governor-General of India
questions.solution: Solution:		The Government of India Act 1858 was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom passed on August 2, 1858. Its provisions called for the liquidation of the British East India Company (who had up to this point been ruling British India under the auspices of Parliament) and the transference of its functions to the British Crown.

questions.Question: The Ghadar Party was founded (November 1913) at San Francisco USA by
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1913, Pacific Coast Hindustan Association was founded by Lala Hardayal with Sohan Singh Bhakna as its president, which was called Ghadar Party. The members of this party were the immigrant sikhs of US and Canada. The first issue of The Ghadar, was published from San Francisco on 1 November 1913.

questions.Question: The Poona Pact (1932) was an agreement between
questions.solution: Solution:		An agreement between Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar and Mahatma Gandhi was signed 84 years ago on September 24, 1932. The agreement was signed by Pt Madan Mohan Malviya and Dr. B. R. Ambedkar and some Dalit leaders at Yerwada Central Jail in Pune, to break Mahathma Gandhi's fast unto death.

questions.Question: Gandhi wanted the students to spend their vacations in
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhi advised the students to spend their vacation in social service. He wanted them to to work with dedication. He advised them to conduct schools. The students should visit harijan quarters and clean them. They should take the harijan children to recreational sights and give them the knowledge about nature. They should give the awareness of cleanliness to harijans. They should read them the stories from the holy books.

questions.Question: Gandhi called for an all India Hartal (strike) to protest against Rowlatt Act on 6th April __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The first major national campaign organized by Mahatma Gandhi was against the Rowlatt Act, which severely limited civil liberties. This movement began with an all-India hartal, observed on Sunday the 6th of April 1919. Gandhi had decided to lead the hartal in Bombay himself.

questions.Question: Who among the following had authored the book, 'At the Feet of Mahatma Gandhi'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Rajendra Prasad had authored the book, 'At the Feet of Mahatma Gandhi'.

questions.Question: Pitts India Act of 1784 was a/an
questions.solution: Solution:		Pitts India Act of 1784 was a Regulating Act by this act dual archy has established by the formation Board of Control.

questions.Question: My Experiments with Truth is the work of Mahatma Gandhi published in
questions.solution: Solution:		My Experiments with Truth is the work of Mahatma Gandhi published in 1906. The Story of My Experiments with Truth is the autobiography of Mohandas K. Gandhi, covering his life from early childhood through to 1921.

questions.Question: The battle of Balakot was in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Sikh Army tried to penetrate from the Garhi Habibullah (15 km downstream) with armies from Kashmir but were put to hold till the reinforcement arrived from Lahore via Timri near Shinkiari. On a little mound in the north of the city, by the Rou Nala, the Battle of Balakot was fought on May 6, 1831. Sikhs became victorious and all the Mujahideens including Syed Ahmad and Shah Ismail were killed.

questions.Question: The enquiry Committee on Jallianwaia Bagh incident was headed by
questions.solution: Solution:		On 14 October 1919, after orders issued by the Secretary of State for India, Edwin Montagu, the Government of India announced the formation of a committee of inquiry into the events in Punjab. Referred to as the Disorders Inquiry Committee, it was later more widely known as the Hunter Commission.

questions.Question: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel was equated with
questions.solution: Solution:		Bismarck was a german statesman who unified 36 states and established unified Germany. Sardar Patel also unified the 565 princely states to make India a federation by his diplomacy and political intelligency. That is why Sardar Vallabh Bhai Patel known as Bismarck of India.

questions.Question: Lord Mountbatten had held detailed discussions on the approaching partition of India with
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Mountbatten held free and frank discussions with Sardar Patel, Maulana Azad, Jawaharlal Nehru, Gandhiji and other prominent leaders.

questions.Question: As per Act of 1919 the lower house of the Central Legislature was known as __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Central Legislative Assembly was the lower house of the Imperial Legislative Council, the legislature of British India. It was created by the Government of India Act 1919, implementing the Montagu–Chelmsford Reforms. It was also sometimes called the Indian Legislative Assembly and the Imperial Legislative Assembly.

questions.Question: Who from the following leaders was not assassinated?
questions.solution: Solution:		Muhammad Ali Jinnah was the one who was not assassinated.

questions.Question: Muslim League was established in December
questions.solution: Solution:		Muslim League was established in December 1906.

questions.Question: Muslim League was founded in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1906, All India Muslim League was founded by Salim-ullah-khan (Nawab of Dhaka) Jinnah, Aga Khan and others. It was proposed Sir Mian Muhammad Safi.

questions.Question: Which of the following was not included in the Treaty to be negotiated as provided in the Cabinet Mission Plan?
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian National Congress was not included in the Treaty to be negotiated as provided in the Cabinet Mission Plan.

questions.Question: On which date was the announcement formally made that India and Pakistan would be made free?
questions.solution: Solution:		The actual division of British India between the two new dominions was accomplished according to what has come to be known as the "3 June Plan" or "Mountbatten Plan". It was announced at a press conference by Mountbatten on 3 June 1947 at 4 pm, when the date of independence of India - 15 August 1947 was also announced.

questions.Question: Who said "Patriotism is religion and religion is love for India"?
questions.solution: Solution:		The statement was uttered by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee. He deliberately equated the patriotism and religion so as to in still the sense of nationalism among the masses.

questions.Question: Jyotirao Phule was born in Satara district of __________ in 1827
questions.solution: Solution:		Jyotirao Govindrao Phule was born in Satara district of Maharastra in 1827. His father, Govindrao was a vegetable-vendor at Poona.

questions.Question: Of the following who transferred the capital from Murshidabad to Monghyr?
questions.solution: Solution:		After the Battle of Chinsura, the British deposed Mir Jafar and placed his son in law Mir Kasim as Nawab of Bengal. Mir Kasim, soon began to show a will of his own, and to cherish dreams of independence. He eventually shifted his capital from Murshidabad to Munger in Bihar where he raised an independent army.

questions.Question: Who was the Nawab when Dalhousie annexed Awadh in 1854?
questions.solution: Solution:		Wajid Ali Shah (30 July 1822 – 1 September 1887) was the tenth and last Nawab of Awadh, holding the position for 9 years, from 13 February 1847 to 11 February 1856.

questions.Question: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad was the author of
questions.solution: Solution:		Maulana Sayyid Abul Kalam Ghulam Muhiyuddin Ahmed bin Khairuddin Al-Hussaini Azad (11 November 1888 – 22 February 1958) was an Indian scholar, activist and a senior leader of the Indian National Congress during the Indian independence movement. Maulana Abul Kalam Azad was the author of India Wins Freedom.

questions.Question: Aruvipuram installation was done by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Aruvippuram is a village in the southern district of Thiruvananthapuram in Kerala, India. It is famous for the Siva temple established by Sri Narayana Guru.

questions.Question: Which nationalist had stoutly preached "Be proud that you are an Indian, proudly claim I am an Indian"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Swami Vivekanand had stoutly preached "Be proud that you are an Indian, proudly claim I am an Indian".

questions.Question: Which of the following was a leader of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Army founded in 1928?
questions.solution: Solution:		HSRA (Hindustan Socialist Republican Association) was formed in Delhi at Firoj Shah Kotla under the leadership of Chandra Shekhar Azad.

questions.Question: The first vernacular paper, Samachar Darpan, was published during the tenure of
questions.solution: Solution:		The first vernacular paper, Samachar Darpan, was published during the tenure of Lord Hastings.

questions.Question: Madame HP Blavatsky had laid the foundation of the Theosophical Society in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		It was in the United States of America in 1875 that Madame H. P. Blavatsky, a Russian lady, and a Colonel H. S. Olcott, a former army officer of England laid the foundation of the modern Theosophical Society.

questions.Question: The second session of the congress met in Calcutta on December 1886, under the president ship of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The second session of the congress met in Calcutta on December 1886, under the president ship of Dadabhai Naoroji.

questions.Question: The Interim Government which took office on September 2, 1946 was headed by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Viceroy's Executive Council became the executive branch of the interim government. Originally headed by the Viceroy of India, it was transformed into a council of ministers, with the powers of a prime minister bestowed on the vice-president of the Council, a position held by the Congress leader Jawaharlal Nehru.

questions.Question: The National Liberal Federation was founded by
questions.solution: Solution:		Banerjee later became a senior leader of the Indian National Congress. Surendranath welcomed Montagu–Chelmsford Reforms, unlike congress, and with many liberal leaders he left congress and founded a new organisation named Indian National Liberation Federation in 1919.

questions.Question: The Pitt's India Act empowered the Governor-General with
questions.optionC: The power to dismiss the council
questions.optionD: The power to add more members to the council
questions.solution: Solution:		The Pitt's India Act empowered the Governor-General with a casting vote.

questions.Question: Provision was made in the Act of 1773, for the office of a Governor-General of
questions.solution: Solution:		As per the act, Office of the Governor-General of the Presidency of Fort William was created in 1773, and on 20 October 1773, Warren Hastings became the first Governor General of India. The members of the council were Lt. General John Clavering, George Monson, Richard Barwell and Philip Francis.

questions.Question: 'August Offer' was issued by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		On 8 August 1940, early in the Battle of Britain, the Viceroy of India, Lord Linlithgow, made the so-called "August Offer".

questions.Question: The founder-president of Indian Independence League was
questions.solution: Solution:		Established primarily to foster Indian Nationalism and to obtain Japanese support for the Indian Independence Movement, the League came to interact and command the first Indian National Army under Mohan Singh before it was dissolved. Rash Behari Bose handed over the INA to Subhas Chandra Bose.

questions.Question: Whom had Gandhi named as Mira Behn?
questions.solution: Solution:		Madeleine Slade, also known as Mirabehn or Meera Behn, was a British woman who left her home in Britain to live and work with Mohandas Gandhi, the leader of the Indian Independence Movement. She devoted her life to human development and the advancement of Gandhi's principles.

questions.Question: Who attended the Congress of Oppressed Nationalities at Brussels in 1927, on behalf of the National Congress?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jawaharlal Nehru attended the Congress of oppressed nationalist at Brusels in 1927 on behalf of the National Congress.

questions.Question: Chanakya was known as__________
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: Through which Educational Report Calcutta University came into existence?
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the Wood's Despatch report Calcutta University was established in 1857. The first governor and chancellor of this university was Lord Canning.

questions.Question: __________ started The Adyar Bulletin, which continued until 1929
questions.solution: Solution:		From 1908 onwards Dr Besant proceeded to enlarge the Headquarters estate at Adyar. In order to link Adyar more intimately with the rest of the Theosophical world, she started The Adyar Bulletin, which continued until 1929. Presently the Adyar Newsletter fulfils a similar function.

questions.Question: The All India Muslim League was formed in 1906 at
questions.solution: Solution:		The All India Muslim League was rooted in 1906 at Dhaka. It emerged from the Aligarh Movement, formed originally to promote a modern education for Muslims. Muslim League, political organization of India and Pakistan, founded 1906 as the All-India Muslim League by Aga Khan III.

questions.Question: The first Famine Commission was constituted under
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Famine Commission (1878-80) under Sir Richard Strachey was appointed and it made many commendable recommendations. They include provision of funds for famine relief and construction work in the annual budget. The Famine Code came into existence in 1883. In 1878, the Vernacular Press Act was passed.

questions.Question: The number of members in the Simon Commission/was __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The commission consisted of seven members—four Conservatives, two Labourites, and one Liberal—under the joint chairmanship of the distinguished Liberal lawyer, Sir John Simon, and Clement Attlee, the future prime minister.

questions.Question: The Charter Act of 1793 Renewed the Company's monopoly for __________ years
questions.solution: Solution:		The Charter Act 1793 or the East India Company Act 1793 was passed by British Parliament to renew the charter of East India Company. This act authorized the company to carry on trade with India for next 20 years.

questions.Question: August Offer' was issued on __________ 1940
questions.solution: Solution:		The August Offer was a proposal made by the British government on 08 August, 1940 promising the expansion of the Executive Council of the Viceroy of India to include more Indians, the establishment of an advisory war council, giving full weight to minority opinion, and the recognition of Indians right to frame their own constitution (after the end of the war).

questions.Question: "India for the Indians" was the political message of
questions.solution: Solution:		"India for the Indians" was the political message of Dayanand.

questions.Question: Baba Ram Singh passed away on November 29, __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Ram Singh was promptly deported to Rangoon. Later on he was sent to Andaman under life imprisonment. He passed away on November 29, 1885.

questions.Question:
Murshid Quli Khan, Alivardi Khan and
Sirajuddaullah were all nawabs of__________ ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Murshid Quli khan, Alivardi khan and Siraj-ud-daullah,were the Nawab of Bengal. At the time of Battle of Plassey the Nawab of Bengal was Siraj-ud-daullah.

questions.Question: Who was not among the three revolutionaries who were hanged on March 23, 1931?
questions.solution: Solution:		Azad was not among the three revolutionaries who were hanged on March 23, 1931.

questions.Question: The All India Muslim League was founded in December 1906 at
questions.solution: Solution:		Muslim League was founded in 30 December 1906, the All-India Muslim League was founded at Dhaka.

questions.Question: Which of the following statements is not correct? Provision was made In the Act of 1935 for
questions.optionD: A List of Subjects for Princely States
questions.solution: Solution:		A princely state, also called native state, feudatory state or Indian state (for those states on the subcontinent), was a vassal state under a local or regional ruler in a subsidiary alliance with the British Raj.

questions.Question: During the Second World War Churchill replaced __________ as Prime Minister of England
questions.solution: Solution:		Winston Churchill, First Lord of the Admiralty, is called to replace Neville Chamberlain as British prime minister following the latter's resignation after losing a confidence vote in the House of Commons.

questions.Question: When was the Gandhi Irwin Pact made?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhi - Irwin pact made in 1931, as per this pact Gandhi accepted to attend the second round table conference at London and suspended the civil disobedience.

questions.Question: The Presidents of early English Settlements (Madras, Bombay and Calcutta) were responsible to __________
questions.optionC: The Home Government of the Company
questions.solution: Solution:		The Bombay Presidency, also known as Bombay and Sind from 1843 to 1936 and the Bombay Province, was an administrative subdivision (presidency) of British India. The presidents of early English settlements (Madras, Bombay and Calcutta) were responsible to the home government of the company.

questions.Question: By the Act of 1858, the powers of the Board of Control and the Court of Directors were transferred to __________
questions.solution: Solution:		By the Act of 1858, the powers of the Board of Control and the Court of Directors were transferred to The Secretary of State.

questions.Question: The Portuguese Governor who abolished Sati in Goa was
questions.solution: Solution:		Portuguese Governor Alfanso-De-Albuqurque abolished Sati in Goa. He conquest Goa in 1510.

questions.Question: Who formed SNDP Yogam?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam (SNDP) was founded in 1903 with the guidance and blessings of Sree Narayana Guru.

questions.Question: Which one of the following wars decided the fate of the French in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Battle of Wandiwash was fought in 1760. It was the end of future for the French in Bengal and also in India.

questions.Question: Whom did Bal Gangadhar Tilak refer to as his Political Guru?
questions.optionD: Dadabhai Naoroji E.  None of these
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahadev Govind Ranade was born in 1842 at Biphad in Nasik, Maharashtra. Known to be the mentor and political guru of famous freedom fighters Gopal Krishna Gokhale, and Bal Gangadhar Tilak,he himself was deeply involved in the freedom struggle of India.

questions.Question: The Young Bengal group published the __________(Quest for Knowledge) for propagating their views
questions.solution: Solution:		The Young Bengal group published the Jnananvesan (Quest for Knowledge) for propagating their views.

questions.Question:
The Indian Universities were first founded in the
time of
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian Universities were first founded during period of Lord Canning in three Presidencies.

questions.Question: The leader of the Anuslian Samiti was
questions.solution: Solution:		The revolutionary organisation 'Anuslian Samiti' was started under the leadership of Barindra Kumar Ghosh and Arabindo Ghosh II.

questions.Question: Who was the founder of 'Gadhar party'
questions.solution: Solution:		Gadhar party was founded in 1913 by NRI revolutionary in USA (San Francisco). Main leaders of the Gadhar Party were Lala Hardayal Ramchandra, Bhagwan singh, Kartar Singh Saraba, Barkatullah and Bhai Parmanand. It was dissolved in 1919.

questions.Question: Which one of the following novels was a source of inspiration for the freedom fighters in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Anandmath was written by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee. It is about the Sanyasi Rebellion in 18th century. The famous slogan "Vande Matrarn" was taken from this epic and it was the motivation for the national leaders.

questions.Question: Whom would you associate with the Censorship of the Press Act 1794?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1799, Lord Wellesley brought the Censorship of Press Act, 1799. The idea was to stop the French from publishing anything which could harm British in any way. This act brought all the newspapers under the Government scrutiny before their publication.

questions.Question: The Charter Act of 1813 allotted Rupees __________ annually for Indian learning and spread of Scientific knowledge
questions.solution: Solution:		The first real support came through the allocation of 1 lakh rupees per year by the Charter Act of 1813. Soon after, Hindu college was set up in 1817, which later came to be called Presidency College in 1857.

questions.Question: The maximum number of additional members for the council of Bengal was raised from 20 to __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The maximum number of additional members for the council of Bengal was raised from 20 to 50.

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi's remark, "A post-dated cheque on a crumbling bank" is regarding the proposals of
questions.solution: Solution:		Cripps Mission (headed by Sir Stafford Cripps) came to India in 1942 to secure full Indian co-operation for world war-II. Gandhiji remarked Cripps Mission as Post dated Cheque on a crumbling bank.

questions.Question: Tilak started his career as a
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak (or Lokmanya Tilak, 23 July 1856 – 1 August 1920), born as Keshav Gangadhar Tilak, was an Indian nationalist, teacher, lawyer and an independence activist.

questions.Question: Which was the earliest settlement of the Dutch in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Dutch East Indian Company was established in 1602 with the monopoly of spice trade for 21 year. Its earliest settlement in India was at Pulicat.

questions.Question: Upon whom was the title 'Punjab Kesari' conferred?
questions.solution: Solution:		The title 'Punjab Kesari' was conferred on Lala Lajpat Rai.

questions.Question: Who said "Truth is the ultimate reality and it is God"?
questions.solution: Solution:		This statement was given by the M.K Gandhi because he believed in non-violence and truth.

questions.Question: According to the Regulating Act, Directors were to be elected for a period of
questions.solution: Solution:		According to the Regulating Act, Directors were to be elected for a period of 4 years.

questions.Question: In 1893 __________represented The Theosophical Society at the World Parliament of Religions in Chicago
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1893 she landed in India, made a tour of the country in the company of H. S. Olcott, and, by her splendid presentation of Indian philosophy and her undisguised personal preference for the Indian spiritual heritage, won the support of orthodox Brahmins to Theosophy.The transformation of the religious life in India, particularly among Hindus, is one of the wonders she performed.

questions.Question: The All India Muslim league was founded by
questions.solution: Solution:		All India Muslim League was founded by the Agha Khan and Salim-Ullah-Khan (Nawab of Dhaka) in December 1906.

questions.Question: The Frontier Gandhi actively participated in
questions.solution: Solution:		Khan Abdul Ghaffar was a political and spiritual leader known for his nonviolent opposition, and a lifelong pacifist and devout Muslim. Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan was an active supporter of The Civil Disobedience Movement from The North-West Frontier Province .

questions.Question: Gandhi-Irwin Pact was signed on
questions.solution: Solution:		The Gandhi-Irwin Pact was a political agreement signed by Mahatma Gandhi and Lord Irwin, the then Viceroy of India, on 5 March 1931 before the second Round Table Conference in London.

questions.Question: Among the numerous followers of Gandhi's 'philosophy' was/were
questions.solution: Solution:		Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan was follower of Gandhi's 'philosophy'.

questions.Question: Who was the founder of the Servants of India Society?
questions.solution: Solution:		Servants of India Society was founded on 12 June 1905 by Gopal Krishna Gokhale to build a dedicated group of people for social service and reforms.

questions.Question: Who gave the slogan "Inquilab Zindabad?
questions.solution: Solution:		The slogan "Inquilab Zindabad" was given by the Bhagat Singh. The meaning of inquilab is - Revolution.

questions.Question: Who was in favour of a partyless democracy?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jai Prakash Narayan popularly known as JP or Lok Nayak believed in Partyless democracy. J.P was an independence activist and advocated a program of social transformation which he termed as Sampurna Kranti.

questions.Question: According to __________ the mutiny was a purely military outbreak
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Sir John Lawrence the mutiny was a purely military outbreak.

questions.Question: Aurobindo was arrested in connection with
questions.solution: Solution:		The 'Alipore Bomb Case' was "the first state trial of any magnitude in India". The British Government arrested Sri Aurobindo, a prominent Nationalist Leader at the time, Barindra Ghose, and many young revolutionaries. They were charged with "Conspiracy" or "waging war against the King" - the equivalent of high treason and punishable with death by hanging.

questions.Question: The Tata Iron and Steel Works was completed with the aid of
questions.solution: Solution:		The founder of the Tata Iron & Steel Company - now called Tata Steel - never lived to see it incorporated. TISCO was born in 1907 - three years after Jamsedji Nusserwanji Tata died. Tata had been pursuing the dream of setting up a steel plant in India since at least 1882. In 1902, he even travelled to Pittsburgh to seek the help of American geologist and metallurgist Charles Page Perin.

questions.Question: A Federal Railway Authority was established by the Act of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Government of India Act 1935 introduced the provincial autonomy and provided for an all India federation. This act introduced dyarchy at the central level. This act had 321 sections and 10 schedules. It made a provision for establishment of a Federal court.

questions.Question: Who was the architect of North and South Blocks of the central Secretariat in Delhi?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Edward Lutyens was an British architect. He designed many buildings in India i.e. India Gate, and he also designed viceroy's house which is known as the Rashtrapati Bhavan.

questions.Question: India was partitioned as a consequence of the formula contained in
questions.solution: Solution:		India was partitioned as a consequence of the formula contained in June 3 Plan or Mountbatten Plan.

questions.Question: Who among of the following was the founder of society called 'Abhinav Bharat'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Abhinav Bharat Society was founded by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar and his brother Ganesh Damodar Savarkar in 1903. It was initially famous as a name of Mitra Mela. It was inspired by Mazzini's "Young Italy".

questions.Question: Which year did Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay wrote Anandmath?
questions.solution: Solution:		 Anandmath was written by Bankim Chandra in 1882. The national song 'Vande Matram' was a part of Anandmath. Sanyasi revolt was also described in this epic.

questions.Question: To face the Maratha Army the Rohelas chief entered into a pact with
questions.solution: Solution:		To face the Maratha Army the Rohelas chief entered into a pact withthe Nawab of Awadh.

questions.Question: __________ was primarily responsible for making India a secular State
questions.solution: Solution:		Nehru is known as an architect of Indian secularism. The constitution of India contains his philosophy about the religious neutral state.

questions.Question: One of the following was not involved in the Chittagong Armoury Raid, 1934. Who was he?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dinesh Gupta was not involved in the Chittagong Armoury Raid. Armoury raid was done under the leadership of Surya sen. He was also known as Master Da.

questions.Question: The Minto Morley reforms was in the year __________
questions.solution: Solution:		A 1909 legislative enactment, called the Morley-Minto reforms, conferred some political reforms which encouraged the constitutionalists in the Congress. Indians who could be elected to the legislatures on the basis of the 1861 Indian Councils Act increased numerically.

questions.Question: Tashkent Agreement was signed between India and __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Tashkent Declaration was a peace agreement between India and Pakistan signed on 10 January 1966 that resolved the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965.

questions.Question: For which community were seats reserved by the Morley-Minto reforms?
questions.solution: Solution:		Morley-Minto reforms also known as India council act 1909, the act introduced separate and discriminatory electorate. This was for the first time that, the seats in the legislative bodies were reserve on the basis of religion for Muslims.

questions.Question: Who, among the following, founded the 'All India Depressed Classes Federation' in 1920?
questions.solution: Solution:		It was founded to protect and promote the interest of Depressed classes or Untouchable. In later phase, he urge his followers to leave Hindu altogether.

questions.Question: Narayana Guru was the son of__________
questions.solution: Solution:		There are many legends surrounding the life of Narayana Guru but few certain facts until his rise to prominence in 1887. He was born probably in 1854, the son of an Ezhava peasant, Madan Asan and his wife Kuttiyamma, in the village of Chempazhanthy near Thiruvananthapuram.

questions.Question: With which of the following was Annie Besant Associated?
questions.solution: Solution:		When Blavatsky died in 1891, Besant was left as one of the leading figures in theosophy and in 1893 she represented it at the Chicago World Fair. The original society, then led by Henry Steel Olcott and Besant, is today based in Chennai, India, and is known as the Theosophical Society Adyar.

questions.Question: 'Anthology of the Bomb' was written by
questions.solution: Solution:		Bipin Chandra Pal a powerful orator of the extremist school to which Tilak belonged. Once he wrote an article ' Anthology of the Bomb' for which he was tried, but he apologised.

questions.Question: Wahabis were __________ fanatics
questions.solution: Solution:		Wahhabism is an Islamic doctrine and religious movement founded by Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab. It has been variously described as "ultraconservative", "austere", "fundamentalist", or "puritan(ical)"; as an Islamic "reform movement" to restore "pure monotheistic worship" (tawhid) by devotees; and as a "deviant sectarian movement", "vile sect" and a distortion of Islam by its opponents. Wahabis were Muslim fanatics.

questions.Question: The strategy of 'divide and rule' had been actually practised by
questions.solution: Solution:		The strategy of 'divide and rule' had been actually practised by Lord Minto.

questions.Question: According to __________ the Mutiny was a popular rebellion
questions.solution: Solution:		According to V A Smith the mutiny was a popular rebellion. The Sepoy mutiny which started in 1857 threatened the British East India Company's very presence in India.

questions.Question: The idea of starting a Home Rule League in 1915 was first propounded by
questions.solution: Solution:		The idea of starting a Home Rule League in 1915 was first propounded by Annie Besant.

questions.Question: Who worte "Sarfaroshi Ki Tamanna Ab Hamaare Dil Mein Hai"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sarfaroshi ki Tamanna is a patriotic poem which was written by Bismil Azimabadi in 1921. Later it was immortalised by Ram Prasad Bismil.

questions.Question: The first plans for an Indian railway system was made by
questions.solution: Solution:		The first plans for an Indian railway system was made byHardinge.

questions.Question: Who composed the song "Sare Jahan Se Achha Hindostan Hamara"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Muhammad Iqbal was a famous poet, politician, philosopher and a remarkable academic. He was also a barrister in British India. He used poetry and songs to spread political awareness amongst the people. Iqbal wrote “Sare Jahan se Achha Hindustan Hamara”, the famous song was used as a slogan to rejuvenate the youth with a feeling of patriotism. The abridged version of the song is still sung and is also played frequently as a marching song by the Indian Armed Forces.

questions.Question: The song 'Jana-Gana-Mana' composed by Rabindra Nath Tagore was first published in January 1912 under the title of
questions.solution: Solution:		Jana-Gana-Mana composed by Rabindra Nath Tagore in Bengali language. The song Jana Gana Mana was first published under the title “Bharat Vidhata” in Tattva Bodhini Patrika in January, 1912.

questions.Question: Who is called as the 'Prophet of New India'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sri Ram Krishna is called as the "Prophet of New India". Honors of Sri Rama Krishna is Paramhansa.

questions.Question: Chandra Shekhar Azad was __________ of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Army
questions.solution: Solution:		Chandra Shekhar Azad was Commander-in-Chief of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Army.

questions.Question: Swami Vivekananda was graduated from __________University
questions.solution: Solution:		Swami Vivekananda was graduated from Calcutta University.

questions.Question: Who was advocated of the famous INA Trials?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bhulabhai Desai was advocated of INA trial. INA defence committee, the legal defence team for INA formed by the Indian National Congress in 1945.

questions.Question: Who said about Mahatma Gandhi that he is a "half naked Fakir"?
questions.solution: Solution:		During the second Round table conference Winston Churchill said to Gandhi ji - a half naked fakir and seditious Fakir. A Britisher Frank Morris also titled Gandhiji "A half naked fakir".

questions.Question: For the annexation of which Indian Kingdom, the "Doctrine of Lapse" was not followed?
questions.solution: Solution:		Doctrine of Lapse was not applied on Punjab. Punjab was annexed by Lord Dalhousie after second Anglo Sikkh war (1849). And Last Sikh Emperor was sent to London and he died in Paris.

questions.Question: A Study in Consciousness was written by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Study in Consciousness is a book by Annie Besant that was written in ca. 1904. Besant intended this book to be a contribution to the science of psychology. She writes that the seed of consciousness is the tri-atomic Atma-Buddhi-Manas, the Jivatma.

questions.Question: Who among of the following started Marathi fortnightly newspaper 'Bahishkrit Bharat'?
questions.solution: Solution:		'Bahishkrit Bharat' was started by Dr.B.R.Ambedkar in 1927, his other newspapers are - Mooknayak (1920), Janata (1930) and Prabuddha Bharat (An awakenned India- 1956)

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi was profoundly influenced by the writings of
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahatma Gandhi was profoundly influenced by the writing of Leo Tolstoy notable works of Tolstoy is War and Peace and The kingdom of God.

questions.Question: The Regulating Act was passed in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Regulating Act, (1773), legislation passed by the British Parliament for the regulation of the British East India Company's Indian territories, mainly in Bengal.

questions.Question: As per Cabinet Mission Plan, the strength of the Constituent Assembly would be
questions.solution: Solution:		As per Cabinet Mission Plan, the strength of the Constituent Assembly would be 389.

questions.Question: According to Gandhi, ahimsa could not be construed to mean
questions.optionC: tolerance of the wrong and unjust
questions.optionD: doing good even to the evildoers
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Gandhi, Ahimsa or Non-Violence has a positive meaning also. In positive sense Non- Violence means 'love'. That means one should not love only human being but every living being in the world. When a person claims to be non-violent, he is expected not to be angry with one who has injured him.

questions.Question: The quintessence of Gandhian thought is
questions.solution: Solution:		Satyagraha - the totality or most typical example of Gandhian thought can be regarded as Satyagraha which was the backbone of Gandhian Struggle.

questions.Question: The day (22 December 1939) the Congress Ministries resigned in the Provinces the Muslim League observed
questions.solution: Solution:		On 22 October 1939, the Congress called upon all its ministries to resign in the wake of the viceroy's declaration. On 2 December that year, League chief Muhammad Ali Jinnah called upon Indian Muslims to celebrate 22 December as 'Deliverance Day' from Congress.

questions.Question: Who was the Congress President at the time when India become free?
questions.solution: Solution:		In spite of being ideologically at odds with both the right-wing Vallabhbhai Patel and the left-wing Jawaharlal Nehru – J B Kripalani was elected Congress President for the crucial years around Indian independence in 1947.

questions.Question: The historic fast by Gandhi came to an end as a result of the
questions.solution: Solution:		The historic fast by Gandhi came to an end as a result of the Poona Pact.

questions.Question: Who among the following was impeached in the UK for his actions in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Edmund Burke on the impeachment of Warren Hastings (1788) Introduction: Warren Hastings (1732-1818) was the first Governor General of India (1778-1884). He resigned, returned to England, was impeached for his conduct in India and had to face a trial by Parliament. He was acquitted in 1795.

questions.Question: In Gandhian Socialism
questions.optionC:
State is sometimes required and sometimes
not required
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhian socialism generally centres on Hind Swaraj or Indian Home rule. So according to Gandhiji's socialism state is not required.

questions.Question: 'Amar Shonar Bangla' the national anthem of Bangladesh was composed by whom?
questions.solution: Solution:		Rabindranath Tagore was a great Bengali Poet. He played important role in development of modern literature.He is titled as 'Guru dev'. He win noble prizes for "Gitanjali" in 1913. He also composed the song "JAN GAN MAN" (National Anthem of India) and "AMAR SONAR BANGLA" (National Anthem of Bangladesh).

questions.Question: In the Carnatic, the English supported the claims of
questions.solution: Solution:		The French wanted to reduce the growing influence of the English in the Carnatic. So they supported Husain Dost Khan (Chanda Sahib) as the rightful Nawab of the Carnatic against Muhammad Anwaruddin, who was supported by the British.

questions.Question: The two states which had non Congress Ministries in 1937 were
questions.solution: Solution:		Bengal and Punjab were the two states where Non-Congress Ministries established after elections. In Bengal Muslim league and Krishak Praja party made the government and In Punjab, government was made by the Unionist and Muslim league.

questions.Question: Motilal presided over the Congress Session of 1919 held at
questions.solution: Solution:		Motilal Nehru presided over the Amritsar session of INC in 1919 as well as the Kolkata session of 1928. Motilal Nehru was an eminent lawyer and is the founder patriarch of the Nehru-Gandhi family.

questions.Question: A resolution declaring 'Purna Swaraj' was passed in the Congress Session held at
questions.solution: Solution:		In the Lahore session of December 1929, Congress passed the Poorna Swaraj resolution. It was the same session in which Jawaharlal Nehru was elected as president of the Congress.

questions.Question: Who among the following leader made the famous 'Objectives Resolution', in the Constituent Assembly?
questions.solution: Solution:		An 'Objective Resolution' was moved by Jawaharlal Nehru in the assembly, laying down the underlying principles of the constitution.

questions.Question: Which of the following European Colonisers did not have a settlement on the Eastern Coast of India ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Danish was the one who had not any settlement on the eastern coast of India whereas French settlement in Pondicherry, Portugese have Goa and Dutch in Kochi.

questions.Question: India is in favour of __________ in the economic field
questions.solution: Solution:		In a mixed economy, private and public sectors go side by side. The government directs economic activity in some socially important areas of the economy, the rest being left to the price mechanism to operate. Before Independence, Indian economy was a 'laissez faire' economy.

questions.Question: Who had conceived and founded the Ramakrishna Mission?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vivekananda went on lecture tours and held private discourses on Hinduism and spirituality. He also founded the first Vedanta Society in the United States at New York. He returned to India in 1897 and founded the Ramakrishna Mission on 1 May 1897.

questions.Question: As per Wavell's Plan the external affairs would be under the charge of __________
questions.optionC: An Indian Member of the Executive Council
questions.solution: Solution:		As per Wavell's Plan the external affairs would be under the charge of an Indian member of the Executive Council.

questions.Question: Sati was declared a punishable offence in__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Bentinck when he passed the Sati Regulation Act in 1829. The practice of Sati was declared illegal and punishable by criminal courts.

questions.Question: The Shimla Conference which was convened as per Wavell's Plan ended in failure because of the stiff opposition of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Shimla Conference which was convened as per Wavell's Plan ended in failure because of the stiff opposition of Jinnah.

questions.Question: Siraj-ud-Daulah renamed which city as Alinagar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Siraj-ud-Daulah renamed Calcutta as Alinagar, the treaty of Alinagar was signed on 9 feb 1757 between Robert Clive and Siraj-ud-Daulah.

questions.Question: Who is also known by the name of 'Tiger of  'Mysore'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tipu Sultan Successor of Hyder Ali (Ruler of Mysore), is known as the "Tiger of Mysore" and also known as "CITIZEN TIPU". He was a good administrator and launched many reforms related to Revenue andadministration. He founded the "Jacobian Club" in Mysore. He died in fourth Anglo Mysore war.

questions.Question: Which of the following treaty ended the First Carnatic War?
questions.solution: Solution:		First Carnatic War 1746-48 was a part of the War of the Austrian Succession that was fought between the Kingdom of Prussia, Spain, France, and Bavaria, Sweden etc. on one side and Habsburg Monarchy, England, Dutch Republic, Russia on the other side. This war finally ended with the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle (1748).

questions.Question: During the Anglo-French struggle in the Carnatic, the French were finally defeated by the English in the battle of
questions.solution: Solution:		Battle of Wandiwash, (Jan. 22, 1760), in the history of India, a confrontation between the French, under the comte de Lally, and the British, under Sir Eyre Coote. It was the decisive battle in the Anglo-French struggle in southern India during the Seven Years War (1756–63). During the Anglo-French struggle in the Carnatic, the French were finally defeated by the English in the battle of Wandiwash.

questions.Question: In which of the following provinces the Congress Ministry was not formed in June 1937?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Assam provinces the Congress Ministry was not formed in June 1937.

questions.Question: When the Governor-General was away from Bengal a Vice President appointed by __________ would act for him
questions.solution: Solution:		When the Governor-General was away from Bengal a Vice President appointed by Governor-General would act for him.

questions.Question: The Rama Krishna Mission was established by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Rama Krishna Misson was established by Swami Vivekananda on 1st May 1897 at Belur Math near Kolkata(West Bengal). The Motto of Rama Krishna Mission is "For one's own Solution, and for the Welfare of the World".

questions.Question: The first Swarajist Conference was held at
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Swarajist Conference was held at Allahabad.

questions.Question: Swarajist Party was organised by
questions.solution: Solution:		Swaraj Party, Indian political party established in late 1922–early 1923 by members of the Indian National Congress (Congress Party), notably Motilal Nehru, one of the most prominent lawyers in northern India (and the father of political leader Jawaharlal Nehru), and Chitta Ranjan Das, a nationalist politician from Bengal.

questions.Question: The Deccan Riots of 1874-75 in Maharashtra were directed against
questions.solution: Solution:		In May and June 1875, peasants of Maharashtra in some parts of Pune, Satara and Ahmednagar districts revolted against increasing agrarian distress. The Deccan Riots of 1875 targeted conditions of debt peonage (kamiuti) to moneylenders.

questions.Question: Who led the armed raid on the government armoury at Chittagong in 1930?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chittagong armoury raid held on 18 April,1930 to raid the armoury of police and auxiliary forces form the Chittagong armoury in Bengal which was led by Surya Sen.

questions.Question: The Wahabis operated from
questions.solution: Solution:		The Wahabis operated from Hindukush.

questions.Question: Who of the following attended all the Three Round Table Conferences?
questions.solution: Solution:		Three Round table Conferences were held in London in 1930,1931,1932. Dr.B.R Ambedkar attended allthree Round table conference. Gandhi Ji attended second round table Conference.

questions.Question: Who declared "Swaraj is my birth right and I shall have it"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak is also known as Lokmanya Tilak. He was against the discriminative attitude of British government. He along with Annie Besant started Home Rule Movement across the country, seeking self government in India.

questions.Question: Who said "The Simmon Commission Report should be thrown on a heap of rubbish"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Shivaswami Iyer examined the Simon commission Report and said that this report should be thrown on a heap of rubbish.

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi compared Pherozeshah Mehta with the Himalayas, Tilak with the Ocean and Gokhale with
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahatma Gandhi compared Pherozeshah Mehta with the Himalayas, Tilak with the Ocean and Gokhale with the Ganges.

questions.Question: The Mohamedan Association was founded in __________in 1856
questions.solution: Solution:		The Muslims of Bengal who were largely raiyats and peasants had little interest and connection with this Association. So in order to protect their own interest the Mohamedan Association was founded in Calcutta in 1856.

questions.Question: The first weekly paper published by the INC (in 1889) was
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1889, the committee started to publish India, a monthly journal summarising Indian affairs and news for the British press and politicians.

questions.Question: In May__________, S. Ramaswami Mudaliar and P. Anandacharlu established the Madras Mahajana Sabha
questions.solution: Solution:		Madras Mahajana Sabha was established by S. Ramaswami Mudaliar and P. Anandacharlu in 1884. Its first conference was held on December 29, 1884.

questions.Question: The Act of 1833 concentrated the legislative powers in the hands of
questions.solution: Solution:		the act of 1833 concentrated the legislative powers in the hands of Governor-General in Council.

questions.Question: When was the office of District Collector created?
questions.solution: Solution:		Revenue Collection system was the major problem for east India company in his initial phase Governor General of Bengal Warren Hastings established the office of District collector in 1772 for collection of revenue.

questions.Question: Who declared as his ultimate aim the wiping of every tear from every eye?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jawaharlal Nahru in his speech 'Freedom at midnight"said that the ambition of the greatest men of our generation has to be to wipe every tear from every eye.

questions.Question: Who among the following from the first cabinet of indepenent India was responsible of mass religious conversion?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dr. B. R. Ambedkar argued that converting into Buddhism was the only way for the untouchables to gain equality. In 1956, he started the Dalit Buddhist Movement.

questions.Question: 'Dyarchy' was introduced in the Government of India Act of
questions.solution: Solution:		Dyarchy, also spelled diarchy, system of double government introduced by the Government of India Act (1919) for the provinces of British India.

questions.Question: The problem that exercised and evoked the reformists in the 19th century to the greatest extent related to
questions.solution: Solution:		The problem that exercised and evoked the reformists in the 19th century to the greatest extent related to Women's issues.

questions.Question: The 'Hero of Plassey' was
questions.solution: Solution:		The 'Hero of Plassey' was Clive. Clive decided that the best way to secure the company's interests in Bengal was to replace Siraj with a new and more pliant nawab.

questions.Question: The hero of the Kakori 'Dacoity' case was
questions.solution: Solution:		Kakori Dacoity was a train robbery conceived by Ram Prasad Bismil near Lucknow. It was organised under the banner Hindustan Republican Association.

questions.Question: Who preached the idea of Home Rule through his two news papers - the Kesari and the Maratha?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kesari is a Marathi newspaper which was founded in 1881 by Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak.

questions.Question: The main founder (s) of the Swaraj Party was/were
questions.solution: Solution:		Swaraj Party, Indian political party established in late 1922–early 1923 by members of the Indian National Congress (Congress Party), notably Motilal Nehru, one of the most prominent lawyers in northern India (and the father of political leader Jawaharlal Nehru), and Chitta Ranjan Das, a nationalist politician from Bengal.

questions.Question: As per Pitt's India Act the Committee of Secrecy would consist of three members of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		A committee of secrecy of not more than three members was appointed. The other members of the court of Directors could thus be ignored in important matters.

questions.Question: Who of the following has the distinction of having Authored the National Anthems of two countries of the world?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ravindranath Tagore had written National anthem of two countries and those are India and Bangladesh.

questions.Question: Who had first sought the legalisation of widow remarriage in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ishwar Chandra Vidayasagar

questions.Question: Which of the following was not a common social reform attempted by all the Hindu social reformers of the 19th century
questions.solution: Solution:		untouchability was not a common social reform attempted by all the Hindu social reformers of the 19th century.

questions.Question: Which of the following Government of India Act gave separate representation to the Muslims?
questions.solution: Solution:		Government of India Act of 1909 gave separate representation to the Muslims.

questions.Question: The Muslim League withdrew its acceptance of the Cabinet  Mission Plan and decided to resort to Direct Action Day on
questions.solution: Solution:		Direct Action Day (16 August 1946), also known as the Great Calcutta Killings, was a day of widespread communal rioting between Muslims and Hindus in the city of Calcutta (now known as Kolkata) in the Bengal province of British India. The day also marked the start of what is known as The Week of the Long Knives.

questions.Question: The Nehru Report of 1928 with proposals for constitutional reforms had been prepared by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Nehru Report of 28-30 August, 1928 was a memorandum outlining a proposed new dominion status constitution for India. It was prepared by a committee of the All Parties Conference chaired by Motilal Nehru with his son Jawaharlal Nehru acting as secretary.

questions.Question: Annie Besant joined The Theosophical Society on 21 May __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Annie Besant joined the Theosophical Society in May 1889 and became Blavatsky's devoted pupil and helper. She became a prominent worker in the Society and was elected President which position she held till her death on 21 September 1933. She first came to India on 16 November 1893.

questions.Question: In 1875, Sir Syed founded the Madarsatul Uloom in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1875, Sir Syed founded the Madarsatul Uloom in Aligarh and patterned the MAO College after Oxford and Cambridge universities that he went on a trip to London. His objective was to build a college in line with the British education system but without compromising its Islamic values.

questions.Question: When King George-V and Queen of India visited India, a magnificent Durbar was held at
questions.solution: Solution:		The 1911 Durbar was the only one that a sovereign, George V, attended. The term was derived from the common Mughal term durbar. On 22 March 1911, a royal proclamation announced that the Durbar would be held in December to commemorate the coronation in Britain a few months earlier of George V and Mary of Teck and allow their proclamation as Emperor and Empress of India.

questions.Question: The __________ were the first Europeans to start a Joint stock company trade with India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Dutch were the first Europeans to start a Joint stock company trade with India.

questions.Question: The Alipore conspiracy case was launched against the revolutionary activities of
questions.solution: Solution:		The revolutionary philosophies and movement made its presence felt during the 1905 Partition of Bengal. Arguably, the initial steps to organise the revolutionaries were taken by Aurobindo Ghosh, his brother Barin Ghosh, Bhupendranath Datta, Lal Bal Pal and Subodh Chandra Mullick when they formed the Jugantar party in April 1906. Jugantar was created as an inner circle of the Anushilan Samiti, which was already present in Bengal mainly as a fitness club.

questions.Question: The English established their first factory in India at
questions.solution: Solution:		The East India Company arrived first at Surat, India in 1608 in the ship Hector commanded by William Hawkins and within a few years had established a permanent factory there.

questions.Question: Who is regarded as 'the Mother of the Indian Revolution'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bhikaiji Rustom Cama,or Madam Cama was born on 24 September 1861 in Bombay. She was an outstanding lady of great courage, fearlessness, integrity, perseverance and passion for freedom and is considered as the mother of Indian revolution because of her contributions to Indian freedom struggle.

questions.Question: Who was the first to raise the slogan 'Inquilab zindabad'?
questions.solution: Solution:		The famous slogan Inquilab Zindabad was given by Hasrat Mohani. This famous slogan inspired the activities of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association particularly Ashfaqulla Khan, Bhagat Singh and Chandrashekhar Azad.

questions.Question: Atmopadesa Satakam is the work of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		"Atmopadesa Satakam" is a Malayalam spiritual work by Narayana Guru in the form of a poem.

questions.Question: Nirvruthi Panchakam was written by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Nirvruthi Panchakam was written by Sree Narayana Guru.

questions.Question: Zamindari Association was the political association of modern India
questions.solution: Solution:		The Zamindari Association, which was later renamed Landholders' Society, was established in 12 November 1837 by Dwarkanath Tagore, Prasanna Kumar Tagore, Radhakanta Deb, Ramkamal Sen and Bhabani Charan Mitra. It has been described as “the first organisation of Bengal with distinct political object.”

questions.Question: Who was the Nawab of Bengal during "Battle of Plassey"?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Plassey was fought in 1757 between the Nawab of Bengal Siraj-ud-daulah and east India company. The Victory of the British forces in this battle paved the way the British rule in India.

questions.Question: Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak hailed form
questions.solution: Solution:		Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak hailed fromMaharashtra.

questions.Question: Who is the founder of the concept "Sarvodaya"?
questions.solution: Solution:		M.K Gandhi Translated John Ruskin's work on political economy - "Unto the Last" under the title of 'Sarvodaya' which means 'Universal upliftment'.

questions.Question: Who among the following is known as the "Father of the Indian Renaissance"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Ram Mohan Roy was known as the 'Father of the Indian Renaissance'.

questions.Question: Which of the following leader said that the Act of 1935 provided 'a machine with strong brakes but no engine'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jawaharlal Nehru said that the Act of 1935 provided 'a machine with strong brakes but no engine'.

questions.Question: When was the first train steamed off in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		On April 16,1853, the first passengers train steamed between Bori Bunder in Bombay and Thane.

questions.Question: Of the following, which country's constitution did not influence the fathers of Indian Constitution?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Constitution of The USSR did not influence the fathers of Indian Constitution.

questions.Question: What was Lala Lajpat Rai demonstrating against when he succumbed to police brutality?
questions.solution: Solution:		Simon commission was appointed to report the working of the existing government, it was a six Members commission under the chairmanship of John Simon and it did not consist a single Indian member. Hence, Congress decided to boycott the commission. Lala ji who led the movement in Lahore was Severely injured by lathi charge.

questions.Question: Who founded as Mohammedan Anglo Oriental College (MAOC) at Aligarh in 1875?
questions.solution: Solution:		Muhammadan Anglo Oriental College was founded in 1875, initially as a primary school, with the intention of taking it to a college level institution, known as Muhammedan Anglo Oriental Collegiate School. Its given Urdu name was Madrasatul Uloom Musalmanan-e-Hind. It started operations on Queen Victoria's 56th birthday, 24 May 1875. Sir Saiyad Ahmed Khan found it.

questions.Question: Who founded the Central Hindu School and College in Banaras (now Varanasi)?
questions.solution: Solution:		Founded by noted freedom-fighter Annie Besant in July 1898, with Dr. Arthur Richardson, a science graduate from England as the principal, and went on to become the nucleus of Banaras Hindu University, which was established in 1916. Asia's first Educational conference was held in the ground of the CHBS.

questions.Question: In November 1881, Narendra went to meet __________who was staying at the Kali Temple in Dakshineshwar
questions.solution: Solution:		One day in November 1881, Narendra went to meet Sri Ramakrishna who was staying at the Kali Temple in Dakshineshwar. Apart from removing doubts from the mind of Narendra about the existence of God, Sri Ramakrishna won him over through his pure, unselfish love.

questions.Question: What was the name of the English weekly edited by Mahatma Gandhi?
questions.solution: Solution:		Young India was a weekly paper or journal in English published by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi from 1919 to 1931.

questions.Question: Rohelas were of __________ origin
questions.solution: Solution:		They belonged to an Afghan Ghilzai tribe. It was first Afghan dynasty which ruled large part of the Indian subcontinent between 1290 and 1320.

questions.Question: As a result of the elections held in early 1937 under the Act of 1935 the Congress formed ministries in provinces
questions.solution: Solution:		As a result of the elections held in early 1937 under the Act of 1935 the Congress formed ministries in 8 provinces.

questions.Question: The Secretary of State for India was given powers by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Secretary of State for India was British cabinet minister and political head of Indian office. This post was created in 1858 by Government of India Act which transferred the power to British crown when East India Company rule in Bengal ended and India( except princely states) was brought under the direct administration of the government in London which marked the beginning of the colonial period under British Empire.

questions.Question: Who said that the constant 'drain of wealth' from India was responsible for India's economic miseries?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naoroji was the first man to say that internal factors were not the reasons of poverty in India but poverty was caused by the colonial rule that was draining the wealth and prosperity of India.

questions.Question: 'AI Hilal' was a newspaper launched for propagating nationalism by
questions.solution: Solution:		Al-Hilal (newspaper) was a weekly Urdu language newspaper established by the Indian leader Maulana Abul Kalam Azad and used as a medium for criticism of the British Raj in India. The first issue came out on 13 July 1912.

questions.Question: The song Jana-Gana-Mana composed by Rabindranath Tagore was first published in January 1912 under the title of
questions.solution: Solution:		The song Jana-Gana-Mana composed by Rabindranath Tagore was first published in January 1912 under the title of Bharat Vidhata.

questions.Question: To whom is the statement "Cowardice and ahimsa do not go together any more than water and fire" attributed?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cowardice and ahimsa do not go together any more than water and fire" attributed to M K Gandhi.

questions.Question: Who was the moving spirit behind the oganization of the Ghadar Party?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lala Hardayal was the moving spirit behind the oganization of the Ghadar Party.

questions.Question: Of the following who was a poet and political thinker?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Muhammad Iqbal widely known as Allama Iqbal, was a poet, philosopher and politician, as well as an academic, barrister and scholar in British India who is widely regarded as having inspired the Pakistan Movement.

questions.Question: Who had scrapped the partition of Bengal?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Hardinge had scrapped the partition of Bengal.

questions.Question: __________edited the journal of Poona Sarvajanik Sabha
questions.solution: Solution:		After graduation in 1884, Gokhale joined the Deccan educational Society founded by Ranade. He served the society for twenty years in various capacities as a school master, a professor and principal of Fergusson College, Poona. He also edited the quarterly journal of the Poona Sarvajanik Sabha.

questions.Question: Which of the following event was probe by the Hunter Commission?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Jallianwala Bagh massacre, also known as the Amritsar massacre, took place on 13 April 1919 when troops of the British Indian Army under the command of Colonel Reginald Dyer fired rifles into a crowd of Punjabis, who had gathered in Jallianwala Bagh, Amritsar, Punjab.

questions.Question: Indirect election was introduced in India by the Act of
questions.solution: Solution:		The act of 1892 can be said to be a first step towards the beginning of the representative government in India. However such representation was via only indirect elections and there was nothing for a common Indian. The system of indirect election prevented direct contact between the public and the representatives.

questions.Question: Who was the founder of Banaras Hindu University?
questions.solution: Solution:		Madan Mohan Malviya strived to promote modern education among hindus and eventually founded Banaras Hindu University (BHU) at Varanasi in 1916, which was created under the B.H.U. Act, 1915. The largest residential university in Asia and one of the largest in the world, having over 40,000 students across arts, sciences, engineering, medical, agriculture, performing arts, law and technology from all over the world. He was Vice Chancellor of Banaras Hindu University from 1919–1938.

questions.Question: Of the following who are not given reserved seats in the Indian legislature?
questions.solution: Solution:		Landed Gentry are not given reserved seats in the Indian legislature.

questions.Question: Who among the following did not attend the First Round Table Conference?
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Round Table Conference convened from 12 November 1930 to 19 January 1931. Prior to the Conference, M. K. Gandhi had initiated the Civil Disobedience Movement on behalf of the Indian National Congress.

questions.Question: In 1939 Subhash Chandra Bose was elected as President of the Congress Party defeating
questions.solution: Solution:		In the Tripuri Session of 1939 of INC a deadlock was created due to the ideological differences between M.K. Gandhi and Subhash Chandra Bose and election was held for the post of chairman in which Bose defeated Pattabhi Setharamayya (supported by M.K Gandhi).

questions.Question: The President of the Constituent Assembly was
questions.solution: Solution:		Dr. Sachchidananda Sinha was the first chairman (temporary) of Constituent Assembly. Later Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as the president and its vice-president was Harendra Coomar Mookerjee, a Christian from Bengal and former vice-chancellor of Calcutta University.

questions.Question: Who ruled that pilgrims could wear yellow clothes - the colour of the garments Sri Buddha wore
questions.solution: Solution:		Sree Narayana Guru ruled that pilgrims could wear yellow clothes - the colour of the garments Sri Buddha wore

questions.Question: Who introduced the permanent settlement in Bengal?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Cornwallis introduced permanent settlement in Bengal. Under this fix revenue system was introduced.

questions.Question: Who among the following Governor-General repealed the Vernacular Press Act of Lytton?
questions.solution: Solution:		Governor-General Ripon repealed the Vernacular Press Act of Lytton.

questions.Question: Baba Ram Singh, born at Bhaini, in __________district in 1816
questions.solution: Solution:		Ram Singh was born at Bhaini in Ludhiana district of Punjab in 1816. He joined as a soldier in the Sikh army and there he came under the influence of Bhai Balak Singh.

questions.Question: Mahabandula was killed at __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In December 1824, Maha Bandula opened a broad offensive against the British positions in the area of Rangoon but was defeated and retreated to Danubyu. He defended Danubyu successfully beginning on March 5 but was killed during an artillery bombardment.

questions.Question: Narayana Guru was born on August 22, 1856, in the village of __________ near Thiruvananthapuram
questions.solution: Solution:		Sree Narayana Guru was born on August 22, 1856 (1032 Chingam in Malayalam calendar) in a humble cottage in the pretty hamlet of Chempazhanthi near Thiruvananthapuram. His father was Madan Asan, a farmer, and mother Kutti Amma and he had three sisters. He was named by his father as Narayanan; he affectionately called him Nanu, a short name for Narayanan.

questions.Question: In 1913, the Guru founded an Ashram at __________ called the Advaita Ashram
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1913, the Guru founded an Ashram at Aluva called the Advaita Ashram.

questions.Question: Of the following who died as political prisoner in Lahore prison?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jatindra Nath Das (27 October 1904 – 13 September 1929), also known as Jatin Das, was an Indian independence activist and revolutionary. He died in Lahore jail after a 63-day hunger strike.

questions.Question: Who among the following introduced Ryotwari system in madras?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Thomas Munro introduced Ryotwari system in Madras in 1820. Under Ryotwari System the ryots (peasnts) were given thc direct ownership and British government collected taxes directly from peasant. This system was introduced in Madras, Bombay, part of Assam.

questions.Question: Har Bilas Sarda was instrumental in the passage of the famous Sarda Act of 1930, which provided for
questions.optionB: removal of restrictions on intercaste marriages
questions.optionC: penalisation of parties to a marriage in which the girl was below 14 or the boy was below 18 years of age
questions.solution: Solution:		Har Bilas Sarda was Instrumental in the passage of the famous Sarda Act of 1930, which provided for penalisation of parties to a marriage in which the girl was below 14 or the boy was below 18 years of age.

questions.Question: Who was the first propounder of the doctrine of Passive Resistance ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Doctrine of Passive Resistance was propounded by Aurobindo Ghosh, it was based on a series of articles published by Aurobindo Ghosh.

questions.Question: Who established the Indian Civil Liberties Union in 1936?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jawahar Lal Nehru established the Indian CivilLiberties union in 1936. This is the origin of Human right movement in India.

questions.Question: The term of office of member of the Council of India as per the act of 1919 was
questions.solution: Solution:		The term of office of member of the Council of India as per the act of 1919 was 5 years.

questions.Question: Identify the revolutionary among the following who was not active in London?
questions.solution: Solution:		The revolutionary Ashfaqullah was not active in London.

questions.Question: Who were called "Kukas"?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Namdharis were also known as “Kukas” because of their trademark style of reciting the “Gurbani” (Sayings/Teachings of the Guru). This style was in a high-pitched voice called “Kook” in Punjabi. Thus, the Namdharis were also called “Kukas”.

questions.Question: Mrs Annie Besant became the first woman President of the INC in
questions.solution: Solution:		She launched the Home Rule League in 1916, modelling the Indian plight on that of Ireland. She was a member of the Fabian Society, owing to her close relationship with George Bernard Shaw. In 1917 she became the first woman president of the Indian National Congress at a session in Calcutta.

questions.Question: Who had paned the Vernacular Press Act into law?
questions.solution: Solution:		Proposed by Lord Lytton, then viceroy of India (governed 1876–80), the act was intended to prevent the vernacular press from expressing criticism of British policies—notably, the opposition that had grown with the outset of the Second Anglo-Afghan War (1878–80). The act excluded English-language publications.

questions.Question: The famine in Bihar and Bengal in 1873-74 was averted by the timely action of
questions.solution: Solution:		The famine in Bihar and Bengal in 1873-74 was averted by the timely action of Northbrook.

questions.Question: 'There are no politics devoid of religion' is stated by
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhiji said "there is no politics devoid of religion" and "Politics bereft of religion death trap".

questions.Question: The __________ was run by Tarachand Chakravarty
questions.solution: Solution:		The Quill was run by Tarachand Chakravarty. Tarachand's own paper, Quill, was the mouthpiece of the modernist reform school that he headed.

questions.Question: Tilak was sentenced and transported to
questions.solution: Solution:		Tilak was sent to prison for six years (he spent most of it in a prison in Mandalay, Burma).

questions.Question: 'Confessions of Thug' was written by
questions.solution: Solution:		Confessions of a Thug is an English novel written by Philip Meadows Taylor in 1839 based on the Thuggee cult in British India.

questions.Question: The Hindu College was started in 1817 at
questions.solution: Solution:		Hindu College was established in 1817 by Raja Ram Mohan Roy, Radhakanta Deb, David Hare, Sir Edward Hyde East, Baidyanath Mukhopadhya and Rasamay Dutt.

questions.Question: Jinnah gave his opposition to Wavell's Plan in the Conference held at __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Jinnah gave his opposition to Wavell's Plan in the Conference held at Shimla.

questions.Question: In 1937, the Congress formed Ministries in
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1937 , Congress had clean majority in five provinces i.e.- United provincesU.P., Madras, Bihar, Central provinces (C. P.), Orissa and formed its own government in 5 provinces.

questions.Question: The author of the "The Peri plus of the Erythraean Sea" was a
questions.solution: Solution:		The author of the "The Peri plus of the Erythraean Sea" was a sailor.

questions.Question: The Muslim League demanded creation of Pakistan (Pakistan Resolution) in its session held on March 24, 1940 at
questions.solution: Solution:		The resolution for the establishment of a separate homeland for the Muslims of British India passed in the annual session of the All India Muslim League held in Lahore on 22–24 March 1940 is a landmark document of Pakistan's history.

questions.Question: The Cripps Mission visited India in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The Cripps Mission was a failed attempt in late March 1942 by the British government to secure full Indian cooperation and support for their efforts in World War II. The mission was headed by a senior minister Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal and leader of the House of Commons.

questions.Question: My strongest bulwark is gone lamented Mahatma Gandhi on the death of
questions.solution: Solution:		My strongest bulwark is gone lamented Mahatma Gandhi on the death of Bal Gangadhar Tilak.

questions.Question: The first Indian to enter the Indian Civil Service was
questions.solution: Solution:		Satyendranath was selected for the Indian Civil Service in June, 1863. He completed his probationary training and returned to India in November 1864.

questions.Question: The first President of the Ghadar Party - founded in 1913 in USA was
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1913, Pacific Coast Hindustan Association was founded by Lala Hardayal with Sohan Singh Bhakna as its president, which was called Ghadar Party.

questions.Question: The first statue of the Guru was conceived by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Moorkoth Kumaran was a disciple of Narayana Guru and wrote the first biography of Guru. This biography contains the essence of Guru's message. He has initiated to install first statue of Narayana Guru in Kerala when he was alive.

questions.Question: Who among the following was famous for framing the education minute?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Macaulay was famous for framing education minute, he brought English language as a medium of subject.

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi returned to India from__________  in January 1915
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahatma Gandhi returned to India from South Africa in January 9, 1915. The political Guru of Gandhi was Gopal Krishna Gokhle.

questions.Question: Bicameral Legislature was first provided to India by the
questions.solution: Solution:		Bicameral Legislature was first provided to India by the Government of India Act of 1919.

questions.Question: Who opened the First Round Table Conference?
questions.solution: Solution:		First Round Table Conference was held between November 1930 and January 1931. It was officially inaugurated on November 12, 1930 at House of Lords at London by the British King (George V) and was chaired by then British Prime Minister, Ramsay MacDonald.

questions.Question: Which of the following leaders did not attended the First Round Table Conference?
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Round Table Conference convened from 12 November 1930 to 19 January 1931. Prior to the Conference, M. K. Gandhi had initiated the Civil Disobedience Movement on behalf of the Indian National Congress.

questions.Question: The Mountbatten plan did not envisage the inclusion of the __________ province in the Indian dominion
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mountbatten plan did not envisage the inclusion of the Sind province in the Indian dominion.

questions.Question: The Indian Civil Service Examination was thrown open to all by the Act of
questions.solution: Solution:		From 1858, after the demise of the East India Company's rule in India, the British civil service took on its administrative responsibilities. The change in governance came about due to the Indian Rebellion of 1857, which came close to toppling British rule in the country.

questions.Question: __________'s Darsana Mala is written in Sanskrit
questions.solution: Solution:		The Darsana Mala, or Garland of Visions, was one of the last major works of All Saint Brahmasree Guru Narayana, dictated about 1916.

questions.Question: As per Cabinet Mission Plan, the Princely States would be represented by __________ members in the Constituent Assembly
questions.solution: Solution:		As per cabinet mission plan the princely states would be represent by 93 members in the constituent assembly.
