questions.Question: In the Interim Government formed in 1946, the Minister for Education was
questions.solution: Solution:		In the Interim Government formed in 1946, the Minister for Education was Maulana Abul Kalam Azad.

questions.Question: Who had founded the Indian Home Rule Society?
questions.solution: Solution:		The organisation was founded by Shyamji Krishna Varma, with support from a number of prominent Indian nationalists in Britain at the time, including Bhikaji Cama, Dadabhai Naoroji and S.R. The society was founded amongst efforts and movements that arose to reverse the flow of authority and power from Britain to India.

questions.Question: The main exponent of the theory of Drain of Wealth was
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naoroji's work focused on the drain of wealth from India to England during colonial rule of British in India. One of the reasons that the Drain theory is attributed to Naoroji is his decision to estimate the net national profit of India, and by extension, the effect that colonisation has on the country.

questions.Question: Which great war was fought between the years 1914 and 1918?
questions.solution: Solution:		World War I began in 1914, after the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, and lasted until 1918. During the conflict, Germany, Austria-Hungary, Bulgaria and the Ottoman Empire (the Central Powers) fought against Great Britain, France, Russia, Italy, Romania, Japan and the United States (the Allied Powers).

questions.Question: Who was the first woman President of Congress?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mrs. Annie Beasant was the first women President of Congress (1917, Calcutta session), she was also the founder of Home rule League.

questions.Question: Who had rounded the first women's university in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Shreemati Nathibai Damodar Thackersey (SNDT) University, the first women's university in India. It was founded in 1916 by Dr. Dhondo Keshav Karve, with the objective of educating more women.

questions.Question: Hardayal, an intellectual giant, was associated with
questions.solution: Solution:		Lala Hardayal was a revolutionary attached with Gadar Movement in San Francisco. He inspired many Indians living in US and Canada to fight against British imperialism. He turned down a career in Indian Civil services to participate in National Movement.

questions.Question: Wavell Plan was announced in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		On 14 June 1945 Lord Wavell announced a plan for a new Executive Council in which all members except the Viceroy and the Commander in Chief would be Indians. This executive council was to be a temporary measure until a new permanent constitution could be agreed upon and come into force.

questions.Question: The Constitution drawn by the Constituent Assembly (provided in the Cabinet Mission Plan) would be implemented by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Constitution drawn by the Constituent Assembly (provided in the Cabinet Mission Plan) would be implemented by The British Government.

questions.Question: The 'Doctrine of Lapse' was first applied to the princely State of
questions.solution: Solution:		Satara was the first princely state where Doctrine of lapse applied. The Doctrine of lapse theory was introduced by Lord Dalhousie.

questions.Question: The Hindu Pioneer started in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Hindu Pioneer was started in 1838.

questions.Question: Dandi March started on __________ 1930
questions.solution: Solution:		The historic march to protest against the salt law began on March 12, 1930 and gained momentum throughout India.

questions.Question: Who was the ruler of Delhi when Ahmad Shah Abdali defeated the Marathas in the third Battle of Panipat in 1761?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ahmad Shah Abdali the military General of Nadir shah invaded india during the reign of Shah Alam-II (supported by the Marathas) which lead to Third battle of Panipat in 1761 in which Marathas were defeated by the Abdali.

questions.Question: At Jallianwala Bagh meeting __________ ordered the troops to open fire
questions.solution: Solution:		One of the most horrific massacres of Indians was carried out by soldiers of the British Raj led by General Reginald Dyer, who opened fire on a gathering of unarmed men, women and children at Jallianwala Bagh in Amritsar.

questions.Question: After reading Thomas Paine's famous book __________Jyotirao was greatly influenced by his ideas
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1848, aged 23, Phule visited the first girls' school in Ahmadnagar, run by Christian missionaries. It was also in 1848 that he read Thomas Paine's book Rights of Man and developed a keen sense of social justice. He realised that lower castes and women were at a disadvantage in Indian society, and also that education of these sections was vital to their emancipation.

questions.Question: Who played Socrates to the first generation of the English educated young men of Bengal
questions.solution: Solution:		Henry Louis Vivian Derozio (18 April 1809 – 26 December 1831) was an Indian poet and assistant headmaster of Hindu College, Kolkata, a radical thinker and one of the first Indian educators to disseminate western learning and science among the young men of Bengal. He played Socrates to the first generation of the English educated young men of Bengal.

questions.Question: Bal Gangadhar Tilak earned the epithet of Lokmanya during
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak earned the epithet of Lokmanya during the Home Rule Movement.

questions.Question: Who was the founder of Swatantra Party?
questions.solution: Solution:		After parting away from Congress in 1957, C.Rajagopalachari founded Swatantra Party (Classical Liberal Political Party in 1959).

questions.Question: Who was the first Indian civil servant?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Surendranath Banerjee (10 November 1848 – 6 August 1925) was one of the earliest Indian political leaders during the British Raj. He founded the Indian National Association, through which he led two sessions of the Indian National Conference in 1883 and 1885, along with Anandamohan Bose. He was the first Indian civil servant.

questions.Question: The Governor-General was given power to issue ordinances by the act of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Governor-General was given power to issue ordinances by the act of 1861.

questions.Question: Where was the Royal Durbar Held on November 1st, 1858 to issue to Queen's proclamation?
questions.solution: Solution:		On November 1, 1858, a grand Darbar was held at Allahabad. Here Lord Canning sent forth the royal proclamation which announced that the queen had assumed the government of India. This proclamation declared the future policy of the British Rule in India.

questions.Question: The Pakistan panacea was sponsored by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Pakistan panacea was sponsored by Md Iqbal.

questions.Question: Krishnamohan started the __________ in 1831
questions.solution: Solution:		Krishnamohan Banerjee joined the newly founded Hindu College with a scholarship. In 1831, the religious-reformer-and-litterateur started publishing The Inquirer.

questions.Question: According to the provisions of the Regulating Act the Supreme Court in Bengal consisted of the Chief Justice and
questions.solution: Solution:		According to the provisions of the regulating act the supreme court in Bengal consisted of the chief justice and Three Judges.

questions.Question: Who started the journal 'New India'?
questions.solution: Solution:		New India was a newspaper founded as a means to spread news related to the Indian freedom struggle, and as a means to vocalize the views of its founder, the freedom fighter Dr. Annie Besant, through her editorials.

questions.Question: The Ghadar Party took the name Ghadar from
questions.optionB: its objective to wage another revolt
questions.optionC: a weekly paper Ghadar published in commemoration of the Revolt of 1857
questions.solution: Solution:		The Ghadar party took the name ghadar froma weekly paper Ghadar published in commemoration of the Revolt of 1857.

questions.Question: The first truly revolutionary organisation in Bengal was
questions.solution: Solution:		Anushilan Samiti was a Bengali Indian organisation that existed in the first quarter of the twentieth century, and propounded revolutionary violence as the means for ending British rule in India.

questions.Question: Brahmavidya Panchakam is a Sanskrit work of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Brahmavidya Panchakam is a Sanskrit work of Sree Narayana Guru.

questions.Question: Shuja-ud-Daulah was the Nawab of
questions.solution: Solution:		Shuja-ud-Daulah was the Subedar Nawab of Oudh from 5 October 1754 to 26 January 1775.

questions.Question: Who was the Governor-General when Pindaris had created havoc in Central India by indulging in large-scale looting?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Hastings was determined to suppress the Pindaris. For this, he gathered a large army of 113,000 men and 300 guns and attacked the Pindaris from four sides. He himself took the command of the force from North side while Sir Thomas Hislop commanded the force from the South. By 1818, the Pindaris were completely suppressed and all their bands were disintegrated. By 1824, the menace of Pindaris came to an end.

questions.Question: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad was a scholar in
questions.solution: Solution:		Maulana Sayyid Abul Kalam Ghulam Muhiyuddin Ahmed bin Khairuddin Al-Hussaini (11 November 1888 – 22 February 1958) was an Indian scholar, activist and a senior leader of the Indian National Congress during the Indian independence movement.

questions.Question: Who founded the Ramakrishna Mission?
questions.solution: Solution:		"For one's own salvation and for the welfare of the world" This is the motto of the Ramakrishna Mission which was founded by Swami Vivekananda.

questions.Question: In the famous Kakori Conspiracy Case (August 1925) which of the following revolutionaries was not hanged?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Kakori Conspiracy (or Kakori train robbery or Kakori Case) was a train robbery that took place between Kakori and, near Lucknow, on 9 August 1925 during the Indian Independence Movement against the British Indian Government. The robbery was organised by Hindustan Republican Association. The robbery was conceived by Ram Prasad Bismil and Ashfaqullah Khan who belonged to the HRA, which later became the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association. Snehlata was not hanged.

questions.Question: The revolutionary who died of a 64 days hunger strike was
questions.solution: Solution:		Jatindra Nath Das, also known as Jatin Das, was a revolutionary and Independence activist. He embraced death in Lahore jail after fasting for 63 days on this day, September 13, in the year 1929, aged 24 years.

questions.Question: The first Congress and nationalist leader to face repeated imprisonment was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Congress and nationalist leader to face repeated imprisonment was BG Tilak.

questions.Question: Hevarappathinkangal is a Tamil work of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Hevarappathinkangal is a Tamil work of Sree Narayana Guru.

questions.Question: Sati was prohibited by
questions.solution: Solution:		Governor General Lord William Bentinck passed the Bengal Sati Regalation Act, 1829, which declared the Practice of Sati as punishable offence.

questions.Question: Who shot dead John Saunders on 17th December 1928?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lala Lajpat Rai was lathi charged and died when he was opposing the Simmon commission in Lahore. Bhagat Singh and other shot the Police superintendent John Saunders who was responsible for lathi charge.

questions.Question: Who represented Indian women in The Second Round Table Conference?
questions.solution: Solution:		The second Round Table conference started onSeptember 7, 1931. M.K.Gandhi represented Indian national Congress and Sarojini Naidu represented Indian women.

questions.Question: Identify the body among the following that was not founded by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1880 Vishnushastri Chiplunkar and Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak established the New English School, one of the first native-run schools offering Western education in Pune. In 1884 they created the Deccan Education Society with Gopal Ganesh Agarkar, Mahadev Ballal Namjoshi, V. S. Apte.

questions.Question: The first Indian national leader who began building, organizing and promoting the freedom struggle was
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naoroji was belonged to the Moderates of the Indian National Congress. He was a very strong influence for the other freedom fighters of the Indian independence movement and mentored leaders like Gopal Krishna Gokhale and Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi among the many.

questions.Question: Of the following who did not find a place in the Legislative Council as per the Act of 1853?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Charter act of 1853 provided for appointment of a separate Governor for the Presidency of Bengal, distinct from the Governor General. However, the court of Directors and the Board of Control were authorized to appoint a lieutenant governor, till the appointment of a Governor was made. Please note that the Lieutenant governor was appointed in 1854, but no Governor was appointed for Bengal till 1912.

questions.Question: Author of 'Culture ideology Hegemony Intellectual and Social consciousness in Colonial India' is
questions.solution: Solution:		K. N. Panikkar is Vice-Chancellor of Sree Sankaracharya University of Sanskrit, Kerala. He is the author of 'Culture ideology Hegemony Intellectual and Social consciousness in Colonial India'.

questions.Question: Who among the following has been given honorary status among the seven wonders of the modern world?
questions.solution: Solution:		Great Pyramid of Giza has been given honorary status. Seven wonders of the modern world are Chicken Itza- Mexico, Christ Redeemer- Brazil,The Great Wall- China, Machu Picchu- Peru, Petra- Jordan, The Roman Colosseum- Italy, The Taj Mahal- India.

questions.Question: The Muslim League advocated a separate Muslim State
questions.optionC:
In 1930, when it opposed the Civil Disobedience
Movement
questions.solution: Solution:		At the Lahore Session of 1940 Muslim League advocated a separate Muslim State, Pakistan. The word Pakistan was given by Chaudhary Rehmat Ali. (A student of Cambridge University).

questions.Question: What had the Sir Charles Wood Despatch of 1854 primarily dealt with?
questions.solution: Solution:		Charles Wood was a British Liberal politician and Member of Parliament. He served as Chancellor of the Exchequer from 1846 to 1852. Later he became the President of the Board of Control of the East India Company. In 1854 he sent the “Wood's despatch” to the Governor General Lord Dalhousie.

questions.Question: Which of the following leaders was one of the founding member of the Muslim League?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nawab Sir Khwaja Salimullah Bahadur GCIE KCSI (1871–1915) was the fourth Nawab of Dhaka and one of the leading Muslim politicians during the British Raj. In 1906, the Muslim League was officially founded at the educational conference held in Dhaka. The convention was held at Ahsan Manzil, the official residence of the Dhaka Nawab Family.

questions.Question: Gandhi-Irwin Pact was signed on 5th March __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Gandhi-Irwin Pact was a political agreement signed by Mahatma Gandhi and Lord Irwin, the then Viceroy of India, on 5 March 1931 before the second Round Table Conference in London.

questions.Question: The 19th Century reawakening in India was confined to the
questions.solution: Solution:		The 19th Century reawakening in India was confined to the Upper middle class.

questions.Question: Who among the following reformer associated with the passing of the Widow Remarriage Act?
questions.solution: Solution:		Because of Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar's contribution, the Widow Remarriage Act was passed in 1856 making the marriage of widows legal. Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar worked towards providing education to women. He opened and ran many schools for girls at his own expense.

questions.Question: Who was the first to use the term 'Adivasi' to refer to the tribal people?
questions.solution: Solution:		Thakkar Bappa was the first to use the term 'Adivasi' to refer to the tribal people.

questions.Question: Writing Social History is the book of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Writing Social History is the book of Sumit Sarkar.

questions.Question: "Go back to Vedas" This call  is given by
questions.solution: Solution:		Swami Dayanand Saraswati gave the slogan 'Go back to Vedas'. He was the founder of Arya Samaj, a Hindu reform movements of the vedic tradition.

questions.Question: Jyotiba Phule was one of the prominent __________ of the 19th century India
questions.solution: Solution:		Jyotirao 'Jyotiba' Govindrao Phule was a prominent social reformer and thinker of the nineteenth century India. He led the movement against the prevailing caste-restrictions in India. He revolted against the domination of the Brahmins and struggled for the rights of peasants and other low-caste people.

questions.Question: Who was the National leader who wrote History of India on the walls of the Andaman Cellular Jail?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vir Savarkar was great national leader, he wrote history of Indian on walls of Andaman Cellular jail.

questions.Question: Who designated the administrative head of the district as Collector?
questions.solution: Solution:		MacPherson designated the administrative head of the district as Collector.

questions.Question: Who had set up the Anti-Untouchability League for the eradication of the evil of untouchability?
questions.solution: Solution:		The scrapping of separate electorates was only the beginning of the end of untouchability. Under Gandhi’s inspiration, while he was still in prison, a new organization, Harijan Sevak Sangh was founded to combat untouchability and a new weekly paper, the Harijan, was started. Harijan means "children of God"; it was Gandhi’s name for the "untouchables".

questions.Question: Who attended the Imperial Durbar of 1877 dressed in hand-spun Khadi?
questions.solution: Solution:		Imperial Durbar of 1877 which was first among the three Delhi Darbars, was organised during the Viceroyalty of Lord Lytton. Queen Victoria was conferred with the title of "Kesar-e-hind" in this darbar. It was Ganesh Vasudev Joshi who attended this Darbar dressed in hand-Spun Khadi.

questions.Question: Where did the so-called 'Black Hole Tragedy' take place ?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Black Hole tragedy took place at Fort William in Calcutta in the year 1756. The Background: The Nawab of Bengal gave The East India Company certain special rights as traders in Calcutta and allowed them to build a small fort (the Company named it Fort William) and maintain a small army.

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi began his political activities in India first from
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1917 on the invitation of Raj Kumar Shukla, Gandhi ji visited champaran village in Bihar, were 'Tinkathiya' system was prevalent. In this system farmers were forced to grow Indigo on the 3/20th part of land. Gandhiji organized Champaran Satyagraha to protest against this system.

questions.Question: According to Dadabhai Naoroji 'Swaraj' means
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naoroji, known as Grand old Man of India, was a prominent leader of Indian National Congress. The demand for Swaraj was first raised by Dadabhai Naoroji in Calcutta Session of India National Congress in 1906. According to him 'Swaraj' means self Govemment or 'self rule'.

questions.Question: The Rohelas helped the Afghan invaders in 1761 in the Battle of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Third Battle of Panipat took place on 14 January 1761 at Panipat, about 60 miles (97 km) north of Delhi, between a northern expeditionary force of the Maratha Empire and invading forces of the King of Afghanistan, Ahmad Shah Abdali, supported by two Indian allies—the Rohillas Najib-ud-daulah, Afghans of the Doab region and Shuja-ud-Daula-the Nawab of Awadh.

questions.Question: The landmarks or Dalhousie's administration did not include
questions.optionB: English as the medium of instruction
questions.solution: Solution:		The landmarks of Dalhousie's administration did not include English as the medium of instruction.

questions.Question: The first elected Indian President of the Legislative Assembly was
questions.solution: Solution:		Vithalbhai Patel was elected to the Central Legislative Assembly as one of the candidates of the Congress Swarajya Dal and in 1925 as the first Indian President of the House where he created history.

questions.Question: __________ is remembered as the 'Grand old man of India'
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naoroji (4 September 1825 – 30 June 1917), known as the Grand Old Man of India, was a Parsi intellectual, educator, cotton trader, and an early Indian political and social leader.

questions.Question: One Caste One Religion, One God for Man is the teaching of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Sri Narayana Guru preached the doctrine of 'One caste, One religion, One God.' Its worth note that one of his athiest disciples, Sahadaran Ayyapan, changed into 'no religion, no caste and no God for mankind.

questions.Question: The passage of the Rowlatt Act had been almost immediately followed by the
questions.solution: Solution:		The Rowlatt Act came into effect in March 1919. The army was called into Punjab, and on 13 April people from neighbouring villages gathered for Baisakhi Day celebrations and to protest against deportion of two important Indian leaders in Amritsar, which led to the infamous Jallianwala Bagh massacre of 1919.

questions.Question: The Home Rule League was started by
questions.solution: Solution:		Home Rule movement was a movement in British India on the lines of Irish Home rule movement. It started in India under the leadership of Annie besant and B.G Tilak. Firstly Home Rule established in India by B.G Tilak at Belgam (Karnataka) and later by Annie Besant at Adyar in 1916.

questions.Question: Servants of India Society was founded in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Servants of India Society was formed in Pune, Maharashtra, India on June 12, 1905 by Gopal Krishna Gokhale, who left the Deccan Education Society to form this association.

questions.Question: The Communist Party of India was founded in 1921 by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Communist Party of India was founded in 1921 by MN Roy.

questions.Question: Through which principle/device did Mahatma Gandhi strive to bridge economic inequalities?
questions.solution: Solution:		Trusteeship is a socio-economic philosophy that was propounded by Mahatma Gandhi. It provides a means by which the wealthy people would be the trustees of trusts that looked after the welfare of the people in general. This concept was condemned by socialists as being in favor of the landlords, feudal princes and the capitalists, opposed to socialist theories.

questions.Question: Through which principle or device did Ghandhiji strive to bridge economics inequalities?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ghandhiji postulated the 'Trusteeship theory'. It was a social economic theory based on the principle of "Transforming the present capitalist order of society into egalitarian one".

questions.Question: Who had observed that "Good government was never a good substitute for self-government"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Swami Dayananda observed that "Good government was never a good substitute for self-government".

questions.Question: Who was the only Indian to be elected as President of the United Nations General Assembly?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vijayalakshmi Pandit was the first woman and only Indian till date to become president of United Nations General Assembly. She was also the member of Constituent Assembly and the first Indian woman to hold a cabinet post in pre-independent India.

questions.Question: Gandhi wanted to realise 'truth' through
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhiji always followed the philosphy of non-violence and truth in his movements.

questions.Question: Which of the following leader was associated with the Home Rule League?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak founded the first home rule league at the Bombay provincial congress at Belgaum in April,1916.

questions.Question: The first national leader to decry the salt tax in the Indian legislature was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first national leader to decry the salt tax in the Indian legislature was G K Gokhale.

questions.Question: The Indian National Army (Azad Hind Fauj) fought in the Second World War against
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian National Army in 1942 - 45 fought against GreatBritain along with Japanese during second world war-II.

questions.Question: The Portuguese built their first fort on India soil in the territory of the Raja of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Raja of Cochin even permitted them to build factory and allowed Portugues to stay in Cochin.

questions.Question: Permanent Revenue settlement of Bengal was introduced by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Permanent Settlement (Permanent Settlement of Bengal) was introduced by Lord Cornwallis in 1793. According to this settlement Landlords agreed to have perpetual and hereditary rights over the land, as long as they pay fixed revenue to the British Government.

questions.Question: The Act of __________ had introduced the system of separate electorates
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian Councils Act of 1909, also called Morley-Minto Reforms, series of reform measures enacted in 1909 by the British Parliament, the main component of which directly introduced the elective principle to membership in the imperial and local legislative councils in India.

questions.Question: Which of the following ruler was the first Indian native ruler to accept the system of Subsidiary Alliance?
questions.solution: Solution:		The nizam of Hyderabad was the first to enter into such an alliance. Tipu Sultan of Mysore refused to do so, but after the British victory in the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War, Mysore was forced to become a subsidiary state. The Nawab of Awadh was the next to accept the Subsidiary Alliance, in 1801.

questions.Question: Under whose leadership was the Chittagong Armoury Raid organised?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chittagong armoury raid was organized by Surya sen (popularly known as Master da) along with Kalpana Dutt. It was aimed at dacoiting the British Armoury at Chittagong (then in Bengal, now in present day Bangladesh).

questions.Question: What was the name of the Sabha started by Debendranath Tagore?
questions.solution: Solution:		On 6 October 1839 Debendranath Tagore established Tattvaranjini Sabha which was shortly thereafter renamed the Tattwabodhini (Truth-seekers) Sabha. Initially confined to immediate members of the Tagore family, in 2 years it mustered over 500 members.

questions.Question: Dandi March started from __________ in 1930
questions.solution: Solution:		On 12 March 1930, Gandhi and 80 satyagrahis, many of whom were from scheduled castes, set out on foot for the coastal village of Dandi, Gujarat, over 390 kilometres (240 mi) from their starting point at Sabarmati Ashram.

questions.Question: Commissioners for the Affairs of India were known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The Right Honourable Board of Commissioners for the Affairs of India (commonly known as the India Board or the Board of Control) was an arm of the Government of the United Kingdom responsible for managing the Government's interest in British India and the East India Company between 1784 and 1858.

questions.Question: Which one of the following was not a French settlement in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Goa is a former Portuguese colony, the Portuguese overseas territory of Portuguese India existed for about 450 years until it was annexed by India in 1961. In 1510, the Portuguese defeated the ruling Bijapur kings with the help of a local ally, Timayya, leading to the establishment of a permanent settlement in Velha Goa (or Old Goa).

questions.Question: Who contemptuously referred to Mahatma Gandhi as a halfnaked fakir?
questions.solution: Solution:		British Prime Minister Winston Churchill once called Mahatma Gandhi "a seditious Middle Temple lawyer, now posing as a fakir... striding half-naked up the steps of the Viceregal Palace."

questions.Question: Who called Sree Narayana Guru as 'The Second Buddha'?
questions.solution: Solution:		G.Sankara Kurup called Shri Narayana Guru as Second Buddha.

questions.Question: AI Hilal was a
questions.solution: Solution:		The Al-Hilal was a weekly Urdu language newspaper established by the Indian leader Maulana Abul Kalam Azad and used as a medium for criticism of the British Raj in India. The first issue came out on 13 July 1912.

questions.Question: Muslim communalism was lent an impetus by the activities of
questions.solution: Solution:		Muslim communalism was lent an impetus by the activities of Sayyid Ahmad Khan.

questions.Question: Who threw two bombs on the Door of the Central Assembly in New Delhi on April 8, 1929?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bhagat Singh also disapproved that the two should be escorted after the bombing by the rest of the party. On 8 April 1929, Singh and Dutt threw a bomb onto the corridors of the assembly and shouted “Inquilab Zindabad!” (“Long Live the Revolution!”). This was followed by a shower of leaflets stating that it takes a loud voice to make the deaf hear.

questions.Question: Noakhali is situated in
questions.solution: Solution:		Noakhali is a district in South East Bangladesh 16th August, 1946 was declared the 'Direct Action Day'(also known as Calcutta killings Great) by Muslim League putting forward the demand of separate Nation and the riots broke out at Noakhali.

questions.Question: During the first Carnatic War, the French Governor-General of Pondicherry was
questions.solution: Solution:		General Joseph François Dupleix was the French Governor-General of Pondicherry during the first Carnatic War.

questions.Question: How many volunteers had accompanied Gandhi on the famous Dandi March of March 12, 1930?
questions.solution: Solution:		The 24-day march lasted from 12 March 1930 to 6 April 1930 as a direct action campaign of tax resistance and nonviolent protest against the British salt monopoly. It gained worldwide attention which gave impetus to the Indian independence movement and started the nationwide Civil Disobedience Movement. 78 volunteers had accompanied Gandhi on the famous Dandi March of 12 March 1930.

questions.Question: Who established the 'Sharda Sadan', a school for Indian Widows in colonial India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pandita Ramabai started 'Sharda sadan' (House of Learning) at Bombay in 1889. It was the school of Indian Widows in colonial India.

questions.Question:
In which session of Congress the demand of "Purna
Swaraj" was accepted as the aim of the congress ?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1928, Gandhi ji demanded Swaraj in the coming one year, from the British Government. In Lahore Session of 1929 of INC which took place on the bank of river Ravi under the presidentship of Pt. Jawahar Lal Nehru, the JNC declared 'Purna Swaraj' as its ultimate goal.

questions.Question: The immediate cause for the Mutiny was
questions.optionC: The Episode of the Greased Cartridges
questions.optionD: The fear of me Indians that they would be converted to Christianity
questions.solution: Solution:		The immediate cause of the revolt was the introduction of the new Enfield rifle and the greased cartridge. In loading the rifle the sepoy before inserting the cartridge had to bite off its top. It was believed that the grease was made out of the fats of cows and pigs.

questions.Question: Which religious reformer of Western India was known as 'Lokhitwadi'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Hari Deshmukh was an Indian activist, thinker social and religious reformer who belonged to Maharashtra. He is also known 'Lokhitwadi'.

questions.Question: Who said "Give me Blood, I will give you Freedom"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Subhash Chandra Bose was an Indian Nationalist. He was a member national Planning commission under the leadership of Nehru. He said the famous slogan "Give me blood, I will give you freedom" during the commandership of INA.

questions.Question: As per the Regulating Act, a Governor-General and four Councillors were appointed for
questions.solution: Solution:		The Act designed its chief as Governor- General of Bengal and a council of four members were appointed. The first Governor General (Warren Hestings) and Councilors (Philip Francis, Clavering, Monson, and Barwell) were named in the Act.

questions.Question: Indian handicrafts rapidly declined due to
questions.optionC: stiff competition from the machine-made goods of England
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian handicrafts rapidly declined due to lack of patronage, growing craze for imported goods, stiff competition from the machine-made goods of England.

questions.Question: When Gandhi-Irwin Pact was signed, the Secretary of State for India was
questions.solution: Solution:		When Gandhi-Irwin Pact was signed, the Secretary of State for India was Wedgwood Benn.

questions.Question: Cripps Mission came to India
questions.solution: Solution:		In March 1942, a delegation headed by Stafford Cripps a left wing labourite came to India to seek India's Support in war and offered constitutional proposal in return. Gandhiji referred it as a post dated cheque.

questions.Question: As per the Regulating Act a Supreme Court was established in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Supreme Court of Judicature at Fort William, Calcutta (Kolkata) was founded by an Act of Parliament in 1774. It replaced the Mayor's Court of Calcutta and was British India's highest court from 1774 until 1862, when the High Court of Calcutta was established.

questions.Question: Swami Vivekananda, known in his pre-monastic life as__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Swami Vivekananda, known in his pre-monastic life as Narendranath Datta, was born in Kolkata on 12 January 1863. Born with a yogic temperament, he used to practise meditation even from his boyhood, and was associated with Brahmo Movement for some time.

questions.Question: When the August Offer 1940 was offered to India the Prime Minister of England was
questions.solution: Solution:		When the August Offer 1940 was offered to India the Prime Minister of England was Winston Churchill.

questions.Question: Who had strongly advocated the policy of abolishing princely states in free India?
questions.solution: Solution:		C Rajagopalachari had strongly advocated the policy of abolishing princely states in free India.

questions.Question: Pitt's India Bill was introduced by __________ in 1784
questions.solution: Solution:		Pitt's India Act 1784 or the East India Company Act 1784 was passed in the British Parliament to rectify the defects of the Regulating Act 1773.

questions.Question: When was the First Round Table Conference held?
questions.solution: Solution:		First Round Table Conference (November 1930 – January 1931) officially inaugurated by George V on November 12, 1930 in Royal Gallery House of Lords at London and chaired by the Prime Minister.

questions.Question: Swami Vivekananda's father, __________, was a successful attorney with interests in a wide range of subjects
questions.solution: Solution:		Swami Vivekananda, known in his pre-monastic life as Narendranath Datta, was born in an affluent family in Kolkata on 12 January 1863. His father, Vishwanath Datta, was a successful attorney with interests in a wide range of subjects, and his mother, Bhuvaneshwari Devi, was endowed with deep devotion, strong character and other qualities.

questions.Question: __________ is the acknowledged high priest of the drain theory
questions.solution: Solution:		The acknowledged high priest of the drain theory was Dadabhai Naoroji. It was in may 1867 that Dadabhai Naoroji put forward the idea that Britain was draining India. From then on for nearly half a century he launched a raging campaign against the drain, hammering at the theme through every possible form of public communication.

questions.Question: The name of the periodical published by Gandhi during his stay in South Africa was
questions.solution: Solution:		The name of the periodical published by Gandhi during his stay in South Africa was Indian Opinion.

questions.Question: The majority of the moderate leaders of India's freedom struggle may be traced to hail from
questions.optionD: Both rurals as well as urban parts
questions.solution: Solution:		The majority of the moderate leaders of India's freedom struggle may be traced to hail from Urban areas.

questions.Question: Which one of the following was the first English ship that came to India?
questions.solution: Solution:		East India Company, Second Voyage (1604–1605) The Second Voyage of the East India Company to the East Indies was made by the same four ships that had made the previous voyage, with Red Dragon now under the command of Sir Henry Middleton.

questions.Question: The first Indian selected for Indian Civil Service was
questions.solution: Solution:		Satyendra Nath Tagore was the first Indian to join the Indian Civil Service. He was elected in ICS in June 1863. He was the elder brother of Gurudev Rabindra nath Tagore.

questions.Question: Who founded India House in London and guided other revolutionaries
questions.solution: Solution:		Shyamji Krishna Varma (4 October 1857 – 30 March 1930) was an Indian revolutionary fighter, an Indian patriot, lawyer and journalist who founded the Indian Home Rule Society, India House and The Indian Sociologist in London.

questions.Question: Mohan Das Karamchand Gandhi was called as 'Mahatma' by
questions.solution: Solution:		Rabindra Nath Tagore gave title Mahatma to Mohan Das Karamchand Gandhi after Champaran Satyagraha.

questions.Question: The famous revolutionary song 'Sarfaroshi ki tamanna ab hamare dil mei hai ' was composed by
questions.solution: Solution:		Ramprasad Bismil composed the song "Sarfarosi ki Tamanna Ab Hamare Dil mei hai" during British Period but it was written by Bismil Azimabadi of patna in 1921.

questions.Question: After the 1935 elections, the only two provinces out of eleven which had non-Congress ministries were
questions.solution: Solution:		Provincial elections were held in British India in the winter of 1936-37 as mandated by the Government of India Act 1935. Elections were held in eleven provinces - Madras, Central Provinces, Bihar, Orissa, United Provinces, Bombay Presidency, Assam, NWFP, Bengal, Punjab and Sindh. After the 1935 elections, the only two provinces out of eleven which had non-Congress ministries were Bengal and Punjab.

questions.Question: Subhash Bose established the Provisional Government of Free India at
questions.solution: Solution:		The Provisional Government of Free India, or, more simply, Free India (Azad Hind), was an Indian provisional government established in occupied Singapore in 1943 and supported by the Empire of Japan, Nazi Germany, Italian Social Republic, and their allies.

questions.Question: The Permanent settlement introduced by Cornwallis is in Bengal is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Zamindari System was introduced by Cornwallis in 1793 through Permanent Settlement Act. It was introduced in provinces of Bengal, Bihar, Orissa and Varanasi. Zamindars were recognized as owner of the lands. Zamindars were given the rights to collect the rent from the peasants.

questions.Question: Who was the first Governor General of the new Indian Dominion?
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Governor-General of British India was Lord William Bentinck, and the first Governor-General of independent India was Lord Mountbatten.

questions.Question: Who among the following controlled maximum trade in the western coastal region during 17th century?
questions.solution: Solution:		Portuguese controlled maximum trade in western coastal region during 17th century.

questions.Question: Which amidst the following sites/monuments in India is on the UNESCO's list of World Cultural Heritages?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kashi Vishvanath Temple is one of the most famous Hindu temples dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is located in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, India. The temple stands on the western bank of the holy river Ganga, and is one of the twelve Jyotirlingas, the holiest of Shiva temples. It is not on the UNESCO's list of World Cultural Heritages.

questions.Question: 'Education is the manifestation of the perfection already in man'.Who said this?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vivekananda believed education is the manifestation of perfection already in men. He thought it a pity that the existing system of education did not enable a person to stand on his own feet, nor did it teach him self-confidence and self-respect. To him education was an assimilation of noble ideas.

questions.Question: Which of the following periods is considered as the revolutionary era in Indian history?
questions.solution: Solution:		1857-90 is considered as the revolutionary era in Indian history.

questions.Question: Which of the following events inspired for the formation of the Home Rule Leagues?
questions.optionB: Just before the First World War
questions.optionD: After the passing of the Act of 1909
questions.solution: Solution:		Annie Besant gave new hope to the country. “The moment of England’s difficulty is the moment of India’s opportunity.”She started the Home Rule League Movement to be later supported fully by Tilak. It aimed at self-government for India within the British Commonwealth. She was more Indian than most Indians, a woman of profound courage and determination. The movement soon made a great impact upon the people.

questions.Question: Mahabandula was the great General of the
questions.solution: Solution:		General Maha Bandula was commander-in-chief of the Royal Burmese Armed Forces from 1821 until his death in 1825 in the First Anglo-Burmese War.

questions.Question: When was the All India Women's Conference founded?
questions.solution: Solution:		All India Women's conference was founded in 1927 and registered in 1930,under the societies registration act XXI of 1850, It is an organization dedicated to the upliftment and betterment of women. It was founded by Margaret Cousins.

questions.Question: Jathi Nirnayam is the work of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		A Critique on Jati (Casteism) by Sree Narayana Guru Translated by Muni Narayana Prasad written in 1914, this work deals with concept of Jati (Casteism).

questions.Question: Ram Prasad Bismil had been associated with the case?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Kakori Conspiracy (or Kakori train robbery or Kakori Case) was a train robbery that took place between Kakori and, near Lucknow, on 9 August 1925 during the Indian Independence Movement against the British Indian Government. The robbery was organised by Hindustan Republican Association (HRA). The robbery was conceived by Ram Prasad Bismil and Ashfaqullah Khan who belonged to the HRA, which later became the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association.

questions.Question: Who among the following leader draws his inspiration from M.K Gandhi?
questions.solution: Solution:		Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan, also known as the 'Frontier Gandhi', was a political and spiritual leader known for his belief in non-violence and the methods of opposition to the British adopted by Mahatma Gandhi.

questions.Question: Who among the following organised the "All India Depressed Classes Association" in colonial India?
questions.solution: Solution:		"All India Depressed class Association" was organized by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar at Nagpur on August 8, 1930.

questions.Question: In __________ , Jyotiba Phule formed the Satya Shodhak Samaj (Society of Seekers of Truth)
questions.solution: Solution:		Satyashodhak Samaj (Truth-seekers' Society) is a social reform society founded by Jyotiba Phule in Pune, India, on 24 September 1873. Its purpose was to liberate the less privileged in the then prevailing society such as women, Shudra, and Dalit from exploitation and oppression.

questions.Question: The Servants of India Society was founded in 1905 by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Servants of India Society was formed in Pune, Maharashtra, on June 12, 1905 by Gopal Krishna Gokhale, who left the Deccan Education Society to form this association.

questions.Question: Which of the following Acts had provision of Indian Civil Services recruitment on the basis of competitive examination?
questions.solution: Solution:		Charter Act of 1853 had provision of Indian Civil Services recruitment on the basis of competitive examination.

questions.Question: First Indian Commander-in-Chief was
questions.solution: Solution:		Field Marshal K. M. Cariappa or Kodandera "Kipper" Madappa Cariappa OBE (28 January 1899 – 15 May 1993) was the first Indian commander-in-chief (C-in-C) of the Indian Army. He led Indian forces on the Western Front during the Indo-Pakistani War of 1947.

questions.Question: In 1901 the State Census Manual of __________recorded Sree Narayana as a revered "Guru" and an erudite Sanskrit scholar
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1901 the State Census Manual of Travancore recorded Sree Nārāyana as a revered " Guru" and an erudite Sanskrit scholar.

questions.Question: The Government of India Act of 1935 had divided India into __________ provinces
questions.solution: Solution:		The Government of India Act of 1935 had divided India into 11 provinces.

questions.Question: Who played an important role in bringing all the states in the independent India into the country's unity?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vallabhbhai Patel is the single most important reason that we have inherited the India that we have today – the political and geographic landmass we call India, without which there can be no 'idea of India'. Sardar Patel played an important role in bringing all the states in the independent India into the country's unity.

questions.Question: The first to come and last to leave India were
questions.solution: Solution:		Portuguese was the first voyage to India was by Vasco de Gama in 1498. The Portuguese Settlement in India is supposed to have lasted between 1505 and 1962. The most famous governor among the Portuguese was Alfonso de Albuquerque.

questions.Question: The Dyarchy which was introduced on 1921 in province was in force till the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The Dyarchy which was introduced on 1921 in province was in force till the year 1937.

questions.Question: Who gave the concept of Total Revolution?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jayaprakash Narayan was an Indian Independece activist. He gave the concept of Total Revolution which is political, social, economic, cultural, ideological, educational and motivational revolution.

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi had been present at the Round Table Conference(s) held in London
questions.solution: Solution:		The second Round Table Conference was held in London from 7 September 1931 to 1 December 1931 with the participation of Gandhi and the Indian National Congress.

questions.Question: Sir Saiyad breathed his last on Sunday, 27th March__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Syed breathed his last on March 27, 1898 and was buried in the premises of the university mosque in the Sir Syed Hall, AMU.

questions.Question: The 'Mohammadan Anglo-Oriental College' later became the
questions.solution: Solution:		Aligarh Muslim University established by Sir Sayyed Ahmad Khan as Mohammadan Anglo-Oriental College in 1875.

questions.Question: High courts were established in Calcutta, Bombay and Madras in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Calcutta, Bombay and Madras high court were established in 1862 by the Indian High court act of 1861, which was authorized by the Parliament ofUnited Kingdom.

questions.Question: The Special Congress Session held in 1920 at Calcutta was presided over by
questions.solution: Solution:		On 4 September 1920, Congress met at Calcutta in a special session. This special session was presided by Lala Lajpat Rai.

questions.Question: Lahore was Ranjeet Singh's political capital. Which city was called his religious capital?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ranjeet Singh was famous Sikh ruler of Punjab, Amritsar was his religious capital. Lahore was the political capital.

questions.Question: The communal electorate was introduced for the first time in India in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Communal electorate (for Muslim) was introduced for the first time by Morley Reforms in 1909.

questions.Question: The reformer from Maharashtra popularly known as 'Lokhitavadi' (For the well of others) was
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Hari Deshmukh (18 February 1823 – 9 October 1892) was an Indian activist, thinker, social reformer and writer from Maharashtra. His original surname was Shidhaye. Because of 'Vatan' (right of Tax collection) that the family had received,the family was later called Deshmukh.

questions.Question: The Bombay Association, the first political association in Bombay presidency was founded by __________ in 1852
questions.solution: Solution:		The first political association in Bombay presidency was founded by Dadabhai Naoroji in 1852, to express public grievances to the British.

questions.Question: Who was the founder of the, Ghadar Party?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ghadar Party was founded by the Lala Hardyal in United States and Canada in 1913. Sohan Singh Bhakna was the president of Ghadar Party.

questions.Question: Kasturba Gandhi died in detention (in 1944) at
questions.solution: Solution:		Kasturba Gandhi died in detention (in 1944) at Aga Khan Palace.

questions.Question: Jyotiba Phule died On 28 November,__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Jyotiba Phule died On 28 November,1890.

questions.Question: Who founded the Naujawan Bharat Sabha?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Naujawan Bharat Sabha was founded by Sardar Bhagat Singh.

questions.Question: The first Defence Minister of India was
questions.solution: Solution:		On 15 August 1947, India became an independent nation and Baldev Singh became India's first Minister of Defence, under the first Prime Minister of India, Jawaharlal Nehru.

questions.Question: The system of civil services had been introduced into India by
questions.solution: Solution:		Governor-General Lord William Bentick paid attention to new administrative reforms and introduced some changes in the sphere of administration. He started the practice of appointing Indians in Company's service.

questions.Question: The upliftment of the backward classes had been the prime concern of the
questions.solution: Solution:		The upliftment of the backward classes had been the prime concern of the Satyashodhak Samaj.

questions.Question: Who was the author of the book My Experiment with Truth?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mohan Das Karam Chand Gandhi was the author of book 'My Experient with Truth'.

questions.Question: Narayana Guru's later literary and philosophical masterpiece Atmopadesa Satakam was written in__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Narayana Guru's later literary and philosophical masterpiece Atmopadesa Satakam was written in Malayalam.

questions.Question: The Hindu of Madras started in 1868 as a weekly, became a Daily in
questions.solution: Solution:		In Madras, the Hindu was started as a weekly in 1868 which became tri-weekly in 1883 and a daily from 1889.

questions.Question: In which year was Burma separated from India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The British separated Burma Province from British India in 1937 and granted the colony a new constitution calling for a fully elected assembly, with many powers given to the Burmese, but this proved to be a divisive issue as some Burmese felt that this was a ploy to exclude them from any further Indian reforms.

questions.Question: As per the Act of 1853 the Governor-General's Council was enlarged for the purpose of
questions.solution: Solution:		As per the Act of 1853 the Governor-General's Council was enlarged for the purpose of Legislation.

questions.Question: Narendra MandaI was inaugurated by Duke of Connaught in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Narendra MandaI was inaugurated by Duke of Connaught in the year 1921.

questions.Question: Who was the founder-editor of the famous newspaper 'Kesari' during the National Struggle?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kesari is a newspaper founded in 1881 by Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak, a prominent leader of the Indian Independence movement.

questions.Question: With which of the following would you associate Jyotiba Phule?
questions.solution: Solution:		Satyashodhak Samaj (Truth-seekers' Society) is a social reform society founded by Jyotiba Phule in Pune, India, on 24 September 1873. Its purpose was to liberate the less privileged in the then prevailing society such as women, Shudra, and Dalit from exploitation and oppression. Jyotibha's wife Savitribai was the head of women's section of the society.

questions.Question: Who was the first leader to preside over the INC?
questions.solution: Solution:		Womesh Chandra Banerjee presided over the first session of the Indian National Congress held at Bombay in 1885 from 28 December to 31 December.

questions.Question: The first newspaper which was published in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		Hickey's Bengal Gazette was an English newspaper published from Kolkata (then Calcutta), India. It was the first major newspaper in India, started in 1780. It was published for two years. Founded by James Augustus Hicky, a highly eccentric Irishman who had previously spent two years in Jail for debt.

questions.Question: Who among the following leader presided the historic 1916 Lucknow Session of the Congress?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ambika Charan Majumdar presided over the 1899 Bengal Provincial Conference at Burdwan as well as the 1910 Conference in Calcutta. He had served as the president of the 31st session of the Indian National Congress in 1916 where the famous Lucknow Pact was signed between the Congress and the Muslim league and also moderates and extremists of the Congress party came together once again.

questions.Question: Who did Mahatma Gandhi recognise as his political Guru?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Krishna Gokhale was a mentor to both Mohammed Jinnah and Mahatma Gandhi. Born on May 9, 1866, he is known to be a mentor to Mahatma Gandhi. Gopal Krishna Gokhale was also a social reformer whose goals were to promote non-violence and reform within existing government institutions.

questions.Question: Which scripture was called his 'mother' by Gandhiji?
questions.solution: Solution:		No other book or Scripture influenced Gandhi, shaped his character and transformed his life as profoundly and permanently as did the Bhagvad Gita, As a spiritual reference book, the Gita was not only his constant companion, it was his "eternal mother" who he esteemed even more than his earthly mother.

questions.Question: The joint session of the Congress and Muslim League was held in 1916 at
questions.solution: Solution:		The Lucknow Pact was an agreement reached between the Indian National Congress and the Muslim League at the joint session of both the parties held in Lucknow in December 1916.

questions.Question: In which year was the All India Muslim League founded?
questions.solution: Solution:		Founded in In 30 December 1906, the All-India Muslim League was founded at Dhaka. Founders: Khwaja Salimullah, Vikar-ul-Mulk, Syed Amir Ali, Syed Nabiullah.

questions.Question: Against Lord and State was written by
questions.solution: Solution:		Against Lord and State was written by K N Panikkar.

questions.Question: The ruler of Mysore who secured the rendition of Mysore was
questions.solution: Solution:		The ruler of Mysore who secured the rendition of Mysore was Krishnaraja III.

questions.Question: Which governor General abolished the 'Sati System' in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sati System in india was abolished by Governor General Lord William Bentinck. Indian Social Reformer Raja Ram Mohan Roy also played an important role to abolish Sati system.

questions.Question: Who started the Sharda Sadan in Bombay?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1889, Ramabai started Sharada Sadan in the erstwhile Bombay with two students and a principle of observing complete religious freedom. It then moved to Pune and later became Pandita Ramabai Mukti Mission.

questions.Question: Shuja-ud-Daulah wanted to acquire the territory of
questions.solution: Solution:		Shuja-ud-Daulah wanted to acquire the territory of Rohelas.

questions.Question: Who had introduced the Indian Universities Act 1904?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Curzon had introduced the Indian Universities Act 1904.

questions.Question: Name the Commission that came to India in 1928 to reform India's constitutional system
questions.solution: Solution:		Simon Commission came to India in 1928 to reform India's constitutional system. Indian opposed this commission because there were no Indian members in this commission (also called white commission).

questions.Question: Who said that "India's Soul live in villages"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahatma Gandhi said that "India's Soul live in villages."

questions.Question: The office of the Secretary of State for India was created by the Act of
questions.solution: Solution:		The First Secretary of State of India: Lord Stanley. The first Secretary of state was Lord Stanley, who prior to 2 August 1858, served as President of the Board of Control. The Secretary of State was now the political head of the India.

questions.Question: "Sir Saiyad was a prophet of education" who said this?
questions.solution: Solution:		The words were said by Mahatma Gandhi.

questions.Question: The Deccan Educational Society founded by
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1885 Ranade, Vaman Abaji Modak, and historian Dr. R. G. Bhandarkar established the Maharashtra Girls Education Society and Huzurpaga, the oldest girls high school in Maharashtra.

questions.Question: Who had succeeded Mir Jafar to the throne?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mir Qasim was the Nawab of Bengal from 1760 to 1763. He was installed as Nawab with the support of the British East India Company, replacing Mir Jafar, his father-in-law, who had himself been supported earlier by the East India Company after his role in the Battle of Plassey.

questions.Question: "India Wins Freedom" is the autobiography of
questions.solution: Solution:		"India wins freedom" is the autobiography of Abul Kalam Azad. His Birthday (11 November) is celebrated as " National Education day" Bharat Ratna was conferred to him in 1992 (Posthumously). In 1923 he became the youngest president of Congress in Delhi session and also served as congress president from 1940 to 1945. He became the first education minister of independent India.

questions.Question: The Asiatic Society had been established in Calcutta by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Asiatic Society was founded by civil servant Sir William Jones on 15 January 1784 in a meeting presided over by Sir William Jones, Justice of the Supreme Court of Judicature at Fort William Calcutta, then capital of the British Raj, to enhance and further the cause of Oriental research.

questions.Question: A 19th century social reformer who is regarded as the bridge between the past and the future is
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Ram Mohan Roy is considered to be the first Indian who tried to pull out the Indian society out of the medieval age. He is known as "Father of Modern India"; "Father of Indian Renaissance" and "bridge between past and future".

questions.Question: Satyarth Prakash was written by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The book Satyarth Prakash was written by Swami Dayanand Saraswati. The word Satya Prakash means “The Light of Truth” is a book written in Hindi in the year 1875. The major portion of the book is dedicated to laying down the reformist advocacy of Swami Dayanand.

questions.Question: Pazhassi Samarangal (Malayalam) was written by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		K.K.N.Kurup has published numerous works in both English and Malayalam. Pazhassi Samarangal (Malayalam) was written by him.

questions.Question: Constituent Assembly of India was formulated on the recommendation of
questions.solution: Solution:		Constituent assembly of India was formulated on the recommendation of Cabinet mission 1946. The members of Cabinet Misson were Patthick Lawrence, Stafford Cripps and A.B Alexander.

questions.Question: The socialist group in the INC during, the 1930s had been led by
questions.solution: Solution:		The socialist group in the INC during, the 1930s had been led by Subhas Chandra Bose.

questions.Question: 'A day of deliverance and thanks giving' was celebrated in 1939 by
questions.solution: Solution:		On 2 December that year, League chief Muhammad Ali Jinnah called upon Indian Muslims to celebrate 22 December as 'Deliverance Day' from Congress.

questions.Question: The revolutionary who was an accused in Lahore Conspiracy Case and who died in Jail after 64 days fast was
questions.solution: Solution:		Jatindra Nath Das (27 October 1904 – 13 September 1929), also known as Jatin Das, was an Indian independence activist and revolutionary. He died in Lahore jail after a 63-day hunger strike.

questions.Question: Who said Ask not, Say not, Think not caste, Think only Gods
questions.solution: Solution:		The slogan popularized by Sree Narayana Guru-“One caste, one religion and one God for mankind”. He taught “Whatever may be the religion of a man, it is enough if he becomes virtuous”, “Ask not, Say not, think not caste”, “Act that one performs for one's sake should also benefit other”.

questions.Question: On the Direct Action Day unprecedented bloodshed took place (as a result of Hindu-Muslim riots) in
questions.solution: Solution:		Direct Action Day or The Great Calcutta Killing was a planned attack on the Hindus of Calcutta by the Muslims under the leadership of Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy. On this day more than 5000 Hindus were killed by the fanatic Muslim mob.

questions.Question: In which session of India National Congress the tricolour flag was unfurled for the first time?
questions.optionB: Annual Session of Congress at Nagpur, 1920
questions.solution: Solution:		At Lahore congress session, 1929 Indian National Congress unfurled flag first time.

questions.Question: Who was the first to give the call for Swarajya – "India for Indians"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dayananda Saraswati [1824-1883] was the first to give the call for Swarajya – "India for Indians" – in 1876. Dayananda Saraswati was the first to dispute the Aryan myth was, rejecting out of hand the entire 19th Century European view of the Veda.

questions.Question: Aligarh Muslim University was founded by
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Syed Ahmed Khan established the MAO College which eventually became the Aligarh Muslim University.

questions.Question: With whom is the slogan "Do or Die" associated?
questions.solution: Solution:		On the night of 8th August 1942 addressing the Congress delegates Mahatma Gandhi gave the the slogan "Do or Die". It means we shall either free India or die in the attempt.

questions.Question: The Charter Act of 1813 left intact the Company's monopoly of __________ trade
questions.solution: Solution:		The Charter act of 1813 ended the monopoly of the East India Company in India, however the company's monopoly in trade with china and trade in tea was remained intact. The charter act of 1813, for the first time explicitly defined the constitutional position of the British territories in India.

questions.Question: Who started the Young Men's Indian Association in 1914?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1914, when Annie Besant, the president of the Theosophical Society, founded the Young Men's Indian Association (YMIA), she chose Gokhale Hall as its headquarters, where the youth would indulge in sports from table tennis to boxing and sit on the verandahs debating on the nation's affairs.

questions.Question: Who was the first European to translate the Bhagavad Gita into English?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1785, the Bhagavad Gita was first translated into English by Charles Wilkins and published as “Bhagvat-geeta or Dialogues of Kreeshna and Arjoon” by the British East India Company with an introduction by Lord Warren Hastings, the first British Governor-General of India.

questions.Question: Which of the following leader was associated with the formation of the Congress Socialist Party?
questions.solution: Solution:		Acharya Narendra Dev was associated with the formation of the Congress Socialist Party. Acharya Narendra Deva became president.

questions.Question: The main brain behind hurling a bomb at Lord Hardinge, while he was making his state entry into Delhi was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Delhi Conspiracy case, also known as the Delhi-Lahore Conspiracy, refers to a conspiracy in 1912 to assassinate the then Viceroy of India, Lord Hardinge, on the occasion of transferring the capital of British India from Calcutta to New Delhi. Hatched by the Indian revolutionary underground in Bengal and Punjab and headed by Rashbehari Bose, the conspiracy culminated on the attempted assassination on 23 December 1912 when a homemade bomb was thrown into the Viceroys's Howdah when the ceremonial procession moved through the Chandni Chowk suburb of Delhi.

questions.Question: Which of the following personality is related with the "Deepavali Declaration"?
questions.solution: Solution:		The "DEEPAVALI DECLARATION" passed during the tenure of Lord Irwin in 1929(just after simon comission 1928).It was just a show leaf to indians for dominion status that was to be not granted anywhere in the near future.

questions.Question: The 'political philosophy' was the work of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Krishna Gokhale was prominent leader of Indian Independence Movement. Gokhale's political thought revolves around the socio- political issues. He appreciated and welcomed the British rule in India. He was essentially a liberal thinker and preferred constitutional methods for attaining the goal of self government.

questions.Question: A letter to the Mughal emperor Jahangir from King James I had been presented by
questions.solution: Solution:		“In 1614 Sir Thomas Roe was instructed by James I to visit the court of Jahangir, Emperor Jahangir's letter to James I, King of England, 1617 A.D.It was named after Mughal Emperor Jahangir in 1610.

questions.Question: In 1917 Anasuya Sarabhai had led the __________textile workers' strike
questions.solution: Solution:		Sewa founder Ela Bhatt presided over the function. Exactly a century ago on December 4, 1917, 'Motaben' Anasuya Sarabhai had organized the textile labour force under one umbrella organization mentored by Mahatma Gandhi. Back in 1917 textile workers in Ahmedabad were demanding a 50% hike in plague bonus.

questions.Question: Who among the following was the real founder of the Aligarh Muslim University?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Anglo–Indian statesman Syed Ahmad Khan founded the predecessor of AMU, the Muhammadan Anglo Oriental College, in 1875 having already established two schools. The movement of Muslim awakening associated with Syed Ahmad Khan and M.A.O. College came to be known as Aligarh Movement.

questions.Question: The revolutionary leader who had organized an attack on the armoury of Chittagong was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Chittagong armoury raid, also known as the Chittagong uprising, was an attempt on 18 April 1930 to raid the armoury of police and auxiliary forces from the Chittagong armoury in the Bengal Presidency of British India (now in Bangladesh) by armed Indian independence fighters led by Surya Sen.

questions.Question: Where was the 'Azad Hind Fauj' founded?
questions.solution: Solution:		"Azad Hind fauz" was founded in Singapore. The chief commander of Indian National Army(INA) was Subhash Chandra Bose.

questions.Question: The use of the mother tongue in India in the law Court was permitted by
questions.solution: Solution:		The use of the mother tongue in India in the law Court was permitted by Bentinck.

questions.Question: Of the following who was not the leader of the Extremists?
questions.solution: Solution:		Hume was not the leader of the Extremists.

questions.Question: Who had observed that "Political freedom is the life-breath of a nation"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sri Aurobindo (born Aurobindo Ghose; 15 August 1872 – 5 December 1950) was an Indian philosopher, yogi, guru, poet, and nationalist. He joined the Indian movement for independence from British rule, for a while was one of its influential leaders and then became a spiritual reformer, introducing his visions on human progress and spiritual evolution. Sri Aurobindo said that political freedom is the life breath of a nation.

questions.Question: SN Banerjee was appointed Professor in English in the Metropolitan Institute at
questions.solution: Solution:		Upon his return to India in June 1875, Banerjee became an English professor at the Metropolitan Institution, the Free Church Institution and at the Rippon College, now Surendranath College, founded by him in 1882.

questions.Question: Who amidst the following great music composers was the ruler of a  State?
questions.solution: Solution:		Swati Thirunal Rama Verma was the Maharaja of Travancore Kingdom of British India. He was a great musician of both carnatic and Hindustani music.

questions.Question: The Muslim League passed a resolution demanding the partition of India in the __________ session held in 1940
questions.solution: Solution:		The resolution for the establishment of a separate homeland for the Muslims of British India passed in the annual session of the All India Muslim League held in Lahore on 22–24 March 1940 is a landmark document of Pakistan's history.

questions.Question: The President of the Congress Sessions of 1898 and 1902 was
questions.solution: Solution:		Banerjee played a prominent role in the Indian National Congress from the time of its founding in 1885 in Bombay. Banerjee merged his organization with the INC, owing to their common objectives and memberships. He served as Congress President in 1895 and 1902.

questions.Question: Which of the following was established by B. R. Ambedkar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Scheduled Castes Federation (SCF) was an organisation in India founded by B. R. Ambedkar in 1942 to campaign for the rights of the Dalit community. Ambedkar had founded the Depressed Classes Federation (DCF) in 1930 and the Independent Labour Party (ILP) in 1935.

questions.Question: Gokhale was born in a Marathi Brahmin family at __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Gokhale was born in a Marathi Brahmin family at Ratnagiri.

questions.Question: Who established Narayana Gurukulam in 1923 in the Nilgiri Hills with the blessings of Narayana Guru?
questions.solution: Solution:		 Nataraja Guru, introduced Guru's visions and ideals to the western world and established Narayana Gurukulam in 1923 in the Nilgiri Hills.

questions.Question: The first Indian who was elected to the leadership of the Communist International was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Indian who was elected to the leadership of the Communist International was MN Roy. Manabendra Nath Roy (21 March 1887 – 26 January 1954), born Narendra Nath Bhattacharya, was an Indian revolutionary, radical activist and political theorist, as well as a noted philosopher in the 20th century. Roy was a founder of the Mexican Communist Party and the Communist Party of India. He was also a delegate to congresses of the Communist International and Russia's aide to China.

questions.Question: Who had founded the Deccan Educational Society?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahadev Govind Ranade (18 January 1842 - 16 January 1901) was an Indian scholar, social reformer and author. He had founded the Deccan Educational Society.

questions.Question: Who was the other Congress leader who joined with Motilal Nehru to start the Swaraj Party in 1923?
questions.solution: Solution:		In December 1922, Chittaranjan Das, Narasimha Chintaman Kelkar and Motilal Nehru formed the Congress-Khilafat Swarajaya Party with Das as the president and Nehru as one of the secretaries.

questions.Question: Sardar Patel brought all the Indian States into the Country's unity
questions.optionD: With the help of the English
questions.solution: Solution:		"Sardar Patel is the symbol of India's unity. He had brought the country's 562 principalities under the fold of the union and had achieved this task within a very short span of 70 days through a bloodless revolution".

questions.Question: The formation of the Self Employed Women's Association (SEWA) at the initiative of __________ in 1972
questions.solution: Solution:		SEWA is a trade union registered in 1972. It is an organisation of poor, self-employed women workers. These are women who earn a living through their own labour or small businesses. They do not obtain regular salaried employment with welfare benefits like workers in the organised sector.

questions.Question: Name the 'Political Guru' of Mahatma Gandhi
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Krishna Gokhle was the "Political Guru" of Mahatma Gandhi. Gandhi Ji wrote a book "Gokhle : My Political Guru"

questions.Question: Who among the following visited Gandhiji in South Africa?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Krishna Gokhale met Gandhiji in South Africa. He was the political guru of Mahatma Gandhi.

questions.Question: The Ganapati festival was started in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1893, the Indian freedom fighter Lokmanya Tilak praised the celebration of sarvajanik Ganesha utsav in his newspaper, Kesari, and dedicated his efforts to launch the annual domestic festival into a large, well-organised public event.

questions.Question: Who scripted Gandhiji's favorite song 'Vaishnav Jan to __________ '?
questions.solution: Solution:		Narsi Mehta composed the song (Vaishnav Jan to). He was also known as pillar of Gujarati literature.

questions.Question: A Royal Commission on the Public Service was appointed in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Islington Commission, 1912 a Royal Commission formed to recommend reforms in the Public Service of British India with Lord Islington as its chairman.

questions.Question: Which of the following was not one of the cardinal principles of Mahatma Gandhi doctrine of Satyagraha?
questions.solution: Solution:		For Gandhi, satyagraha went far beyond mere "passive resistance" and became strength in practising non-violent methods. In his words: Truth (satya) implies love, and firmness (agraha) engenders and therefore serves as a synonym for force. Abstinence was not one of the cardinal principles of Mahatma Gandhi doctrine of Satyahraha.

questions.Question: The only AICC session Gandhiji presided was held at
questions.solution: Solution:		The only AICC session Gandhi ji presided was the Belagam session of 1924. The Belagam session is known for the readmittance of the swarajist into the Congress.

questions.Question: To which personality Mahatma Gandhi gave the title "Deen Bandhu"?
questions.solution: Solution:		To CF Andrews Mahatma Gandhi gave the title "Deen Bandhu".

questions.Question: Who had formulated and perfected the use of the subsidiary alliance system?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Subsidiary Alliance System was “Non-Intervention Policy” used by Lord Wellesley who was the Governor-General (1798-1805) to establish British Empire in India. According to this system, every ruler in India had to accept to pay a subsidy to the British for the maintenance of British army.

questions.Question: Which of the following writers did not have a profound influence on the thinking of Mahatma Gandhi?
questions.solution: Solution:		Writer Marx did not have a profound influence on the thinking of Mahatma Gandhi.

questions.Question: The word Pakistan was coined by
questions.solution: Solution:		The name of the country was coined in 1933 as Pakistan by Choudhry Rahmat Ali, a Pakistan Movement activist, who published it in his pamphlet Now or Never, using it as an acronym ("thirty million Muslim brethren who live in PAKISTAN") referring to the names of the five northern regions of British India.

questions.Question: In which year was the partition of Bengal scrapped?
questions.solution: Solution:		The decision to effect the Partition of Bengal was announced in July 1905 by the Viceroy of India, Lord Curzon. The partition took effect in October 1905 and separated the largely Muslim eastern areas from the largely Hindu western areas. Indians were outraged at what they recognised as a "divide and rule" policy, where the colonisers turned the native population against itself in order to rule, even though Curzon stressed it would produce administrative efficiency. The partition animated the Hindus and led the Muslims to form their own national organization. Bengal was reunited in 1911.

questions.Question: In which city of South Africa was Gandhi beaten up and thrown off the pavement by the white people?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhi arrived in Durban, Natal in 1893 to serve as legal council to a merchant Dada Abdullah, he asked him to under take a rail trip, where Gandhi was seated in first-Class compartment. A white person who entered the compartment hastened to summon the white railway officials and ordered Gandhi to remove himself, but herefused to comply with the order then a white police officer pushed him out of the train.

questions.Question: Who said that "My ultimate aim is to wipe every tear from every eye"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jawahar Lal Nehru said that "My ultimate aim is to wipe every tear from every eye".

questions.Question: Advaita Deepika is the work of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Advaita Deepika is the work of Sree Narayana Guru.

questions.Question: The author of 'A Nation in the Making' was
questions.solution: Solution:		SN Banerjee defeat at the polls in 1923 brought his political career to a close and he went on to write the widely acclaimed A Nation in Making, published in 1925.

questions.Question: Under pressure from his family, Nanu married__________, the daughter of a traditional village doctor
questions.solution: Solution:		Under pressure from his family, Nanu married Kaliamma, the daughter of a traditional village doctor. The marriage was a simple affair with the groom's sisters themselves investing the bride with the 'Thaali' (wedding knot) on his behalf. The bride remained with her parents, since Nanu asan became a wanderer not long after.

questions.Question: Sindhia's troops were defeated by General Wellesley at
questions.solution: Solution:		The battle of Assaye, fought on September 23, 1803 between the Maratha and British armies, is largely forgotten in India. Yet it remains an amazing story of gallantry and skill on both sides.
