Assaye was a hard-won victory for the British, one that challenges common assumptions about how Europeans conquered the subcontinent.

questions.Question: Which town/city in India has got a tower (minar) named after Muhammad Ali Jinnah?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jinnah tower is a landmark monument in the city of Guntur in Andhra Pradesh. It is a Symbol of Peace and harmony.

questions.Question: Provision was made by the Charter Act of 1813 for the establishment of a Church at __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Charter Act of 1813 marked an important stage in the later history of East India company of India. This inclided provisions for the creation of an anglican church establishment in Calcutta, the opening-up of the country to Christian missionaries, and the encouragement of the Indian education.

questions.Question: In which state was the first non-Congress Government set up in independent India?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1957, CPI defeated congress in legislative assembly elections in the southern state of Kerala and formed the first non-congress government in independent India.

questions.Question: Who was the first Indian ruler to apply the western methods to his administration?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tipu Sultan was the first indian ruler to apply the western methods to his administration. Sultan Fateh Ali Sahab Tipu, also known as the Tipu Sahib, was a ruler of the Kingdom of Mysore.

questions.Question: In 1946, the Interim Government was formed under
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1946, the Interim Government was formed under Jawaharlal Nehru.

questions.Question: Purna Swaraj was declared as the goal of the Congress in the Congress session held at Lahore under the Presidentship of
questions.solution: Solution:		Purna Swaraj was declared as the goal of the Congress in the Congress session held at Lahore under the Presidentship of Jawaharlal Nehru.

questions.Question: Who was the author of 'Esoteric Christianity'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Annie Besant was the author of 'Esoteric Christianity'.

questions.Question: The Cabinet Mission Plan ruled out the possibility of the formation of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Cabinet Mission Plan ruled out the possibility of the formation of Pakistan.

questions.Question: The Home Rule League was formed during the
questions.optionC: Struggle following the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre
questions.solution: Solution:		Home Rule League, either of two short-lived organizations of the same name in India established in April and September 1916, respectively, by Indian nationalist Bal Gangadhar Tilak and British social reformer and Indian independence leader Annie Besant during first world war.

questions.Question: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel was the leader of__________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Bardoli Satyagraha of 1928, in the state of Gujarat, India during the period of the British Raj, was a major episode of civil disobedience and revolt in the Indian Independence Movement. The movement was eventually led by Vallabhbhai Patel, and its success gave rise to Patel becoming one of the main leaders of the independence movement.

questions.Question: The immortal national Song 'Vande Mataram' has been written by
questions.solution: Solution:		National Song "Vande Mataram" is a part of Anand Math written by Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyaya.

questions.Question: Before the passing of the Act of 1773, each of the three English Settlement in India was governed by
questions.solution: Solution:		Before the passing of the Act of 1773, each of the three English Settlement in India was governed by President.

questions.Question: Which of the following was the most important feature of the Montague-Chelmsford reforms?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dyarchy, also spelled diarchy, system of double government introduced by the Government of India Act (1919) for the provinces of British India. Dyarchy was introduced as a constitutional reform by Edwin Samuel Montagu (secretary of state for India, 1917–22) and Lord Chelmsford (viceroy of India, 1916–21).

questions.Question: Azad Hind Fauz or the Indian National Army (INA) was founded by
questions.solution: Solution:		Kuala Lumpur fell on 11 January 1942 with 3,500 Indian prisoners of war, and Singapore on 15 February with 85,000 British troops, of whom 45,000 were Indians. Mohan Singh asked for volunteers who would form the Azad Hind Fauj (Free India Army) to fight for Indian independence from the British rule.

questions.Question: Madam Bhikaji Cama unfolded the National Flag of India in 1907 at
questions.optionC: Vande Mataram Office at San Francisco
questions.solution: Solution:		“Behold, the flag of independent India is born! It has been made sacred by the blood of young Indians who sacrificed their lives in its honour. In the name of this flag, I appeal to lovers of freedom all over the world to support this struggle.” – Bhikaji Cama. Madam Bhikaji Cama unfolded the National Flag of India in 1907 at International Socialist Congress Stuttgart.

questions.Question: A focal point of all revolutionary activities in London was
questions.solution: Solution:		A focal point of all revolutionary activities in London was India House.

questions.Question: The last of the Charter Act concerning India was the Act of
questions.solution: Solution:		Charter Act of 1853 was the last charter act passed for East India Company. It was passed on expiry of charter act of 1833. The charter was renewed but no substantial changes were made.

questions.Question: Which day was declared as the 'Direct Action Day' by the Muslim League?
questions.solution: Solution:		On 16th August,1946 Direct Action Day was declared, the day also known as the Great Calcutta killings. Itwas a day of widespread riots and manslaughter between Hindus and Muslims in Bengal.

questions.Question: The social reformer of Maharashtra who became famous by his pen name lokhitwadi was
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Hari Deshmukh (18 February 1823 – 9 October 1892) was an Indian activist, thinker, social reformer and writer from Maharashtra. His original surname was Shidhaye. Because of 'Vatan' (right of Tax collection) that the family had received,the family was later called Deshmukh. Deshmukh is regarded as an important figure of the Social Reform Movement in Maharashtra.

questions.Question: The Tomar Rajputs, were defeated in the middle of the twelfth century by the Chauhans of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Tomar Rajputs, were defeated in the middle of the twelfth century by the Chauhans of Ajmer.

questions.Question: The State, from among the following, which was not annexed by the 'doctrine of lapse' is
questions.solution: Solution:		The company took over the princely states of Satara (1848), Jaitpur and Sambalpur (1849), Nagpur and Jhansi (1854), Tore and Arcot (1855) and Udaipur (Chhattisgarh) under the terms of the doctrine of lapse. Oudh (1856) is widely believed to have under the Doctrine of Lapse. The State which was not annexed by the 'doctrine of lapse' is Gwalior.

questions.Question: The Headquarters of the Ramakrishna Math and Mission established by Vivekananda in 1898 are at
questions.solution: Solution:		Ramakrishna Mission (RKM) is a Hindu religious and spiritual organisation which forms the the core of a worldwide spiritual movement known as the Ramakrishna Movement or the Vedanta Movement. The headquarters of Ramakrishna Math at Belur ( popularly known as Belur Math). It was at Belur Math that Swami Vivekananda (1863-1902), the foremost disciple of Sri Ramakrishna (1836-1886), lived the last years of his brief life.

questions.Question: After leaving the Congress, Subhash Chandra Bose formed, in 1939, his own party, named
questions.solution: Solution:		Subhash Chandra Bose was an Indian Nationalist, he had been a leader of Indian National Congress in the late 1920's and 1930's and leaving from Congress leadership positions in 1939 due to dispute with Gandhiji and formed a new party named Forward bloc.

questions.Question: The Diwani Adalat was presided over by
questions.solution: Solution:		In the Diwani Adalat, the Collector was to preside assisted by this 'native dewan'.

questions.Question: An emigre (a person or thing who/which has emigrated) communist journal brought out by M N Roy was
questions.solution: Solution:		An emigre (a person or thing who/which has emigrated) communist journal brought out by M N Roy was Vanguard.

questions.Question: Who among the following had attended all the three Round Table Conferences in London?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ambedkar and Tej Bahadur Sapru took part in all the three round table conferences.

questions.Question: Which of the following incident ended the historic fast of Gandhi?
questions.solution: Solution:		Poona Pact was an agreement between Dr. Bhimrao Ambedkar and Mahatma Gandhi signed on September 24, 1932. This pact ended Gandhi's fast unto death.

questions.Question: Who started the journal 'The Commonweal'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Annie Besant is responsible for introducing two journals: The Commonweal and New India, while the former was a weekly that looked into issues related to national reform, the latter was a daily newspaper that went on for fifteen years. It was a powerful newspaper that spread the idea of revolutionizing journalism and encouraged Home Rule Movement.

questions.Question: The partition of Bengal had to be annulled in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The partition of Bengal had to be annulled in 1911.

questions.Question: The Simon Commission was formed to review
questions.optionB: Fitness of India for further reforms
questions.solution: Solution:		The Simon Commission was formed to review the working of Government of India Act, 1919 and suggest further constitutional and administrative reforms in the British colonial rule of India.

questions.Question: Rowlatt after whom Rowlatt Act was named was a
questions.solution: Solution:		Passed on the recommendations of the Rowlatt Committee and named after its president, British judge Sir Sidney Rowlatt, this act effectively authorized the government to imprison any person suspected of terrorism living in British India for up to two years without a trial, and gave the imperial authorities power to deal with all revolutionary activities.

questions.Question: Swami Vivekananda was born in an affluent family in __________ on 12 January 1863
questions.solution: Solution:		Swamiji was born on 12 January 1863 in Calcutta (now Kolkata). Swami Vivekananda died on 4 July, 1902 in Kolkata.

questions.Question: The Rowlatt Act was passed in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The Anarchical and Revolutionary Crimes Act of 1919 , popularly known as the Rowlatt Act or Black Act, was a legislative act passed by the Imperial Legislative Council in Delhi on 10 March 1919, indefinitely extending the emergency measures of preventive indefinite detention, incarceration without trial and judicial review enacted in the Defence of India Act 1915 during the First World War.

questions.Question: India attained 'Dominion  status' on
questions.solution: Solution:		India attained "Dominion Status" on 15 Aug 1947 by the Mountbattan plan, two dominian state came in existence first Pakistan (14th August 1947) and second India (15th August 1947).

questions.Question: Who was the first Indian Governor General of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		C Raja Gopalachari became the only and the first Indian Governor General of Independent India.

questions.Question: When did the Cripps Mission, which had practically repeated the August Offer 1940 visit India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Cripps Mission was a failed attempt in late March 1942 by the British government to secure full Indian cooperation and support for their efforts in World War II.

questions.Question: The sole representative of the Congress in the Second Round Table Conference was
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahatma Gandhi was the sole representative of the Indian National Congress at the Second Round Table Conference held at London in 1931.

questions.Question: In 1908, Bal Gangadhar Tilak was imprisoned for six years and sent to
questions.solution: Solution:		Tilak was sentenced to a jail term from 1908 to 1914 in Mandalay in Burma. While in prison, Tilak read and wrote extensively and developed his ideas on the Indian nationalism movement.

questions.Question: The Province of Bengal was partitioned into two parts in 1905 by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Partition was made on 16 oct,1905 by Lord Curzon, the first Partition in Bengal was implemented as an administrative making governing the two provinces, West and East Bengal (Bengali- Hindu or Bengali- Muslim).

questions.Question: In the . . . . . . Provinces were allowed to form groups with common executives and legislatures
questions.solution: Solution:		The Cabinet Mission of 1946 came to India aimed to discuss the transfer of power from the British government to the Indian leadership, with the aim of preserving India's unity and granting it independence.

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi got his inspiration for Civil Disobedience from
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhiji got his inspiration of 'Civil Disobedience' after reading the Thoureau's essay on duty of Civil disobedience movement.

questions.Question: Which of the following was the 'Newspaper' of Annie Besant?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1914, Annie Besant purchased an Indian newspaper, the Madras Standard, and on August 1 of that year changed its name to New India.

questions.Question: In the Battle of Buxar the English army was commanded by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Buxar was fought on 22 October 1764, during the Bengal War was between the forces under the command of the British East India Company, led by Hector Munro, and the combined armies of Mir Qasim, Nawab of Bengal till 1763; the Nawab of Awadh; and the Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II.

questions.Question: The Sikhs were defeated by the English at __________ in 1856
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Sobraon was fought on 10 February 1846, between the forces of the East India Company and the Sikh Khalsa Army, the army of the Sikh Empire of the Punjab. The Sikhs were completely defeated, making this the decisive battle of the First Anglo-Sikh War.

questions.Question: Which of the following was not included in the early three English Settlements in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Punjab was not included in the early three English Settlements in India.

questions.Question: Of the following who did not oppose the Non-cooperation resolution?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Non-cooperation movement was withdrawn because of the Chauri Chaura incident. Although he had stopped the national revolt single-handedly, on 10 March 1922, Gandhi was arrested. Motilal Nehru and Chittaranjan Das formed the Swaraj Party, rejecting Gandhi's leadership.

questions.Question: Who among the following was the first to sign the 'Instruments of Accession'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Instrument of Accession was a legal document first introduced by Government of India Act, 1935. It was used in and after 1947 to enable each of rulers of princely states under British parliamentary to join one of the new dominions of India or Pakistan. Dewan of Travancore was the first to sign 'Instrument of Accession'.

questions.Question: Who among the following leader headed the interim Government of 1946?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Viceroy's Executive Council became the executive branch of the interim government. Originally headed by the Viceroy of India, it was transformed into a council of ministers, with the powers of a prime minister bestowed on the vice-president of the Council, a position held by the Congress leader Jawaharlal Nehru.

questions.Question: The United Nations declared __________ as the International Year of Women
questions.solution: Solution:		International Women's Year (IWY) was the name given to 1975 by the United Nations. Since that year March 8 has been celebrated as International Women's Day, and the United Nations Decade for Women, from 1976 to 1985, was also established.

questions.Question: Gandhiji considered Khadi as a symbol of
questions.solution: Solution:		Khadi was used a symbol of economic independence and promoted in Vijayawada session of INC (1921).

questions.Question: Which of the following institutions was not founded by Gandhi?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ramakrishna Mission (RKM) is a Hindu religious and spiritual organisation which forms the core of a worldwide spiritual movement known as the Ramakrishna Movement or the Vedanta Movement. The mission is named after and inspired by the Indian saint Ramakrishna Paramahamsa and founded by Ramakrishna's chief disciple Swami Vivekananda on 1 May 1897.

questions.Question: Indian Association formed in __________ was one of the pioneer political associations with an all India outlook
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian Association formed in 1876 was one of the pioneer political associations with an all India outlook. During the second half of the 19th century India witnessed marked changes in social and economic life.

questions.Question: On April 12, 1944 Subhash Chandra Bose hoisted the INA Flag in a town. In which State/Union Territory is that town now?
questions.solution: Solution:		Moirang is a city and Municipal council in the state of Manipur where Subhash Chandra Bose hoisted the INA flag. During world war-II Moirang was the head quarters of Azad Hind Fauz, colonel Shaukat Malik of INA hoisted the Tri-colour for the first on Indian soil on 14 April 1944 in Moirang with the help of Manipuris.

questions.Question: China invaded Indian frontiers in the year __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Exactly 55 years ago, a full-fledge war broke out between India and China. The Sino-India war began on October 20, 1962 when the People's Liberation Army of China invaded Ladakh and Arunachal Pradesh (then known as the North East Frontier Agency) in a synchronised move.

questions.Question: Guru died on 20 September, __________
questions.solution: Solution:		On 20 September 1928, Sree Narayana Guru, great social and religious reformer from Kerala died at Sivagiri, Kerala.

questions.Question: In 1913 . . . . . founded the Advaita Ashram at Aluva.
questions.solution: Solution:		Alwaye Advaita Ashram - the ashrams in Alwaye, founded in 1913 by Sree Narayana Guru in order to reach, propagate as well as live the Advaita philosophy.

questions.Question: Which of the following Congress leader rejected the 'August Offer' of 1940?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Viceroy of India, Lord Linlithgow, issued a statement from Simla on 8 August 1940 in the response of when congress formally ask England to affirm its adherence to the goal of Independence for India which is popularly known August Offer.

questions.Question: The Mohammadan Anglo-Oriental College at Aligarh was founded by
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Sayyid Ahmad Khan founded Mohammadan Anglo oriental college in 1875 and it was renamed as Aligarh muslim university in 1920. He also established 'Scientific Society" and published magazine 'RAJBHART MUSALMAN'.

questions.Question: When was first telegraph line started in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The British India opened the first telegraph line and office in October 1851, between Calcutta and Diamond Harbour.

questions.Question: Who is generally acknowledged as the pioneer of local self-government in modern India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Ripon, the pioneer of local self-government, a resolution of 1882 set off the institution of localself-government in India. Ripon also known as the father of Local self government in India and real liberal of goldstein era. "The Duty of Age" was written by him.

questions.Question: Daiva Dasakam is a Malayalam work of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Daiva Dasakam is a Malayalam work of Sree Narayana Guru.

questions.Question: Who gave the title or "Mahamana" to Madan Mohan Malviya?
questions.solution: Solution:		Madan Mohan Malviya was the most prominent leader of INC. He was most remembered as the founder of Banaras Hindu University (B.H.U) at Varansi in 1916. Rabindra Nath Tagore titled him "Mahamana" and he awarded by Bharat Ratna in 2015 (Posthumous).

questions.Question: Calcutta medical college in__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Medical College and Hospital, Kolkata, commonly referred to as Calcutta Medical College, formerly Medical College, Bengal, is a medical school and hospital in the city of Kolkata in the state of West Bengal, India. It was established in 1835 by William Bentinck.

questions.Question: The first Shivaji festival was held at Raigarh in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Shivaji festival was held at Raigarh in 1895.

questions.Question: Swami Vivekananda attended the World's Parliament of Religions held in Chicago in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Swami Vivekananda represented India and Hinduism at the Parliament of the World's Religions (1893). This was the first World's Parliament of Religions and it was held from 11 to 27 September 1893. Delegates from all over the world joined this Parliament.

questions.Question: Jawaharlal Nehru had helped to start the newspaper
questions.solution: Solution:		National Herald is an Indian newspaper published by The Associated Journals Ltd. It was founded by India's first prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru in 1938 as a tool to win independence.

questions.Question: The Mayo College was started at
questions.solution: Solution:		Mayo College is a boys' residential public school in Ajmer, Rajasthan, India. It was founded in 1875 by Richard Bourke, 6th Earl of Mayo who was also the Viceroy of India from 1869 to 1872.

questions.Question: The INA was largely composed of
questions.optionC: Indian Prisoners of war under the Japanese
questions.optionD: Deserters from the British Indian Army
questions.solution: Solution:		During early 1942 the Japanese conducted a campaign to persuade Indian prisoners of war in Hongkong, Shanghai, and Singapore that they should fight along with the Japanese for the “liberation” of India. In June 1942 the Japanese sponsored a conference in Bangkok at which the INA was formally launched, originally headed by Capt. Mohan Singh, and by November 1942 the Japanese claimed that the strength of the force was 16,000 troops.

questions.Question: 'The Times of India' which celebrated its 150th anniversary in 1988, was first published in 1838 as
questions.solution: Solution:		The Times of India issued its first edition on 3 November 1838 as The Bombay Times and Journal of Commerce.

questions.Question: As per the Act of 1919 which of the following was not a transferred subject?
questions.solution: Solution:		As per the Act of 1919 land Revenue was not a transferred subject.

questions.Question: Who said that 'the real seat of taste is not the tongue but the mind.'?
questions.solution: Solution:		It is the statement from the autobiography of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi which contains the life incidents of Gandhi ji from his childhood. It was published weekly in his other journal , Navjeevan.

questions.Question: When Ramakrishna Mission was founded?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vivekananda went on lecture tours and held private discourses on Hinduism and spirituality. He also founded the first Vedanta Society in the United States at New York. He returned to India in 1897 and founded the Ramakrishna Mission on 1 May 1897.

questions.Question: Who wrote the song 'Sare Jahan Se Accha Hindoostan Hamara'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Poet and Politician Mohammad Iqbal wrote the song "Sare Jahan Se Accha Hindoostan Hamara". Iqbal was also known as the founder of Two Nation Theory.

questions.Question: Which of the following newspaper was started by Annie Besant?
questions.solution: Solution:		New India was an early 20th century daily newspaper published in India by Annie Besant. New India was a newspaper founded as a means to spread news related to the Indian freedom struggle.

questions.Question: Who among the following started Bengali weekly newspaper 'Sambad Kaumudi' in year 1821?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sambad Kaumudi was a Bengali weekly newspaper published from Kolkata in the first half of the 19th century by Ram Mohan Roy. It was a noted pro-Reformist publication that actively campaigned for the abolition of the Sati Pratha.

questions.Question: With whom was the seven-year rule of' "missions, omissions and commissions' associated?
questions.solution: Solution:		The seven-year rule of 'Mission, Omissions and Commission' was associated with Lord Curzon.

questions.Question: Narayana Guru started a Sanskrit school in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1904 he decided to settle down in a place to continue his spiritual practices. He chose Sivagiri at Varkala, twenty miles north of Thiruvananthapuram. He started a Sanskrit school in Varkala and poor boys and orphans were given free education regardless of their caste.

questions.Question: Sarvodaya stands for
questions.solution: Solution:		Sarvodaya (Which means universal upliftment or progress of all), used by Mahatma Gandhi in 1908 for the title of his translation of John Ruskin's "Unto The Last".

questions.Question: The most famous woman disciple of Vivekananda was
questions.solution: Solution:		Sister Nivedita born Margaret Elizabeth Noble; 28 October 1867 – 13 October 1911) was an Irish teacher, author, social activist, school founder and disciple of Swami Vivekananda.

questions.Question: After the defeat at Plassey, Siraj-ud-daullah was assassinated __________and was made the nawab
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Plassey was fought of 23 June, 1757Company's Army was lead by the Robert Clive. Nawab was defeated by The East India Company and Mir Jafar was made the Nawab.

questions.Question: Which of these battles proved decisive in the Anglo French rivalry in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Wandiwash was a decisive battle in India during the Seven Years' War. Having made substantial gains in Bengal and Hyderabad, the British, after collecting huge amount of revenue, were fully equipped to face the French in Wandiwash, whom they defeated.

questions.Question: The capital of Tipu Sultan, where he died while fighting the Fourth Anglo-Mysore war in 1799, was
questions.solution: Solution:		The capital of Tipu Sultan, where he died while fighting the Fourth Anglo-Mysore war in 1799, was Seringapatam.

questions.Question: In which year was the Indian Home Rule Society founded?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian Home Rule Society (IHRS) was an Indian organisation founded in London in 1905 that sought to promote the cause of self-rule in British India.

questions.Question: The Cripps Offer was regarded as a 'post dated cheque' by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Congress stopped talks with Cripps and, guided by Gandhi, the national leadership demanded immediate self-government in return for war support. Gandhi said that Cripps' offer of Dominion Status after the war was a "post-dated cheque drawn on a failing bank".

questions.Question: Who termed Cripps proposals as  " a post dated cheque in a crashing bank"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhi ji termed Cripp's proposals as " a post dated Cheque in a crashing Bank".

questions.Question: In . . . . . Derozio founded with his students the 'Academic Association' which organised debates on various subjects
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1828 Derozio founded with his students the 'Academic Association', which organised debates on various subjects. Derozio's students read the writings of Voltaire, Hume, Locke, Tom Paine and others and quoted them freely in their debates.

questions.Question: The Cabinet Mission which arrived Delhi in 1946 was headed by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Cabinet Mission which arrived Delhi in 1946 was headed by Lord Pethrick Lawrence.

questions.Question: The Government of India Act of 1935 consists of __________ sections and 10 schedules
questions.solution: Solution:		The 1935 Act was the second installment of constitutional reforms passed by British Parliament for implementing the ideal of responsible government in India. The Act of 1935 was quite a lengthy and detailed document. It consisted of 321 sections and 10 schedules.

questions.Question: Indian Universities Act, 1904 was passed during the governorship of
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the governorship of Lord Curzon Indian Universities act was passed in 1904. The provision of this act was that the governing bodies of the universities were reconstituted and the size of sevates was reduced.

questions.Question: The doctrine of lapse had been put to much use by
questions.solution: Solution:		Oudh (1856) is widely believed to have under the Doctrine of Lapse. However it was annexed by Lord Dalhousie under the pretext of mis-governance. The princely state of Kittur was taken over by the East India Company in 1824 by imposing a 'doctrine of lapse'.

questions.Question: Who is the first female governor of Independent India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sarojini Naidu became the first female governor of Independent India, she is known as Nightangle of India.

questions.Question: In __________, the First National Trade union organization (The All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC)) was established
questions.solution: Solution:		All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) was founded in 1920 with Lala Lajpat Rai as its first president. Upto 1945 Congressmen, Socialists, Communists worked in the AITUC which was the central trade union organisation of workers of India.

questions.Question: Queen Victoria became the Empress of India according to the Act of
questions.solution: Solution:		Disraeli also pushed the Royal Titles Act 1876 through Parliament, so that Victoria took the title "Empress of India" from 1 May 1876.

questions.Question: Tashkent Agreement was signed between India and Pakistan in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The Tashkent Declaration was a peace agreement between India and Pakistan signed on 10 January 1966 that resolved the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965.

questions.Question: After the ruin of India's trade, industries and handicrafts, the burden of taxation in India had to be mainly borne by
questions.solution: Solution:		After the ruin of India's trade, Industries and handicrafts, the burden of taxation in India had to be mainly borne by peasantry.

questions.Question: The National Anthem was first sung in year 1911 at the Annual session of the India National Congress held at
questions.solution: Solution:		National anthem (Jana-gana-mana song) was originally composed by the Rabindranath Tagore in Bengali. It was first sung in Calcutta in the meeting of Indian National Congress on 27th of December in 1911.

questions.Question: The Sepoy Mutiny broke out on May 10, 1857 at __________
questions.solution: Solution:		It was on May 10, 1857 that the Indian soldiers at the Meerut cantonment in modern UP revolted against the British.

questions.Question: As per 'August Offer 1940' the Constitution of India would be drawn by
questions.solution: Solution:		The August Offer was a proposal made by the British government in 1940 promising the expansion of the Executive Council of the Viceroy of India to include more Indians, the establishment of an advisory war council, giving full weight to minority opinion, and the recognition of Indians' right to frame their own constitution (after the end of the war).

questions.Question: The first Carnatic War in India was an extension of the Anglo-French War in
questions.solution: Solution:		First Carnatic War was an extension of the Anglo-French War in Europe which was caused by the Austrian War of Succession.

questions.Question: In 1920 under her leadership the__________, the Ahmedabad textile mill workers union was established
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1920 under her leadership the Majoor Mahajan, the Ahmedabad textile mill workers union was established.

questions.Question: Which Brigadier was associated with Jallianwala Bagh tragedy?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Jallianwala Bagh massacre, also known as the Amritsar massacre, took place on 13 April 1919 when troops of the British Indian Army under the command of Colonel Reginald Dyer fired rifles into a crowd of Punjabis, who had gathered in Jallianwala Bagh, Amritsar, Punjab.

questions.Question: In 1942, Europe had witnessed a great war between
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1942, Europe had witnessed a great war between Germany and Russia.

questions.Question: Jyotirao's family belonged to __________ caste
questions.solution: Solution:		Jyotirao's family belonged to 'mali' caste and their original title was 'Gorhay'. Mali's were considered as an inferior caste by the Brahmins and were shunned socially. Jyotirao's father and uncles served as florists, so the family came to be known as 'Phule'.

questions.Question: The Editor of 'Young India' and 'Harijan' was
questions.solution: Solution:		Young India was a weekly paper or journal in English published by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi from 1919 to 1931. Gandhi wrote various quotations in this journal that inspired many.

questions.Question: Which Sultan of Delhi was the first to charge GHARI or HOUSE TAX?
questions.solution: Solution:		Alauddin Khalji was the First Sultan of Delhi to charge Ghari or House Tax.

questions.Question: In which year was the quit India movement launched?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Quit India Movement, or the August Movement, was a movement launched at the Bombay session of the All-India Congress Committee by Gandhiji on 8 August 1942, during World War II, demanding an end to British Rule of India.

questions.Question: Which Viceroy of India had largest tenure during British rule:
questions.solution: Solution:		Governor General and Viceroy of India (1936-1944) Lord Linlithgow was Viceroy of India from 1936 to 1944 and this eight years period was longest reign as Viceroy of India.

questions.Question: Who was governor general when the 1857 revolt broke out?
questions.solution: Solution:		Charles Canning, the Governor-General of India during the rebellion when the 1857 revolt broke out.

questions.Question: The title VIKRAMADITYA was assumed by:
questions.solution: Solution:		"Vikramaditya" was a common title adopted by several Indian kings, and the Vikramaditya legends may be embellished accounts of different kings (particularly Chandragupta II).

questions.Question: Sisir Kumar Ghosh, Shambhuchand Mukherhee, Kali Mohan Das and Jogesh Chandra Dutt were editors of:
questions.solution: Solution:		Sisir Kumar Ghosh, Shambhuchand Mukherjee, Kali Mohan Das and Jogesh Chandra Dutt were editors of – Amrit Bazar Patrika.

questions.Question: The Cabinet mission arrived in Delhi on:
questions.solution: Solution:		The Cabinet Mission of 1946 came to India aimed to discuss the transfer of power from the British government to the Indian leadership, with the aim of preserving India's unity and granting it independence. He came of March 24, 1946.

questions.Question: The British government declared Communist Party of India illegal in:
questions.solution: Solution:		The British government, did not favour the activities of the Communists in India and on 23rd July, 1934 it imposed a ban on the functioning of the party.

questions.Question: The pioneer of Indian communism was
questions.solution: Solution:		Manabendra Nath Roy (21 March 1887 – 26 January 1954), born Narendra Nath Bhattacharya, was an Indian revolutionary, radical activist and political theorist, as well as a noted philosopher in the 20th century. Roy was a founder of the Mexican Communist Party and the Communist Party of India. He was the pioneer of Indian communism.

questions.Question: Whom did B.G.Tilak call the "Diamond of India"?
questions.solution: Solution:		B.G.Tilak called the "Diamond of India" to Gopal Krishna Gokhale.

questions.Question: The Battle of Plassey was fought in
questions.solution: Solution:		On 23 June 1757, the Battle of Plassey was fought between the forces of Siraj Ud Daulah, and his French support troops and the troops of the British East India Company, led by Robert Clive. This event was a part of the Seven Years War.

questions.Question: The territory of Porus who offered strong resistance to Alexander was situated between the rivers of
questions.solution: Solution:		The territory of Porus who offered strong resistance to Alexander was situated between the rivers of Jhelum and Chenab.

questions.Question: Under Akbar, the Mir Bakshi was required to look after
questions.solution: Solution:		The head of the military was called the Mir Bakshi, appointed from among the leading nobles of the court. The Mir Bakshi was in charge of intelligence gathering, and also made recommendations to the emperor for military appointments and promotions.

questions.Question: In 1821 Raja Ram Mohan Roy started the Bengal quarterly:
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1821 Raja Ram Mohan Roy started the Bengal quarterly Samvad Kaumudi.

questions.Question: Who established East India Association in London 1866?
questions.solution: Solution:		The East India Association was founded by Dadabhai Naoroji in 1866, in collaboration with Indians and retired British officials in London.

questions.Question: In 1893 Mahatma Gandhi went to South Africa in connection with the trial of a merchant:
questions.solution: Solution:		It was a long journey from India to South Africa. Gandhi reached the port of Natal towards the end of May, 1893. The first thing he noticed was that the Indians there were treated with little respect. Within a week of his arrival in Durban, he visited the court with Abdulla Seth of Dada, Abdulla &Co.

questions.Question: Which foreigner arrived in India on Nov. 16, 1893?
questions.solution: Solution:		Annie Besant arrived in India on Nov. 16, 1893.

questions.Question: Which movement was started by Mahatma Gandhi on March 12, 1930?
questions.solution: Solution:		On March 12, 1930, Indian independence leader Mohandas Gandhi begins a defiant march to the sea in protest of the British monopoly on salt, his boldest act of civil disobedience yet against British rule in India.

questions.Question: The term samanta, meaning a feudatory from the sixth century AD, originally meant  a
questions.solution: Solution:		The term samanta, meaning a feudatory from the sixth century AD, originally meant a Neighbour.

questions.Question: Tulsidas, the author of Ramcharitmanas, was a contemporary of which of the following rulers?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tulsidas wrote several popular works in Sanskrit and Awadhi; he is best known as the author of the epic Ramcharitmanas, a retelling of the Sanskrit Ramayana based on Rama's life in the vernacular Awadhi dialect of Hindi. He was a contemporary of Akbar.

questions.Question: To meet the educational needs of the people, the Madarasa-I-Nasiri was built in the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		To meet the educational needs of the people, the Madarasa-I Nasiri was built in the reign of Iltutmish.

questions.Question: Dr. B. R. Ambedkar organized a Bhishkrit Hitkari Sabha, (The Depressed Classes Institute) in :
questions.solution: Solution:		Dr. B. R. Ambedkar organized a Bhishkrit Hitkari Sabha, (The Depressed Classes Institute) in 1924.

questions.Question: The Gandhi-Irwin Pact was signed on :
questions.solution: Solution:		The Gandhi-Irwin Pact was a political agreement signed by Mahatma Gandhi and Lord Irwin, the then Viceroy of India, on 5 March 1931 before the second Round Table Conference in London.

questions.Question: Who said “Every blow on my body will prove a nail in the coffin of the British Empire”?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lala Lajpat Rai said “Every blow on my body will prove a nail in the coffin of the British Empire”.

questions.Question: In March 1923 Chittranjan Das along with Motilal Nehru formed :
questions.solution: Solution:		The Swaraj Party as established as the Congress-Khilafat Swaraj Party. It was a political party formed in India in January 1923 after the Gaya annual conference in December 1922 of the National Congress, that sought greater self-government and political freedom for the Indian people from the British Raj. It was inspired by the concept of Swaraj. In Hindi and many other languages of India, swaraj means "independence" or "self-rule." The two most important leaders were Chittaranjan Das, who was its president and Motilal Nehru, who was its secretary.

questions.Question: Who said - “patriotism is religion and religion is love for India?”
questions.solution: Solution:		It was uttered by Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay or Bankim Chandra Chatterjee. He was the first to initiate the slogan "Vande Mataram".

questions.Question: The congress policy of prayer and petition ultimately came to an end under the guidance of
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak described the method of three P's – Prayer, petition and protest as political mendicancy.

questions.Question: Universities in the Presidency towns in India were established in
questions.solution: Solution:		Universities in the Presidency towns in India were established in 1857.

questions.Question: The term Nirgrantha is associated with
questions.solution: Solution:		A Nirgrantha is a term that specifically refers to Jains in religious and philosophical works from the Indian religions.

questions.Question: Who founded Anushulin Samiti in 1907 in Dhaka?
questions.optionC: Barindra Ghosh and Bhupendra Nath Dutt
questions.optionD: Jogesh Chandra Dutt E.  Pulin Behari Das
questions.solution: Solution:		Dhaka Anushilan Samiti was a branch of the Anushilan Samiti founded in the city of Dhaka in November 1905. Initially a group of eighty under the leadership of Pulin Behari Das, it "spread like wildfire" throughout the province of East Bengal. More than 500 branches were opened, linked by a "close and detailed organization" to Palin's headquarters at Dhaka. It absorbed smaller groups in the province and soon overshadowed its parent organization in Calcutta. Source :wikipedia.org

questions.Question: Sarojini Naidu was elected Congress President at :
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1925, Naidu presided over the annual session of Indian National Congress at Cawnpore (now Kanpur). In 1929, she presided over East African Indian Congress in South Africa. She was awarded the Kaisar-i-Hind Medal by the British government for her work during the plague epidemic in India.

questions.Question: In 1918 who founded Ahmedabad Textile Labour Association ?
questions.solution: Solution:		In the year 1918 father of the nation Mahatma Gandhi along with Anasuya Sarabhai and Shankerlal Banker founded the Ahmadabad textile labour association.

questions.Question: The term Brahmadeya occurs for the first time in
questions.solution: Solution:		The term Brahmadeya occured the first time in pre-gupta inscriptions.

questions.Question: Under whose leadership was the all India Muslim League set up?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1906, All India Muslim League was set up under the leader ship of Aga Khan, Nawab Salimullab of Dacca and Nawab Mohsin-ul-Mulk. The League supported the partition of Bengal, opposed the Swadeshi Movement, and demanded special safegurds for its community and a separate electorates of Muslims. This led to communal differences between Hindus and Muslims.

questions.Question: Though Ashoka had many sons, the inscriptions mentioned only one who is not mentioned in any other source. He is
questions.solution: Solution:		TIVARAis the only son mentioned in the inscription.

questions.Question: When was Poona Pact between Mahatma Gandhi and Dr. B. R. Ambedkar signed?
questions.solution: Solution:		An agreement between Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar and Mahatma Gandhi was signed 84 years ago on September 24, 1932. The agreement was signed by Pt Madan Mohan Malviya and Dr. B. R. Ambedkar and some Dalit leaders at Yerwada Central Jail in Pune, to break Mahathma Gandhi's fast unto death.

questions.Question: The British Prime Minister Atlee announced the withdrawal of the Britishers in the House of Commons from India on
questions.solution: Solution:		The Prime Minister of Britain Clement Atlee declared on February 20, 1947 in the House of Commons that the British would quit India after transferring power into the responsible hand not later than June 1948.

questions.Question: Who said, “India is for Indians?”
questions.solution: Solution:		Swami Dayanand Saraswati gave the political slogan that India is for Indians. Dayanand said – World is a battlefield where every individual has to work out his salvation by right deeds.

questions.Question: Who said," One Country One God, One Caste, one Mind brothers all of us Without Difference, without Doubt ?"
questions.solution: Solution:		V. D. Savarkar said," One Country One God, One Caste, one Mind brothers all of us Without Difference, without Doubt ".

questions.Question: Who founded Abhinav Bharat ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Abhinav Bharat was named after the Abhinav Bharat Society, an organisation founded by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar in 1904.

questions.Question: Delhi was formally declared the future capital of the British India in :
questions.solution: Solution:		King George V crowned in England in 1911. A durbar was held in Delhi to celebrate this occasion in India and Delhi was declared the capital of imperial India in that durbar. The foundation stone of the city was laid by George V, Emperor of India during the Delhi Durbar of 1911.

questions.Question: The year which is associated with the Gadar movement is:
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1913, Pacific Coast Hindustan Association was founded by Lala Hardayal with Sohan Singh Bhakna as its president, which was called Ghadar Party. The members of this party were the immigrant Sikhs of US and Canada. The first issue of The Ghadar, was published from San Francisco on November 1, 1913.

questions.Question: The Queen Victoria assumed the title of the Empress of India in 1876 by :
questions.solution: Solution:		The Royal Titles Bill was brought before Parliament in 1876. Queen Victoria opened Parliament in person, the first time since the death of Prince Albert, to announce the change in royal title.

questions.Question: From where did the quit India Movement begin?
questions.solution: Solution:		On 8 August 1942 at the All-India Congress Committee session in Bombay, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi launched the 'Quit India' movement. The next day, Gandhi, Nehru and many other leaders of the Indian National Congress were arrested by the British Government.

questions.Question: Abhinav Bharat organized in 1904 was :
questions.optionB: A secret society of revolutionary activists
questions.solution: Solution:		Abhinav Bharat was named after the Abhinav Bharat Society, an organisation founded by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar in 1904. The original organization believed in armed revolution, and was responsible for the assassinations of some officers of the ruling British government before being disbanded in 1952.

questions.Question: The major Muslim organizations which opposed the partition of India were
questions.solution: Solution:		The major Muslim organizations which opposed the partition of India were The Jamiat-Ulema-hind, Khudai Khidmatgar and Majlis-e-Ahrar –Hind.

questions.Question: Who was the selected as first satyagrahi by Mahatma Gandhi to begin individual satyagraha in 1940?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Congress was in a confused state again after the August Offer. The radicals and leftists wanted to launch a mass Civil Disobedience Movement, but here Gandhi insisted on Individual Satyagraha. The first Satyagrahi selected was Acharya Vinoba Bhave, who was sent to Jail when he spoke against the war.

questions.Question: Who was the mastermind of bomb attack on Lord Hardinge at chandani chowk in Delhi in 1912?
questions.solution: Solution:		On the crisp morning of 23 December 1912, Delhi was decked up to welcome the then Viceroy Lord Hardinge on the occasion of the capital’s transfer from Calcutta to Delhi. At a building in Chandni Chowk, a petite woman could be seen waiting with the crowd to see the Viceroy, and then a bomb exploded.Basant Biswas, a young boy of 16 years, had dressed up as a woman and thrown a crude bomb at the elephant carrying the Viceroy. Hardinge escaped with injuries. Rash Behari was the mastermind behind the attack and helped make the bomb. After the blast, Bose went back to his government job at the Forest Research Institute and even organised an honorary reception for Hardinge a few months later.

questions.Question: The main centre of Wahabi Movement  during the freedom movement was
questions.solution: Solution:		This movement, centred around Patna was an Islamic revivalist movement, whose stress was to condemn any change into the original Islam and return to its true spirit. The movement was led by Syed Ahmed Barelvi.

questions.Question: Swami Dayanand established the head quarters of Arya Samaj in:
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Arya Samaj unit was formally set up by him at Bombay in 1875 and later the headquarters of the Samaj were established at Lahore.

questions.Question: In 1912 Mohammad Ali started the paper
questions.solution: Solution:		The Comrade was a weekly English-language newspaper that was published and edited by Maulana Mohammad Ali between 1911 and 1914.

questions.Question: The Indian National congress decided to launch an individual civil disobedience in place of Mass civil Disobedience in:
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian National congress decided to launch an individual civil disobedience in place of Mass civil Disobedience in July 1933.

questions.Question: The term yavanika meant
questions.solution: Solution:		The term yavanika meant curtain.

questions.Question: Visakhadatta sketches the event after the death of Samudragupta in his work
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mudrarakshasa, a historical play in sanskrit by Vishakhadatta in late 4th or early 5th century narrates the ascent of the king Chandragupta Maurya to power in Northern India.

questions.Question: The system of Dual Government during the latter half of the 18th century AD is associated with the name of
questions.solution: Solution:		Dual Government of Bengal started in 1765, when Clive concluded two separate 'treaties of Allahabad' with Shah Alam II(12 Aug.1765) & Shujauddaula(16 Aug.1765). Warren Hastings ended the dual system of government in 1772.

questions.Question: The Vedas contain all the truth was interpreted by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Vedas contain all the truth was interpreted by Swami Dayananda.

questions.Question: The Kalinga was fought in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Kalinga War was a war fought between the Mauryan Empire and the state of Kalinga. Kalinga was an important kingdom because it controlled the trade routes with Southeast Asia. Because of this, Ashoka, the Mauryan king, wanted to capture it. Therefore he lead his huge army to Kalinga in 261 BC.

questions.Question: Under the Government of India, Provincial Legislatures consisted of two chambers, except in the case of
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the Government of India, Provincial Legislatures consisted of two chambers, except in the case was Punjab.

questions.Question: The Venetian traveler who travelled with his wife and reached Vijayanagar around 1420 was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Venetian traveler who travelled with his wife and reached Vijayanagar around 1420 was Niccolo de Conti.

questions.Question: The Uprising of 1857 was described as the first Indian war of Independence by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian War of Independence is an Indian nationalist history of the 1857 revolt by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar that was first published in 1909.

questions.Question: The demand for Swarajya or self- government within the British empire was made from the Congress platform by
questions.optionC: Both Gopal Krishna Gokhale and Dadabhai Naoroji
questions.solution: Solution:		The demand for Swarajya or self- government within the British empire was made from the Congress platform by Gopal Krishna Gokhale in 1905 and Dadabhai Naoroji in 1906.

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi’s first great experiment in Satyagraha came in 1917 in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Champaran Satyagraha of 1917 was the first Satyagraha movement inspired by Gandhi and a major revolt in the Indian Independence Movement. It was a farmer's uprising that took place in Champaran district of Bihar, India during the British colonial period.

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi gave the title of Sardar to Vallabhbhai Patel for his great organizational skill in:
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahatma Gandhi gave the title of Sardar to Vallabhbhai Patel for his great organizational skill in The Bardoli Satyagraha.

questions.Question: Lala Lajpat Rai was also known as :
questions.solution: Solution:		Lala Lajpat Rai was born on 28 January 1865 in Dhudike (now Moga district) of Punjab. He was popularly known as Punjab Kesari meaning The Lion of Punjab also known as Sher-E- Punjab in Punjabi for his contribution to the freedom movement.

questions.Question: Sri Aurobindo Ghosh was born in the year :
questions.solution: Solution:		Aurobindo Ghose was born in India on 15th August 1872. At a young age, he was sent to England to be educated at St Paul's. Sri Aurobindo was an excellent student and won a scholarship to read classics at King's College Cambridge.

questions.Question: Doctrine of Passive Resistance was published in the daily Vande Mataram in:
questions.solution: Solution:		Doctrine of Passive Resistance was published in the daily Vande Mataram in April 1907 by Sri Aurobindo Ghosh.

questions.Question: The Indian People play people’s role in the people’s war was the slogan of:
questions.solution: Solution:		The Communist Party of India had been formed in 1925. The key slogan of their party was to make the Indian People play a people's role in the people’s war.

questions.Question: In 1942 who appealed the Britishers to leave India in God’s hands?
questions.solution: Solution:		In May 1942, Mahatma Gandhi called on Britain to “leave India to God. If this is too much then leave her to anarchy.” In July 1942, the Congress Working Committee met at Wardha. The resolution demanded, “The British Rule in India must end immediately.”

questions.Question: Individual Satyagrah – symbolic and non-violent in nature was started on:
questions.solution: Solution:		The Individual satyagraha movement started on 17th October, 1940 and continued upto December.

questions.Question: United India House organizes Unity among Indians in the United states of America in
questions.solution: Solution:		United India House organizes Unity among Indians in the United states of America in 1910.

questions.Question: Who in the year 1907 unfurled the first national flag at the International socialist conference in Stuttgart (Germany)?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bhikaji Cama, also known as Madame Cama, was the first woman who successfully unfurled the first version of the tricolour Indian flag. She still remains to be one of the most prominent woman personalities to participate in the Indian Nationalist Movement. Born into very well-off Parsi family in Bombay (now Mumbai) Bhikaji received her early education there.

questions.Question: In 1906 to protest discrimination against Indians in S. Africa Mahatma Gandhi started
questions.solution: Solution:		A meeting in Johannesburg on 11 September 1906 marked the start of the resistance campaign, which ultimately became known as satyagraha (meaning ‘truth-force’), with its practitioners called satyagrahi.

questions.Question: Subhash Chandra Bose was elected the president of the Indian national congress :
questions.solution: Solution:		Subhash Chandra Bose and Congress Tripuri Session 1939. The British Government was keen on Bose taking interest in the Axis Powers and the developing Gandhi Bose strife. In December 1938, Bose had a meeting with two representatives of the German Nazi Party.

questions.Question: Two of the great Mughals wrote their own memories. They were
questions.solution: Solution:		Babar and Jahangir were two of the great Mughals wrote their own memories.

questions.Question: To which king belongs the Lion capital at Sarnath?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Lion Capital of Ashoka is a sculpture of four Asiatic lions standing back to back, on an elaborate base that includes other animals. A graphic representation of it was adopted as the official Emblem of India in 1950. It was originally placed on the top of the Ashoka pillar at the important Buddhist site of Sarnath by the Emperor Ashoka, in about 250 BCE. The pillar, sometimes called the Aśoka Column, is still in its original location, but the Lion Capital is now in the Sarnath Museum, in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India.

questions.Question: The use of spinning wheel (Charkha) became common during the
questions.solution: Solution:		The use of spinning wheel (Charkha) became common during the 14th Century AD.

questions.Question: The language of discourses of Gautama Buddha was
questions.solution: Solution:		The language discourses of Gautam Buddha was Pali.

questions.Question: There were widespread risings against the British in the 1820s. Which one of the following did not revolt in the 1820s?
questions.solution: Solution:		There were widespread risings against the British in the 1820s. Santhals did not revolt in the 1820s.

questions.Question: The weekly Commonweal was founded by
questions.solution: Solution:		After making Madras her home, Annie Besant founded a weekly newspaper Commonweal in January 1914.

questions.Question: Ustad Mansur was a famous painter in the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		Ustad Mansur (flourished 1590-1624) was a seventeenth-century Mughal painter and court artist. He grew up during the reign of Jahangir (r. 1605 - 1627) during which period he excelled at depicting plants and animals.

questions.Question: The Vedic deity Indra was the Goddess of
questions.solution: Solution:		In the Vedas, Indra is the king of Svarga (Heaven) and the Devas. He is the god of the heavens, lightning, thunder, storms, rains and river flows. Indra is the most referred to deity in the Rigveda.

questions.Question: Tolkappiyam is associated with the
questions.solution: Solution:		The ancient Tamil literature consists of the grammatical work Tolkappiyam in second Sangam period.

questions.Question: Pulakesin II was the most famous ruler of
questions.solution: Solution:		Pulakeshin II (IAST: Pulakeśin, r. c. 610-642 CE) was the most famous ruler of the Chalukya dynasty of Vatapi (present-day Badami in Karnataka, India).

questions.Question: The Governor General who came to be known as father of communal electorate in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Minto was known as Father of communal electorate.

questions.Question: In order to restrict the freedom of the press, the British government passed "The Indian official secrets Act" in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian official secrets Act in 1904.

questions.Question: The most outstanding representative of Militant Nationalist School of thought was
questions.solution: Solution:		The most outstanding representative of militant school was Bal Gangadhar Tilak later popularly known as Lokamanya Tilak.

questions.Question: Barindra Kumar Ghose and Bhupendranath Dutta started:
questions.solution: Solution:		Barindra Kumar Ghosh or Barindra Ghosh, or, popularly, Barin Ghosh (5 January 1880 – 18 April 1959) was an Indian revolutionary and journalist. He was one of the founding members of Jugantar, a revolutionary outfit in Bengal. Barindra Ghosh was a younger brother of Sri Aurobindo.

questions.Question: Lord Curzon announced the partition of Bengal on :
questions.solution: Solution:		The decision to effect the Partition of Bengal was announced on 19 July 1905 by the Viceroy of India, Curzon. The partition took place on 16 October 1905 and separated the largely Muslim eastern areas from the largely Hindu western areas.

questions.Question: Which Indian revolutionary was called by the Britishers as ‘The Father of Indian Disaffection and biggest traitor’?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak (23 July 1856 – 1 August 1920), born as Keshav Gangadhar Tilak, was an Indian nationalist, teacher, lawyer and an independence activist. He was the first leader of the Indian Independence Movement. The British colonial authorities called him "The father of the Indian unrest."

questions.Question: Who was the founder of a society known as ‘Abhinav Bharat’ ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Abhinav Bharat Society (Young India Society) was a secret society founded by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar and his brother Ganesh Damodar Savarkar in 1903.

questions.Question: Who called Subhash Chandra Bose as Desh Nayak ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Rabindranath Tagore called Subhash Chandra Bose as Desh Nayak.

questions.Question: Who called Government India Act 1935 a Charter of Slavery ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru called Government India Act 1935 a Charter of Slavery.

questions.Question: The Indian National Congress passed Quit India Resolution at :
questions.solution: Solution:		On 8 August 1942 at the All-India Congress Committee session in Bombay, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi launched the 'Quit India' movement. The next day, Gandhi, Nehru and many other leaders of the Indian National Congress were arrested by the British Government.

questions.Question: Which revolutionary was sentenced to death on August 17, 1909?
questions.solution: Solution:		Madanlal Dhingra claimed that he had murdered Curzon-Wyllie as a patriotic act and in revenge for the inhumane killings of Indians by the British Government in India. He was found guilty and sentenced to death. He was executed at Pentonville Prison on 17 August 1909.

questions.Question: Who founded Tattvabodhini  sabha in 1839 ?
questions.solution: Solution:		On 6 October 1839 Debendranath Tagore established Tattvaranjini Sabha which was shortly thereafter renamed the Tattwabodhini (Truth-seekers) Sabha. Initially confined to immediate members of the Tagore family, in 2 years it mustered over 500 members.

questions.Question: Swami Vivekananda established Ramakrishna Mission :
questions.solution: Solution:		Ramakrishna Mission was established on 1st May, 1897 bySwami Vivekananda with the twin objectives of working for one’s own liberation as well as working for the welfare of the world at large.

questions.Question: For the cause of national liberation Swami Dayananda stressed on :
questions.solution: Solution:		For the cause of national liberation Swami Dayananda stressed on Swadeshi, Swadharma, Swabhasha and Swarajya.

questions.Question: Who said - “Our Life and religion are useless without the attainment of Swaraj”?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1906, Bal Gangadhar Tilak introduced two slogans ‘Swaraj is my birth right’ and ‘Our life and religion are useless without the attainment of Swaraj’.

questions.Question: The newspapers ‘The Punjabi and The pupil’ were published by :
questions.solution: Solution:		The newspapers ‘The Punjabi and The pupil’ were published by Lala Lajpat Rai.

questions.Question: The National College in Calcutta had been established on :
questions.solution: Solution:		Bengal National College started with Sri Aurobindo as its first Principal on 14th August 1906.

questions.Question: Who played an important role in the Gadar Movement in 1915?
questions.solution: Solution:		Original name of Ghadar Party was Pacific Coast Hindustan Association. The founding president of Ghadar Party was Sohan Singh Bhakna and Lala Hardayal was the co-founder of this party.

questions.Question: The third person who presented himself for individual Satyagrah launched by Mahatma Gandhi in October 1940 was:
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Satyagrahi selected was Acharya Vinoba Bhave, who was sent to Jail when he spoke against the war. Second Satyagrahi was Jawahar Lal Nehru. Third was Brahma Datt, one of the inmates of the Gandhi’s Ashram.

questions.Question: Subhash Chandra Bose became the Supreme Commander of Indian National Army in :
questions.solution: Solution:		Subhash Chandra Bose became the Supreme Commander of Indian National Army in 1943. Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose was born on 23rd January in 1897. He was an Indian nationalist who form the Indian National Army to fight against British Government.

questions.Question: Lord Mountbatten put forth the plan proposing the partition of India and the creation of Pakistan :
questions.solution: Solution:		On June 3, 1947, immediately after his return to India, Lord mountbatten announced his plan for solving the ‘present impasse’. Before the plan was publicized, Lord Mountbattan had obtained the consent of the Congress and Sikh leaders and also of Mr. M.A. Jinnah.

questions.Question: When quit India Resolution was passed in 1942, the Viceroy of India was :
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Linlithgow took his office on 18 April 1936 and leave on October 1, 1943. Cripps Mission visited India and Quit India resolution was passed in his tenure.

questions.Question: Who presided over the Karachi session of Indian National Congress in 1931 ?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Karachi session was presided by Sardar Patel. The congress adopted a resolution on Fundamental Rights and Economic Policy which represented the Party's Social, Economic and Political programme. It was later known as Karachi Resolution.

questions.Question: Rani Gaidinliu was a rebel leader against the Britishers from:
questions.solution: Solution:		Rani Gaidinliu (26 January 1915 – 17 February 1993) was a Rongmei Naga spiritual and political leader who led a revolt against British rule in India. The movement later turned into a political movement seeking to drive out the British from Manipur and the surrounding Naga areas.

questions.Question: An interim cabinet headed by Jawaharlal Nehru was formed by the congress in :
questions.solution: Solution:		The interim government of India was formed on September 2, 1946from the newly elected Constituent Assembly.

questions.Question: The revolutionary who was associated with the Indian Independence League was :
questions.solution: Solution:		Rash Behari Bose was an Indian revolutionary noted for his planning of the Delhi-Lahore conspiracy of 1912 to assassinate the then Viceroy Lord Hardinge, and his involvement in the Ghadr Conspiracy of 1915.

questions.Question: Indian War of independence 1857 was written by :
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian War of Independence is an Indian nationalist history of the 1857 revolt by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar that was first published in 1909.

questions.Question: Under the Government of India act 1935 it was decided to establish a federation consisting of :
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the Government of India act 1935 it was decided to establish a federation consisting of Governor’s provinces and princely states.

questions.Question: Who called Government of India Act 1935 as thoroughly rotten, fundamentally bad and totally unacceptable?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mohammad Ali Jinnah commented it as “thoroughly rotten, fundamentally bad and totally unacceptable“. Jinnah’s point of view was based upon the feeling that it would substantially increase Hindu majority at the center.

questions.Question: What was the major cause of discontent among soldiers before the revolt of 1857?
questions.solution: Solution:		Question of promotion and pay was the major cause of discontent among soldiers before the revolt of 1857.

questions.Question: Who was the commander of 1857 revolt in Rohilkhand?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ahmadullah Shah (1787 – 5 June 1858) famous as Maulavi of Faizabad, was a leader of the Indian Rebellion of 1857. Maulavi Ahmadullah Shah was known as the Lighthouse of Rebellion in Awadh region.

questions.Question: Partition of Bengal was revoked in 1911 during the Viceroyalty of
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Hardinge, the Viceroy of India (1910- 1916), is remembered for the annulment of the Partition of Bengal in 1911.

questions.Question: Quit India movement began on:
questions.solution: Solution:		The Quit India Movement, or the August Movement, was a movement launched at the Bombay session of the All-India Congress Committee by Gandhiji on 8 August 1942, during World War II, demanding an end to British Rule of India.

questions.Question: Under which document was the separate electorate granted for muslims ?
questions.solution: Solution:		A momentous introduction in the reforms were the separate electorates where seats were reserved for Muslims and in which only Muslims would be polled. The implication that Muslims and their interests could only be protected by Muslims would influence Indian politics in the ensuing decades. The Muslim League had been founded in 1906 by an elite aiming to promote Muslim interests, prevent Hindu dominance over Muslims through a parliamentary system and to advance the Muslim perspective in the deliberations regarding constitutional reforms after October 1907.

questions.Question: During the tenure of which Governor general was the resolution of total independence passed?
questions.solution: Solution:		In the Lahore session of 1929 {presided by Jawaharlal Nehru}, the congress passed a Poorna Swarajya Resolution {drafted by Jawaharlal Nehru} for complete independence. During this time, Lord Irwin was Governor general.

questions.Question: Through which one of the following, the king exercised his control over villages in the Vijayanagar Empire?
questions.solution: Solution:		Through Mahanayakacharya, the king exercised his control over villages in the Vijayanagar Empire.

questions.Question: The Vijayanagara ruler, Kirshnadev Raya's work Amuktamalyada, was in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Vijayanagara ruler, Kirshnadev Rayas work Amuktamalyada, was in Telugu.

questions.Question: The use of Kharoshti in ancient Indian architecture is the result of India's contact with
questions.solution: Solution:		Greece contact with India is the use of kharoshti architechture.

questions.Question: The first Round Table conference was held on:
questions.solution: Solution:		First Round Table Conference was first among the three such conferences organized between 1930 and 1932 by British government towards constitutional reforms in India. These conferences were conducted as per 1930 report of Simon Commission. First Round Table Conference was held between November 1930 and January 1931. It was officially inaugurated on November 12, 1930 at House of Lords at London by the British King (George V) and was chaired by then British Prime Minister, Ramsay MacDonald.

questions.Question: The Gandhi-Irvin pact under which Mahatma Gandhi agreed to suspend the civil Disobedience Movement was signed on
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhi-Irwin Pact, agreement signed on March 5, 1931, between Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian nationalist movement, and Lord Irwin (later Lord Halifax), British viceroy (1926–31) of India.

questions.Question: Which report became the basis for enacting the Government of India Act 1935?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Government of India Act 1935 derived material from four key sources viz. Report of the Simon Commission, discussions at the Third Round Table Conference, the White Paper of 1933 and the reports of the Joint select committees.

questions.Question: The committee headed by Motilal Nehru constituted to draw up a blue print for the future constitution of India published
questions.solution: Solution:		The Nehru Report of 28-30 August, 1928 was a memorandum outlining a proposed new dominion status constitution for India. It was prepared by a committee of the All Parties Conference chaired by Motilal Nehru with his son Jawaharlal Nehru acting as secretary. There were nine other members in this committee.

questions.Question: Velu Thampi led a revolt against the British in state of
questions.solution: Solution:		Velayudhan Chempakaraman Thampi (1765–1809) was the Dalawa or Prime Minister of the Indian kingdom of Travancore between 1802 and 1809 during the reign of Bala Rama Varma Kulasekhara Perumal. He is best known for being one of the earliest individuals to rebel against the British East India Company's supremacy in India.

questions.Question: The term 'Yavanapriya' mentioned in ancient Sanskrit texts denoted
questions.optionC: A fine variety of Indian muslin
questions.optionD: Damsels sent to the Greek court for dance performance
questions.solution: Solution:		The term 'Yavanapriya' mentioned in ancient Sanskrit texts denoted pepper.

questions.Question: Subhash Chandra Bose formed Forward Block in :
questions.solution: Solution:		The All India Forward Block (AIFB) is a left-wing nationalist political party in India. It emerged as a faction within the Indian National Congress in 1939, led by Subhas Chandra Bose. The party re-established as an independent political party after the independence of India.

questions.Question: Who called the 1857 revolt as ‘Student Farmer-Middle class Revolt’?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dr. Amba Prasad called the 1857 revolt as ‘Student Farmer-Middle class Revolt’.

questions.Question: Justice C. Y. Chintamani called Government of India Act 1935?
questions.solution: Solution:		Justice C. Y. Chintamani called Government of India Act 1935 a Lame Federation.

questions.Question: The ultimate ownership of land during the post-Gupta period lay with
questions.solution: Solution:		King has the ultimate ownership of land during the post gupta period.

questions.Question: To which of the republic of Buddha belong?
questions.solution: Solution:		Buddha belong to Sakyas republic.

questions.Question: There was a sharp class division at Harappa and Mohenjodaro. This is clear from the
questions.optionC: Tools and implements used by the Harappans
questions.solution: Solution:		There was a sharp class division at Harappa and Mohenjodaro. This is clear from the Different types of dwellings excavated.

questions.Question: The title given by the British Government to Mahatma Gandhi which he surrendered during the non-cooperation movement was
questions.solution: Solution:		Kaiser-e-hind was the title given by british to Mahatma Gandhi.

questions.Question: Tipu sultan was the ruler of
questions.solution: Solution:		Tipu Sultan (born Sultan Fateh Ali Sahab Tipu, 20 November 1750 – 4 May 1799), also known as the Tipu sahab was a ruler of the Kingdom of Mysore. He was the eldest son of Sultan Hyder Ali of Mysore.

questions.Question: Vaikhanasa the five-fold conception of Vishnu consists of  brahmanpurushaprakritisatyaachyutaaniruddha
questions.optionA: I, II, III, IV and V
questions.optionB: II, III, IV, V and VI
questions.optionC: I, II, IV, V and VI
questions.optionD: I, III, IV, V and VI
questions.solution: Solution:		Vaikhanasa the five-fold conception of Vishnu consists of Brahman, Prakriti, Satya, Achutya and Annirudha.

questions.Question: The troops raised by the emperor but not paid directly the state and place under the charge of mansabadars were known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The troops raised by the emperor but not paid directly the state and place under the charge of mansabadars were known as Dakhili.

questions.Question: To conquer and annex Peshawar and Punjab, Mahmud of Ghazni defeated
questions.solution: Solution:		To conquer and annex Peshawar and Punjab, Mahmud of Ghazni defeated Hindushahis.

questions.Question: To which professions earlier leaders who struggled for freedom of India mainly belonged?
questions.solution: Solution:		Earlier leaders who struggled for freedom of India mainly belonged to Lawyers, Teachers and Journalists.

questions.Question: Who is the founder of Haryanka Dynasty?
questions.solution: Solution:		Initially, the capital was Rajagriha. Later, it was shifted to Pataliputra, near the present-day Patna in India. The founder of this dynasty was Bimbisara himself. According to the Buddhist text, the Mahavamsa, Bimbisara was anointed king by his father at the age of fifteen.

questions.Question: The Moplah Rebellion in 1921 in Malabar was Muslim Peasants Rabellion against :
questions.solution: Solution:		Hindu Land Holders. The Malabar rebellion (also known as the Moplah rebellion and Māppila Lahaḷa in Malayalam) was an armed uprising in 1921 against British authority in the Malabar region of Southern India by Mappilas and the culmination of a series of Mappila revolts that recurred throughout the 19th century and early 20th century.

questions.Question: The Rowlatt Act was passed in :
questions.solution: Solution:		The Anarchical and Revolutionary Crimes Act of 1919 , popularly known as the Rowlatt Act or Black Act, was a legislative act passed by the Imperial Legislative Council in Delhi on 10 March 1919, indefinitely extending the emergency measures of preventive indefinite detention, incarceration without trial and judicial review enacted in the Defence of India Act 1915 during the First World War.

questions.Question: Mahatma  Gandhi launched Kheda Satyagrah on Gujrat in 1918 to support the cause of :
questions.solution: Solution:		The Kheda Satyagraha of 1918, in the Kheda district of Gujarat, India during the period of the British Raj, was a Satyagraha movement organized by Mohandas Gandhi. It was a major revolt in the Indian independence movement. It was the third Satyagraha movement after Champaran Satyagraha and Ahmedabad mill strike. Gandhi organised this movement to support peasants of the Kheda district. People of Kheda were unable to pay the high taxes levied by the British due to crop failure and a plague epidemic.

questions.Question: The Vernacular press Act as a safety valve against vernacular newspapers was passed by Lord Lytton on
questions.solution: Solution:		The act was proposed by Lord Lytton, then Viceroy of India, and was unanimously passed by the Viceroy's Council on 14 March 1878.

questions.Question: Who was the first to call the revolt of 1857 as an organized war for national Independence?
questions.solution: Solution:		V. D. Savarkar was the first to call the revolt of 1857 as an organized war for national Independence.

questions.Question: Whom did the Britishers call the father of Indian disaffection and the biggest traitor?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak (23 July 1856 – 1 August 1920), born as Keshav Gangadhar Tilak, was an Indian nationalist, teacher, lawyer and an independence activist. He was the first leader of the Indian Independence Movement. The British colonial authorities called him "The father of the Indian unrest." He was also conferred with the title of "Lokmanya", which means "accepted by the people (as their leader)".

questions.Question: Who established in 1893 the society for the removal of Obstacles to the Hindu Religion?
questions.solution: Solution:		They organized an association called “Chapekar Club” for physical and military training which they also calledas “the society for the removal of obstacles to the Hindu Religion”.
