Their activities took the form of attacking leading social reformers in the dark, putting tar on the Queen’s statue near the Esplanade in Bombay and burning the examination pandal. They became active members of the Ganapati melas the lustily sang songs praising Shivaji for “his daring deeds and exhorting the audienceto risk their life on the battlefield in a national war to shed upon the earth the lifeblood of the enemies who destroyed Hindu religion”.

questions.Question: Raja Rammohan Roy founded Brahma samaj on
questions.solution: Solution:		The First Session of Ram Mohan Roy's Brahmo Samaj is held in Kolkata. On 20th August 1828, the first session of Raja Ram Mohan Roy's Brahmo Samaj was held in Kolkata. Raja Ram Mohan Roy was a popular social and educational reformer in India who paved the way for progress in India under British rule.

questions.Question: Gandhiji launched the Non-cooperation movement in:
questions.solution: Solution:		The non-cooperation movement was launched on 1 August 1920 and withdrawn in February 1922 after the Chauri Chaura incident.

questions.Question: Zabti System of revenue was prevalent during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Todar Mal, as finance minister of Akbar, brought new system of revenue collection known as zabti system and dahshala system which was a system of taxation. Under the system he took a careful survey of crop yields and prices cultivated for a period of 10 years.

questions.Question: The victories of Karikala are well portrayed in
questions.solution: Solution:		The victories of Karikala are well portrayed in Pattinappalai.

questions.Question: Todar Mal was associated with
questions.solution: Solution:		Todar Mal was associated with land revenue reforms. Raja Todar Mal was the Finance Minister of the Mughal empire during Akbar's reign. He was one of the Navaratnas in Akbar's durbar.

questions.Question: The title of 'Viceroy' was added to the office of the Governor-General of India for the first time in
questions.solution: Solution:		The title of viceroy was added to the office of the Governer- general of India for the first time in 1858 A.D.

questions.Question: To which of the following dynasties did King Bhoja, a great patron of literature and art, belong?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bhoja (reigned c. 1010–1055 CE) was an Indian king from the Paramara dynasty. His kingdom was centered around the Malwa region in central India, where his capital Dhara was located. Bhoja fought wars with nearly all his neighbours in attempts to extend his kingdom, with varying degrees of success. At its zenith, his kingdom extended from Chittor in the north to upper Konkan in the south, and from the Sabarmati River in the west to Vidisha in the east.

questions.Question: Vikramaditya, a king of Ujjain, started the Vikrama samvat in 58 BC in commemoration of his victory over
questions.solution: Solution:		Vikramaditya, a king of Ujjain, started Vikrama Samvat era in 58 BCE after defeating the Shakas, and those who believe that he is based on a historical figure place him around the first century BCE. However, this era is identified as "Vikrama Samvat" after the ninth century CE. Other scholars believe that Vikramaditya is a mythical character, since several legends about him are fantastic in nature.

questions.Question: Tripitakas are sacred books of
questions.solution: Solution:		Tripitaka is a Sanskrit word meaning Three Baskets. The sacred book of Buddhism is called the Tripitaka (called Tipitaka in Pali).

questions.Question: The trident-shaped symbol of Buddhism does not represent
questions.solution: Solution:		Nirvana because in buddhism trident shaped symbol is a reference to the triple gem bhuddha ,dhamma and sangha.

questions.Question: The theory of economic drain of India during British imperialism was propounded by
questions.solution: Solution:		The theory of economic drain of India during British imperialism was propounded by Dadabhai Naoroji.

questions.Question: The treaty of Srirangapatna was signed between Tipu Sultan and
questions.solution: Solution:		The 'Treaty of Srirangapatinam (also called Sri Ranga Patanam or Srirangapatna), signed 18 March 1792, ended the Third Anglo-Mysore War. Its signatories included Lord Cornwallis on behalf of the British East India Company, representatives of the Nizam of Hyderabad and the Maratha Empire, and Tipu Sultan, the ruler of Mysore.

questions.Question: The system of competitive examination for civil service was accepted in principle in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Charter act 1853 Introduced open competition system for recruitment of civil servants. It was open for Indians also for the first time. Accordingly, Macaulay committee (committee on Indian civil service) was appointed in 1854.

questions.Question: When did Mahatma Gandhi go on fast unto death for the first time?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1918, Gandhiji fought for the rights of the textile mill workers of Ahmedabad. Here for the first time he introduced a method of arbitration - fasting.

questions.Question: Who led the revolt of 1857 in Lucknow?
questions.solution: Solution:		During the Indian Mutiny, from 1857 to 1858, Begum Hazrat Mahal's band of supporters, led by Raja Jailal Singh, rebelled against the forces of the British; later, they seized control of Lucknow and she declared her son, Birjis Qadra, as the ruler (Wali) of Oudh.

questions.Question: Who said “one religion one caste and one God for mankind?”
questions.solution: Solution:		Sri Narayana Guru preached the doctrine of 'One caste, One religion, One God.' Its worth note that one of his athiest disciples, Sahadaran Ayyapan, changed into 'no religion, no caste and no God for mankind.

questions.Question: On what ground did the second split in the congress take place in 1918?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Congress in a special session (August 1918) criticized the August Declaration as “disappointing and unsatisfactory” and suggested important modifications. The Moderates, led by Surendra Nath Banerjee, supported the Declaration in a separate conference (November 1918).

questions.Question: The Kakori Conspiracy took place in :
questions.solution: Solution:		The Kakori Conspiracy (or Kakori train robbery or Kakori Case) was a train robbery that took place between Kakori and, near Lucknow, on 9 August 1925 during the Indian Independence Movement against the British Indian Government. The robbery was organised by Hindustan Republican Association (HRA).

questions.Question: Jallianwala Bagh Massacre in Amritsar took place on :
questions.solution: Solution:		The Jallianwala Bagh massacre, also known as the Amritsar massacre, took place on 13 April 1919 when troops of the British Indian Army under the command of Colonel Reginald Dyer fired rifles into a crowd of Punjabis, who had gathered in Jallianwala Bagh, Amritsar, Punjab.

questions.Question: Whom did Mahatma Gandhi consider his political guru?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Krishna Gokhale CIE pronunciation (9 May 1866 – 19 February 1915) was an Indian political leader and a social reformer during the Indian Independence Movement.

questions.Question: Who brought out a paper with the title of the ‘loyal Muhammadanans of India’ ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Sayyid Ahmad Khan brought out a paper with the title of the ‘loyal Muhammadanans of India’.

questions.Question: Individual Satyagrah was started on:
questions.solution: Solution:		On October 17, 1940, the Father of the Nation, Mahatma Gandhi had chosen Acharya Vinoba Bhave as the first satyagrahi (proponent of satyagraha) to start personal satyagraha (movement which meant holding to the truth) and Jawaharlal Nehru as the second.

questions.Question: The First Round Table Conference was held on:
questions.solution: Solution:		First Round Table Conference was held between November 1930 and January 1931. It was officially inaugurated on November 12, 1930 at House of Lords at London by the British King (George V) and was chaired by then British Prime Minister, Ramsay MacDonald.

questions.Question: The East India Association was set up in :
questions.solution: Solution:		The East India Association was founded by Dadabhai Naoroji in 1866, in collaboration with Indians and retired British officials in London. It superseded the London Indian Society and was a platform for discussing matters and ideas about India, and to provide representation for Indians to the Government.

questions.Question: Who established the Hindu Dharma Sangrakshini Sabha in the year 1893 by :
questions.solution: Solution:		Two Brothers- Damodar and Balkrishna Chapekar began the process of revolutionary activities in India. They formed the ‘Hindu Dharma Sangrakshini Sabha’ in 1893 and started celebrating the birthday of Shivaji and Ganesh Utsavs.

questions.Question: Bande Matram was a series of articles published in the year 1907 by :
questions.solution: Solution:		Vande Matram was a series of articles published in the year 1907 by Sri Auronbindo Ghosh.

questions.Question: Which revolutionary wrote books Colour of Swadeshi and Revolutionary Life?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pandit Ram Prasad Bismil wrote books Colour of Swadeshi and Revolutionary Life.

questions.Question: Which revolutionary was associated with the foundation of the Punjab Navjivan Bharat Sabha in 1926?
questions.solution: Solution:		It was founded by Bhagat Singh in March 1926 and was a more public face of the Hindustan Republican Association. The NBS comprised members from the Hindu, Muslim and Sikh communities and organised lectures, public meetings and protests.

questions.Question: The novel ‘Neel Darpan’ depicting the harassment and oppression of Indigo farmers by the Britishers was written by:
questions.solution: Solution:		The novel ‘Neel Darpan’ depicting the harassment and oppression of Indigo farmers by the Britishers was written by Dinabandhu Mitra.

questions.Question: Who led the revolt in 1857 in Bihar and defeated the British Army near Aara?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kunwar Singh led the Indian Rebellion of 1857 in Bihar. He was nearly eighty and in failing health when he was called upon to take up arms. He gave a good fight and harried British forces for nearly a year and remained invincible until the end. He was an expert in the art of guerilla warfare.

questions.Question: Who wrote famous thesis entitled ‘South India in 1857: war of Independence’:
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian War of Independence is an Indian nationalist history of the 1857 revolt by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar that was first published in 1909.

questions.Question: Who founded Satya Shodhak Samaj in 1873 ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Satyashodhak Samaj (Truth-seekers' Society) is a social reform society founded by Jyotirao Phule in Pune, India, on 24 September 1873.

questions.Question: Who conveyed to the Indians – "I am with you wholeheartedly and in terms of culture I am one of you”?
questions.solution: Solution:		Annie Besant conveyed to the Indians – "I am with you wholeheartedly and in terms of culture I am one of you”.

questions.Question: In the history of Indian National Movement Santhal Rebellion took place between :
questions.solution: Solution:		Santhal rebellion 1855-56. The Santhal rebellion predates 1857. It was a rebellion of Santhal people led by 4 Murmu Brothers named Sindhu, Kanhu , Chand and Bhairav, in modern Jharkhand (then Bengal Presidency) against the oppressive Zamindari system. The initially launched Guerilla warfare in the Jungles of Jharkhand.

questions.Question: Who called the revolt of 1857 as a war between barbarism and civilization?
questions.solution: Solution:		T. R. Holmes popularized the view that the Revolt of 1857 was a conflict between civilization and barbarism or a struggle between Oriental and Occidental civilization and culture.

questions.Question: Who is the author of the book ‘The Great Rebellion’?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Author of the Great Rebellion is Ashok Mehta. The great rebellion was the story set in the year of 1857 when Indian freedom fighters fought for independence.

questions.Question: The Turko-Afghan rule in India lasted for about
questions.solution: Solution:		Turko Afghan rule in India lasted for about 3 centuries as they were there in the time of Rana Pratap also and the Turkish king Gaznavi invaded Delhi long before that.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not included in Mughal paintings?
questions.solution: Solution:		The painting which is not included in the Mughal paintings is the Islamic Themes. Mughal paintings are a particular style of South Asian painting. These paintings were evolved during the rule of Mughal Emperors in India and revolved around themes like battles, legendary stories, hunting scenes, wildlife, royal life, mythology, etc.

questions.Question: Against which Mughal Emperor was a FATWA issued from Jaunpur?
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar was the Mughal Emperor against whom the Fatwa was issued from Jaunpur.

questions.Question: Who gave the slogan DO OR DIE during the quit India movement in 1942?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1942, in a fiery speech in Mumbai, Mahatma Gandhi gave a 'do or die' call to the people of India in a final push to make the British quit.

questions.Question: Who founded Atmiya Sabha in 1815?
questions.solution: Solution:		Atmiya Sabha was a philosophical discussion circle in India. The association was started by Ram Mohan Roy in 1815 in Kolkata (then Calcutta). They used to conduct debate and discussion sessions on philosophical topics, and also used to promote free and collective thinking and social reform.

questions.Question: Bal Gangadhar Tilak popularly known as Lokamanya Tilak was born in 1856 at
questions.solution: Solution:		Tilak was born in a Marathi Chitpavan Brahmin family in Ratnagiri as Keshav Gangadhar Tilak, in the headquarters of the eponymous district of present-day Maharashtra (then British India) on 23 July 1856.

questions.Question: An English weekly called ‘New India’ was started by;
questions.solution: Solution:		New India was an early 20th century daily newspaper published in India by the Annie Besant, to highlight issues related to the Indian freedom struggle.

questions.Question: Bang Darshan was the main newspaper of
questions.solution: Solution:		Bangadarshan was a Bengali literary magazine, founded by Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay in 1872, and resuscitated in 1901 under the editorship of Rabindranath Tagore. The magazine had a defining influence on the emergence of a Bengali identity and the genesis of nationalism in Bengal.

questions.Question: In Bengal, the East India Company's headquarters were located at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarters of East India Company were located at Fort William in Bengal. Fort William is a fort built in Calcutta (presently Kolkata) on the eastern banks of the River Hooghly, the major distributary of the River Ganges, during the early years of the Bengal Presidency of British India. It was named after King William III of England. In front of the Fort is the Maidan, which used to be a part of the Fort and is the largest urban park in Calcutta.

questions.Question: Who established the Sadr-Di-wani-Adalat during the British East India Company's rule?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sadr-Di-wani-Adalat during Mughal and British rule in India was a High Court of Civil and Revenue matters.The Ṣadr Dīwānī ʿAdālat was the Supreme Court of Revenue in British India established at Calcutta by Warren Hastings in 1772. It was reformed in 1780 and again in 1793 by the British Parliament.

questions.Question: In 1612 __________established a trading post in Gujarat
questions.solution: Solution:		British established a trading post in 1612 at Gujarat.

questions.Question: Author of Poverty and Un-British Rule in India is__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Naoroji Dadabhai Is the author of books such as Poverty and Un-British Rule In India.

questions.Question: Which of the following events made the English East India Company the legitimate masters of the Bengal Suba?
questions.solution: Solution:		English East India Company became the legitimate masters of Bengal Suba after battle of Buxar which was held on 22 Oct, 1764 between East lndia company led by Hector Munro and Mir Qasim (Nawab of Bengal), Mughal emperor Shah Alam, Nawab of Avadh Shira-jud-daula.

questions.Question: The Viceroy who wanted to train Indian in the art of selfgovernment was
questions.solution: Solution:		Ripon was a true democrat. He took some steps towards liberalizing the administration in India. His aim was to give popular and political education to the Indians. He formulated the local self government and laid the foundations of representative institutions in India.

questions.Question: When the East India Company was formed, the Mughal emperor in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The East India Company was incorporated by royal charter on December 31, 1600. It was an English company formed for the exploitation of trade with East and Southeast Asia and India during the reign of Mughal Emperor Akbar (1556-1605).

questions.Question: The British India Society was formed in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The British India Society (1839): Founded in London with the efforts of William Adam, one of the friends of Raja Ram Mohan Roy. He along with George Thompson, William Ednis, and Major General Briggs organised meetings and enlightened people about the miserable conditions in India.

questions.Question: When the Congress Ministries were formed in the provinces in June 1937, the Viceroy of India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The All-India Muslim League failed to form the government in any province. The Congress ministries resigned in October and November 1939, in protest against Viceroy Lord Linlithgow's action of declaring India to be a belligerent in the Second World War without consulting the Indian people.

questions.Question: The first Mysore War Fought between the British and Hyder Ali in 1767- 1769 A.D., came to an end by the
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1767 Mysore was a powerful state under Hyder Ali. In 1769, the first Anglo-Mysore war was fought in which Haider Ali defeated the British and Treaty of Madras was signed between them. Haider Ali occupied almost the whole of Carnatic.

questions.Question: The British Government intervened in the affairs of the Company and passed an Act in 1773 A.D., known as the
questions.solution: Solution:		Regulating Act, (1773), legislation passed by the British Parliament for the regulation of the British East India Company's Indian territories, mainly in Bengal. The act was amended and the government of India was recast by Prime Minister William Pitt's India Act of 1784.

questions.Question: Who among the following Viceroys became a victim of one of the convicts during his visit to the Andamans?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Mayo was stabbed when he was in Andamans. He was first and last Viceory murdered in India.

questions.Question: India was granted freedom during the British Prime Minister
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian Independence Act 1947 passed on 1st August 1947 by the British Parliament in reign of Prime minister Clement Attlee (Labour party). On 14 August 1947 India divided into two dominion states Pakistan (14th August) and India (15th August).

questions.Question: By the Charter Act of 1813 the Indian trade except in __________ was thrown open to all British subjects
questions.solution: Solution:		Charter act of 1813 ended the monopoly of the East India Company in India, however the company's monopoly in trade with china and trade in tea with India was kept intact. Thus, trade with India for all commodities except Tea was thrown open to all British subjects.

questions.Question: Before the Regulating Act was passed in 1773, there was __________ at home to administer the East India Company
questions.solution: Solution:		Before the Regulating Act was passed in 1773, there was A Committee of 24 at home to, administer the East India Company.

questions.Question: The State Jhansi was made a part of the British Empire in India through
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Dalhousie introduced the Doctrine of Lapse i.e any princely state under the direct influence of East India Company, as a vassal state under the British SubsidiarySystem wouldautomatically be annexed if the ruler was either"manifestly in competent or died without a male heir.The series of state annexed - Satara, Jaipur, Sambhal pur, Jhansi (1854).

questions.Question: The first strategically placed factory that the Britishers had fortified was at
questions.solution: Solution:		Englishmen’s easy success in trade and in establishing independent and fortified settlements at Madras and at Bombay, and the preoccupation of Aurangzeb with the anti-Maratha campaigns led the English to abandon the role of humble petitioners.

questions.Question: Who convinced the British in 1829 to outlaw Sati?
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Ram Mohan Roy convinced the British in 1829 to outlaw Sati.

questions.Question: The Vernacular Press Act was passed in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The act was proposed by Lord Lytton, then Viceroy of India, and was unanimously passed by the Viceroy's Council on 14 March 1878.

questions.Question: In the 18th Century the Royal prerogative in the affairs of the East India Company was controlled by
questions.solution: Solution:		In the 18th Century the Royal prerogative in the affairs of the East India Company was controlled byThe Parliament in England.

questions.Question: Which of the following British Prime Minister headed the First Round Table Conference in London?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Round Table Conference officially inaugurated by George V on November 12, 1930 in Royal Gallery House of Lords at London and chaired by the British Prime Minister, Ramsay MacDonald. The three British political parties were represented by sixteen delegates.

questions.Question: In 1661 the company obtained __________ from Charles II
questions.solution: Solution:		On 11 May 1661, the marriage treaty of Charles II of England and Catherine of Braganza, daughter of King John IV of Portugal, placed Bombay in the possession of the British Empire, as part of Catherine's dowry to Charles.

questions.Question: The Vernacular Press Act was repealed by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Vernacular Press Act, in British India, law enacted in 1878 to curtail the freedom of the Indian-language (i.e., non-English) press. The law was repealed in 1881 by Lytton's successor as viceroy, Lord Ripon (governed 1880-84).

questions.Question: By which Charter Act, the East India Company's monopoly of trade with China come to an end?
questions.solution: Solution:		Charter Acts of 1813 was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom which renewed the charter issued to the British East India Company, and continued the Company's rule in India. However, the Company's commercial monopoly was ended, except for the tea trade and the trade with China. The Charter Act of 1833 ended the monopoly in trade with China and the monopoly to trade in tea in India.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not among the regions where the Britishers had first set up trading posts?
questions.solution: Solution:		Goa is not among the regions where the Britishers had first set up trading posts.

questions.Question: Who propounded the theory of 'Economic Drain of India' during British imperialism?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naoroji's work focused on the drain of wealth from India to England during colonial rule of British in India. One of the reasons that the Drain theory is attributed to Naoroji is his decision to estimate the net national profit of India, and by extension, the effect that colonisation has on the country.

questions.Question: In 1831 Bentinck signed a treaty with Ranjit Singh to protect the British territories from
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1831 Bentinck signed a treaty with Ranjit Singh to protect the British territories from Russian menace.

questions.Question: Regulating Act was in the year of__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Regulating Act, (1773), legislation passed by the British Parliament for the regulation of the British East India Company's Indian territories, mainly in Bengal.

questions.Question: The Governor General of India who initiated the introduction of English in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		In India Lord Macaulay (Thomas Balington Macaulay) is fully credited with the official introduction of English education though the necessary order on the subject were given by Lord William Bentinck the governor general of India on 7th March 1835.

questions.Question: Who made remarkable contribution to the development of Local government?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Ripon made remarkable contribution to the development of local government. In 1882, he abandoned the existing system of local government by the officially nominated people.

questions.Question: Lord Mountbatten had replaced Lord __________ as the viceroy of India in 1947
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Mountbatten had replaced Lord Wavell as the viceroy of India in 1947.

questions.Question: The First Opium War started__________
questions.solution: Solution:		The First Opium War, fought over opium trade, financial reparations, and diplomatic status, began in 1839 and was concluded by the Treaty of Nanking (Nanjing) in 1842.

questions.Question: Who was the first Indian to be elected to the British Parliament?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naroji was the first Anglo Indian to elect the British Parliament. He also known as Grand Old Man of India. He introduced, drain of wealth theory.

questions.Question: The first interim government during the British rule in India was formed in
questions.solution: Solution:		On 2nd September 1946 the Interim Government of India was formed. This temporary government was formed from the Constituent Assembly of India (which was then newly elected). This government was entrusted the task of helping the transition of India and Pakistan from British rule to Independence as two separate nations.

questions.Question: The inauguration of the Ganapati and Shivaji Festivals was done by
questions.solution: Solution:		The inauguration of the Ganapati and Shivaji Festivals was done by 1895.

questions.Question: __________, a judge of the Supreme Court founded the Asiatic society of Bengal in 1784 A.D.
questions.solution: Solution:		The Asiatic Society was founded by civil servant Sir William Jones on 15 January 1784 in a meeting presided over by Sir William Jones, Justice of the Supreme Court of Judicature at Fort William at the Fort William in Calcutta, then capital of the British Raj, to enhance and further the cause of Oriental research.

questions.Question: Who was the supreme body in the Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act- 1858?
questions.solution: Solution:		The British Parliament was the supreme body in the Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act- 1858.

questions.Question: Warren Hastings was appointed as the Governor of __________ in 1772
questions.solution: Solution:		Warren Hastings (6 December 1732 – 22 August 1818), an English statesman, was the first Governor of the Presidency of Fort William (Bengal), the head of the Supreme Council of Bengal, and thereby the first de facto Governor-General of India from 1772 to 1785.

questions.Question: In November 1781, Sir Eyre Coote defeated __________ at Porto Nova
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Porto Novo was fought on 1 July 1781 between forces of the Kingdom of Mysore and British East India Company in the place called Porto Novo (now known as Parangipettai) on the Indian subcontinent, during the Second Anglo-Mysore War. The British force, numbering more than 8,000 under the command of Sir Eyre Coote defeated a force estimated at 40,000 under the command of Hyder Ali.

questions.Question: The English East Company achieved a major victory over the Portuguese in the Battle of __________ in 1612
questions.solution: Solution:		The naval Battle of Swally, also known as Battle of Suvali, took place on 29–30 November 1612 off the coast of Suvali (anglicised to Swally) a village near the Surat city (now in Gujarat, India) and was a victory for four English East India Company galleons over four Portuguese galleons and 26 barks (rowing vessels with no armament).

questions.Question: Who was the Governor General of India during the Civil Disobedience Movement?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Irwin was the Governor General and Viceroy of India (1926-1931). On April 3, 1926 Lord Irwin was appointed 30th Viceroy and Governor-General of India. This was the most tumultuous period for the politics of India.

questions.Question: Who tried to rediscover India's past?
questions.solution: Solution:		Max Muller

questions.Question: The process of the introduction of education in English had been initiated in India by Lord
questions.solution: Solution:		Thomas Babington Macaulay was the secretary to the Board of control of India during the British rule. He was the secretary under Lord Grey from 1832 to 1833. He is known for his Minute on Indian Education which came out in February 1835. He wanted to teach English to the people of India and not Sanskrit or Persian.

questions.Question: Who among the British Governor- General shown great interest in the preservation of ancient monuments?
questions.solution: Solution:		The British Governor- General Lord Curzon shown great interest in the preservation of ancient monuments.

questions.Question: When the East India Company was established India was ruled by
questions.solution: Solution:		When the East India Company was established India was ruled by a Mughal Emperor.

questions.Question: Who among the following revolutionaries was executed by the British
questions.solution: Solution:		Shivaram Hari Rajguru (24 August 1908 – 23 March 1931) was an Indian revolutionary from Maharashtra, known mainly for his involvement in the assassination of a British Raj police officer.

questions.Question: During the Second World War the British forces were defeated at __________
questions.solution: Solution:		As part of the Battle of France on the Western Front, the Battle of Dunkirk was the defence and evacuation to Britain of British and other Allied forces in Europe from 26 May to 4 June 1940. After the Phoney War, the Battle of France began in earnest on 10 May 1940.

questions.Question: The violent Mappilas stormed the bungalow of the District Magistrate . . . . . . and murdered him in 1855
questions.solution: Solution:		At about 9 p.m. on the evening of 11 September 1855 Conolly was attacked and killed at the Collector's Residence at West Hill Bungalow, Calicut by a small group of Mappilas. Conolly was buried in what is now Conolly Park, near South Beach Road; the headstone of his tomb was moved to the premises of the C.S.I. St. Mary's English Church, Calicut in 1997.

questions.Question: The Treaty of Surat was in the year __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Treaty of Surat (6 March 1775) was a treaty by which Raghunathrao, one of the claimants to the throne of the Peshwa, agreed to cede Salsette and Bassein Fort to the English, in consideration of being himself restored to Poona. The military operations that followed are known as the First Anglo-Maratha War.

questions.Question: In 1877 the entrance age to ICS was reduced from 21 to __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1877 the entrance age to ICS was reduced from 21 to 19.

questions.Question: Charles Wood's Despatch__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Charles Wood, the President of the Board of Control, had an important effect on spreading English learning and female education in India. When in 1855 he sent a despatch to Lord Dalhousie, the then Governor-General of India.Wood suggested that primary colleges must adopt vernacular languages, high schools must adopt Anglo verncular language and on college level English medium for education. This is known as Wood's despatch. Vocational and women's education were not stressed upon.

questions.Question: The Indian naval mutiny against the British took place in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The Naval Ratings mutiny took place in 1946. Basically, it started as the sailors were dissatisfied with the food they were given. This snowballed into a mutiny against British rule. The mutiny started in Bombay Dock.

questions.Question: The land was owned by temples known as __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In Kerala, temples are managed by Devaswom Board,which comes under the government of Kerala.

questions.Question: Dyer was __________ by the Government of Britain
questions.solution: Solution:		After the Punjab disturbances, O'Dyer was relieved of his office by the government of Britain.

questions.Question: The capital of British India was transferred from Calcutta to Delhi in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Delhi was officially announced as the capital of British Raj by the then-Emperor George V, on December 12, 1911. The capital was shifted from Calcutta as Delhi was the financial and political seat of many earlier empires and was located closer to the geographical center of India.

questions.Question: The transfer of Government from the 'Company' to the 'Crown' was pronounced by Lord Canning (November 1, 1858) at
questions.solution: Solution:		To declare the assumption of the Government of India by the crown a Durbar was held at Allahabad on November 1, 1858, by the Viceroy Lord Canning. Queen`s proclamation was read by Lord Canning. As per the proclamation, the administration of India came into the direct hands of British Government.

questions.Question: The decisive battle of the third Carnatic War was waged between the French and the British at
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Wandiwash was a decisive battle in India during the Seven Years' War. The Count de Lally's army, burdened by a lack of naval support and funds, attempted to regain the fort at Vandavasi, now in Tamil Nadu. This was the Third Carnatic War fought between the French and the British.

questions.Question: Punjab was annexed to the British empire during the reign of Governor General
questions.solution: Solution:		During the reign of Dalhousie East India Company annexed Punjab in 1849. Most of the Punjab region was annexed by the East India Company in 1849, and was one of the last areas of the Indian subcontinent to fall under British control. In 1858, the Punjab, along with the rest of British India, came under the direct rule of the British crown.

questions.Question: Who of the following Governor General is associated with Subsidiary Alliance System?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Subsidiary Alliance System was “Non-Intervention Policy” used by Lord Wellesley who was the Governor-General (1798-1805) to establish British Empire in India. According to this system, every ruler in India had to accept to pay a subsidy to the British for the maintenance of British army.

questions.Question: The East India Association was founded by __________ in 1866
questions.solution: Solution:		The East India Association was founded by Dadabhai Naoroji in 1866, in collaboration with Indians and retired British officials in London. It superseded the London Indian Society and was a platform for discussing matters and ideas about India, and to provide representation for Indians to the Government.

questions.Question: Who among the following Indian cracks the British Indian Civil Services Examination in the first time of Indian History?
questions.solution: Solution:		Satyendranath Tagore became first Indian who cracked I.C.S. or Indian Civil Service examination.

questions.Question: The term of office fixed by Regulating Act for Governor General was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Regulating Act ( May 3, 1773): In 1765, after the battle of Buxer the East India Company got the Diwani ( Right to collect Revenue) of Bengal , Bihar and Orissa. The Governor General was assisted by four councilors. Their tenure of office was fixed for 5 years.

questions.Question: The only Viceroy to be assassinated in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Mayo was killed by an Afridi Pathan Sher Ali Afridi in Port Blair of Andaman and Nicobar on 8th Feb, 1972.

questions.Question: British Indian Association was founded on October 29, 1851 at__________
questions.solution: Solution:		The British Indian Association was founded on October 29, 1851 at Calcutta with Raja Radhakanta Dev and Debendranath Tagore as its President and Secretary respectively. Other members of the Association included Ramgopal Ghosh, Peary Chand Mitra and Krishnadas Pal. Its membership was kept exclusive to Indians.

questions.Question: Who defeated the Spanish Armada?
questions.solution: Solution:		The defeat of the Spanish Armada in 1588 has long been held as one of England's greatest military achievements. The successful defence of the kingdom against invasion on such an unprecedented scale boosted the prestige of England's Queen Elizabeth I and encouraged a sense of English pride and nationalism.

questions.Question: Which British Governor General introduced Postage Stamp in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Dalhousie introduced Postage stamp, he also introduced Railway, Telegram and PWD.

questions.Question: Who among the following British persons admitted the Revolt of 1857 as a national revolt?
questions.solution: Solution:		British member of Parliament (House of commons) Benziman Disraeli admitted the revolt of 1857 as a National Revolt. V. D. SavarKar describe this revolt as the Indian's first struggle for Independence.

questions.Question: During the Viceroyalty of Sir John Lawrence the bone of contention between India and Bhutan was
questions.solution: Solution:		During the Viceroyalty of Sir John Lawrence the bone of contention between India and Bhutan wasDuars.

questions.Question: The arrival of Vasco da Gama in Calicut, India on __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Vasco Da Gama sailed from Lisbon on July 8, 1497, with a crew of 170 men. He arrived at Calicut (now Kozhikode) on May 20, 1498.

questions.Question: The island of Bombay had been given to the British Prince Charles II as dowry by the
questions.solution: Solution:		The island of Bombay had been given to the British Prince Charles II as dowry by the Portuguese.

questions.Question: Who was the first Governor General of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Warren Hastings (6 December 1732 – 22 August 1818), an English statesman, was the first Governor of the Presidency of Fort William (Bengal), the head of the Supreme Council of Bengal, and thereby the first de facto Governor-General of India from 1773 to 1785. The first governor-general in India (of Bengal) was Warren Hastings, the first official governor-general of British India was Lord William Bentinck, and the first governor-general of the Dominion of India was Lord Mountbatten.

questions.Question: Who was the first Governor General of Bengal?
questions.solution: Solution:		Warren Hastings is the first British Governor General of Bengal. He took the charge as a Governor General on 20th October,1773.

questions.Question: The first Viceroy of India was
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Canning was the first Viceroy of India. The title of Viceroy was created in 1858 after the mutiny of 1857. Before 1858, East India Company was ruling large parts of India and the head of administration of the East India Company was called Governor General.

questions.Question: After the year 1853, a substantial amount of British capital had been invested in
questions.solution: Solution:		After the year 1853, a substantial amount of British capital had been invested in the railways.

questions.Question: The British Governor General and Viceroy who served for the longest period in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The British Governor General and Viceroy who served for the longest period in India wasLord Dalhousie.

questions.Question: During British rule, who was instrumental for the introduction of the Ryotwari system in the then Madras Presidency?
questions.solution: Solution:		Thomas Munro and Captain Reid known as the father of the Ryotwari Settlement in India. It was firstly introduced in district 'BARAMAHAL' of Tamilnadu. By this settlement the Ryott-Cultivator was recognised as a owner of field and he had to pay revenue to British Government directly.

questions.Question: The East India Company was established in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The East India Company was an English company formed for the exploitation of trade with East and Southeast Asia and India. Incorporated by royal charter on December 31, 1600, it was started as a monopolistic trading body so that England could participate in the East Indian spice trade.

questions.Question: The 'Sepoy Mutiny' was in the year __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian Mutiny, also called Sepoy Mutiny, widespread but unsuccessful rebellion against British rule in India in 1857–58. Begun in Meerut by Indian troops (sepoys) in the service of the British East India Company, it spread to Delhi, Agra, Kanpur, and Lucknow.

questions.Question: Which Indian ruler had requested Napoleon for help in driving the British away from India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tipu Sultan had requested Napoleon for help in driving the British away from India.

questions.Question: Rani Laxmi Bai died fighting the British in the Battle of
questions.solution: Solution:		On June 18th 1858, Rani Lakshmibai of Jhansi, one of the most important figures of India's First War of Independence, died while fighting against the British in Gwalior.

questions.Question: In which year was the title of Governor general chanced to that of the Viceroy?
questions.solution: Solution:		The title "Viceroy and Governor-General" was first used in the queen's proclamation appointing Viscount Canning in 1858.

questions.Question: The Mutiny was brought to an end with the fall of __________ into the hands of the British in India
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mutiny was brought to an end with the fall of Gwalior into the hands of the British in India.

questions.Question: The permanent settlement was made in Bengal in the sphere of revenue administration by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Permanent Settlement (also Premanent Settlement of Bengal) was introduced by Lord Cornwallis in 1793. It was an agreement between the British East India Company and the Landlords of Bengal to settle the Land Revenue to be raised.

questions.Question: Gandhi had been provoked into crusading for the lot of the Asians in South Africa by the British law called the Act
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhi had been provoked into crusading for the lot of the Asians in South Africa by the British law called cl Asiatic Registration.

questions.Question: Who was the Viceroy when Delhi became the capital of British India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Charles Hardingewas the Viceroy when the capital of India was shifted from Calcutta (now Kolkata) to Delhi in 1911. There is a well known medical college in Delhi named after the Viceroy.

questions.Question: Joseph François Dupleix was the commander of the __________ forces in India
questions.solution: Solution:		Joseph-Francois Dupleix was a colonial administrator and governor-general of the French territories in India, who nearly realized his dream of establishing a French empire in India.

questions.Question: The Permanent Settlement was enforced on__________
questions.solution: Solution:		The rules of the permanent settlement made every individual zamindar and talukdar the permanent and absolute proprietors of the land under their control. As absolute proprietors of land, zamindars and talukdars were required to pay revenue to government at a rate fixed permanently.

questions.Question: Who set up the dual system of administration in Bengal?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Dual System of Government in Bengal was the brainchild of Lord Clive.

questions.Question: MSP means __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Malabar Special Police (MSP) is a paramilitary unit of the State Police of Kerala.

questions.Question: Lord Lytton had lowered the age limit for Indian for the ICS from 21 year to
questions.solution: Solution:		The age for eligibility in civil services was brought down from 21 to 19 years by Lord Lytton.

questions.Question: The Hindu Widows Remarriage Act __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Hindu Widows Remarriage Act of 1856, provided legal safeguards against loss of certain forms of inheritance for remarrying a Hindu widow, though, under the Act, the widow forsook any inheritance due her from her deceased husband.

questions.Question: What did the Hunter Commission appointed by the Viceroy probe?
questions.solution: Solution:		After Jallianwala Bagh tragedy a commission was estb. under William Wilson Hunter in 1919. It is known as Hunter commission but the report of commission was rejected by INC,and new commission was estb. under Madan Mohan Malviya.

questions.Question: The British colonial policies in India proved most ruinous for Indian
questions.solution: Solution:		The british colonial policies in india proved most ruinous for indian handicrafts. The real blow to Indian handicrafts fell after 1813, when they lost not only their foreign markets but, what was of much greater importance, their market in India itself. The Industrial Revolution in Britain completely transformed Britain’s economy and its economic relations with India.

questions.Question: The first Indian to be elected as a member of the British House of Commons was
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naoroji was elected to the British house of commons from the Finsbury Central Constituency in the elections of 1892 by a narrow margin of 3 votes by defeating Fredrick Thomas Penton. Being a subject of the British crown (Being a citizen of British India) he was allowed to take part in the election.

questions.Question: The first Indian to contest an election to the British House of Commons was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Indian to contest an election to the British House of Commons was Womesh Chandra Banerjee.

questions.Question: The first Bengali Drama, written to highlight the brutality of the British indigo planters, was
questions.solution: Solution:		Nil Darpan (The Indigo Mirror) is a Bengali play written by Dinabandhu Mitra in 1858–1859. The play was published in Dhaka in 1860, under a pseudonym of the author. The play was essential to Nil Vidroha, better known as the Indigo Revolt of February–March 1859 in Bengal, when farmers refused to sow indigo in their fields to protest against exploitative farming under the British Raj.

questions.Question: The Treaty of Lahore was signed between the Sikhs and the British in India in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The Treaty of Lahore was signed on 9 March 1846 after the First Sikh War. After the defeat of the Sikhs at the Battle of Sobraon the British were able to march into Lahore without any further battles. After the British reached the city of Lahore the treaty was signed.

questions.Question: The privileges of free trade granted to the English East India Company were confirmed in 1717 by Emperor
questions.solution: Solution:		Emperor Farrukhsiyar issued the British East India Company such a farman in 1717. It allowed the Company to live and trade for free in Mughal India except for an annual payment. They were also given the right to issue dastak or trade permits to transfer goods, which the officials largely used for their own gains.

questions.Question: Which of the following British official associated with the local self-government?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Ripon is known to have granted the Indians first taste of freedom by introducing the Local Self Government in 1882. His scheme of local self government developed the Municipal institutions which had been growing up in the country ever since India was occupied by the British Crown.

questions.Question: Year of the Battle of Wandiwash is __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Battle of Wandiwash, (Jan. 22, 1760), in the history of India, a confrontation between the French, under the comte de Lally, and the British, under Sir Eyre Coote. It was the decisive battle in the Anglo-French struggle in southern India during the Seven Years War (1756–63).

questions.Question: The Charter for the establishment of the East India Company was granted by
questions.solution: Solution:		Charter granted to the East India Company. Queen Elizabeth I of England grants a formal charter to the London merchants trading to the East Indies, hoping to break the Dutch monopoly of the spice trade in what is now Indonesia.

questions.Question: By the Act of 1773, Parliament granted a loan of __________ to the East India Company
questions.solution: Solution:		By the Act of 1773, Parliament granted a loan of Rs. 400,000 to the East India Company.

questions.Question: During colonial period, British capital was mainly invested in
questions.solution: Solution:		Agriculture was mainly invested by British during colonial period, the raw material related to agriculture was compulsory for industry during colonial period.

questions.Question: In 1650 Gabriel Boughton, an employee of the Company obtained a license for trade in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1650, Gabriel Boughton an employee of the Company obtained a license for trade in Bengal. An English factory was set up in 1651 at Hugli.

questions.Question: The East India Company had taken Bombay from
questions.solution: Solution:		The East India Company had taken Bombay from Charles II. On 21 May 1662, the marriage treaty of Charles II of England and Catherine of Braganza, daughter of King John IV of Portugal, placed Bombay in possession of the British Empire, as part of dowry of Catherine to Charles.

questions.Question: The first Indian Governor of a British Province (Bihar) in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		He was the first Governor of Bihar and Orissa, first Indian Advocate-General of Bengal, first Indian to become a member of the Viceroy's executive Council and the first Indian to become a member of the British ministry. He is sometimes also referred as Satyendra Prasanno Sinha or Satyendra Prasad Sinha.

questions.Question: August Offer 1940 was made by the Viceroy
questions.solution: Solution:		On 8 August 1940, early in the Battle of Britain, the Viceroy of India, Lord Linlithgow, made the so-called "August Offer".

questions.Question: Fakir-Sannyasi Resistance against the East India Company dominated in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Fakir-Sannyasi Resistance an armed resistance of the combined body of Muslim fakirs (sufis) and Hindu sannyasis (yogis) against the dominance of the English East India Company in Bengal. This resistance began in 1760 and continued for more than four decades.

questions.Question: The Treaty of Mangalore was in the year __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Treaty of Mangalore was signed between Tipu Sultan and the British East India Company on 11 March 1784. It was signed in Mangalore and brought an end to the Second Anglo-Mysore War.

questions.Question: During their rule the British persuaded or forced cultivators in Assam to grow__________
questions.solution: Solution:		The trade of tea was most profitable to Britishers that's why they turned to cultivator in Assam to grow Tea.

questions.Question: On which day had premier Attlee conceded that the British would quit India by June, 1948?
questions.solution: Solution:		February 20, 1947 had premier Attlee conceded that the British would quit India by June, 1948.

questions.Question: Lord Cornwallis had introduced the __________ land tenure system
questions.solution: Solution:		Immediately after putting his legs in India, Lord Cornwallis in 1786 opined once-for-all settlement with the zamindars for the collection of land revenue. In fact, Lord Cornwallis cut the Gordian knot in 1790 when the decennial permanent settlement system was decided to be introduced in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.

questions.Question: Lytton was selected as Viceroy to India to fulfill the ambitious plans of Disraeli in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Lytton was selected as Viceroy to India to fulfill the ambitious plans of Disraeli in Afghanistan.

questions.Question: Who said that the exploitative nature of British rule was 'Bleeding India White'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naoroji said that the exploitative nature of British rule was 'Bleeding India White'.

questions.Question: Which of the following British official intiated the Doctrine of Lapse?
questions.solution: Solution:		The policy is most commonly associated with Lord Dalhousie, who was the Governor General of the East India Company in India between 1848 and 1856.

questions.Question: The Act constituting the first legislative interference by the British Parliament in the affairs of India was the
questions.solution: Solution:		The Regulating Act 1773 was an Act of the Parliament of Great Britain intended to overhaul the management of the East India Company's rule in India.

questions.Question: The United East India Company refers to the company in India formed by the
questions.solution: Solution:		The United East Indian Company (Dutch: Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie; VOC), referred to by the British as the Dutch East India Company, was originally established as a chartered company in 1602, when the Dutch government granted it a 21-year monopoly on Dutch spice trade.

questions.Question: The new proletariat class which emerged in India on account of the British economic policies, consisted of
questions.solution: Solution:		The new proletariat class which emerged in India on account of the British economic policies, consisted of Money lenders, Landlords, Traders.

questions.Question: As per 'August Offer' the British objective for India was __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The August Offer was a proposal made by the British government in 1940 promising the expansion of the Executive Council of the Viceroy of India to include more Indians, the establishment of an advisory war council, giving full weight to minority opinion, and the recognition of Indians' right to frame their own constitution (after the end of the war). The Congress rejected the August Offer. Nehru said, “Dominion status concept is dead as a door nail.” Gandhi said that the declaration had widened the gulf between the nationalists and the British rulers.

questions.Question: During the period of which Governor General Viceroy was the Indian Civil Service introduced?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cornwallis realised that in order to consolidate the British rule in India, it was very important to organise the civil services. Civil Services was started by Lord Cornwallis and hence he is called the “Father of Indian Civil Service”.

questions.Question: Who said that he had not become His Majesty's first Minister to preside over the liquidation of the British Empire?
questions.solution: Solution:		Churchill said that the Charter did not apply to India, for he had 'not become His Majesty's first minister to preside over the liquidation of the British empire'.

questions.Question: The Seven Years' War (1756-1763) resulted in the defeat of the__________ forces
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1756, the British formally declared war against France. In addition, Spanish attempts to aid France in the Americas had failed, and France also suffered defeats against British forces in India. The Seven Years' War ended with the signing of the treaties of Hubertusburg and Paris in February 1763.

questions.Question: India became independent during the vice royalty of
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Mountbatten: Last Viceroy of India (1947-1948) Lord Mountbatten served as last Viceroy of India from 12 February 1947 – 15 August 1947; and then first Governor General of Free India from 15 August 1947 – 21 June 1948. During his tenure, India got independence in the form of two dominions of India Pakistan.

questions.Question: Which Governor General had entertained Ranjit Singh with great honour at Ropar?
questions.solution: Solution:		 Governor General William Bentinck had entertained Ranjit Singh with great honour at Ropar.

questions.Question: Who was the prime minister of Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act, 1858?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Palmerston was the prime minister of Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act, 1858.

questions.Question: Who was the monarch of Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act, 1858?
questions.solution: Solution:		 In August 1858, the British parliament passed an act that set an end to the rule of the company. The control of the British government in India was transferred to the British crown. At this time, Victoria was the queen of Britain.

questions.Question: "Treaty of Rajpurghat" was signed on December 25, 1805 between Holkar and __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Yashwantrao was the last to sign a treaty with the British, on 24 December 1805 at a place called Rajpur Ghat on the bank of Beas River. The treaty was named 'The Treaty of Peace and Amity between the British Government and Yashwantrao Holkar.'

questions.Question: The Peshwaship was abolished by the British at the time of Peshwa
questions.solution: Solution:		Baji Rao II (10 January, 1775 – 28 January, 1851) was the last Peshwa of the Maratha Empire, and governed from 1795 to 1818. He was installed as a puppet ruler by the Maratha nobles, whose growing power prompted him to flee his capital Pune and sign the Treaty of Bassein (1802) with the British. The last Peshwa was Baji Rao-II. Duringhrs reign the peshwa ship was abolished by the British Government (Lord Harding-I, third Anglo Maratha battle).

questions.Question: Who among the following had been the leader of a number of anti-British revolts in Sambalpur?
questions.solution: Solution:		By virtue of the Doctrine of Lapse, Lord Dalhousie annexed Sambalpur in 1849, as Narayan Singh had no male successor to succeed him. During the uprising of 1857 the sepoys set Surendra Sai and his brother Udyant Sai free. The resistance to British continued in Sambalpur under the leadership of Surendra Sai.

questions.Question: On imprisonment in 1908 by the British, Bal Gangadhar Tilak was in
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak was imprisoned in 1908 to Mandalay for six years. Tilak criticise the Britishers in his newspaper, under a article name 'Bharat ki Durdasha' and this became the reason for his imprisonment.

questions.Question: Madras was returned by the French to the British in 1748 by the Treaty of
questions.solution: Solution:		Madras was returned by the French to the British in 1748 by the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle.

questions.Question: Which of the following counterpart of British in the Treaty of Salbai?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Treaty of Salbai was signed on 17 May 1782, by representatives of the Maratha Empire and the British East India Company after long negotiations to settle the outcome of the First Anglo-Maratha War. David Anderson concluded the Treaty of Salbai on behalf of the East India Company.

questions.Question: The master stroke of Lord Wellesley to establish British paramountcy in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The master stroke of Lord Wellesley to establish British paramountcy in India was Subsidiary Alliance.

questions.Question: Who was Lord Morley?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Morley became secretary of state for India in Henry Campbell-Bannerman's Cabinet of 1905.

questions.Question: The Non-Cooperation Movement under Gandhi was in full swing during the Viceroyalty of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Non-Cooperation Movement under Gandhi was in full swing during the Viceroyalty of Reading.

questions.Question: Queen Victoria's famous proclamation, transferring authority from the East India Company to the Crown , was made from
questions.solution: Solution:		Queen Victoria's famous proclamation, A Royal Durbar was held at Allahabad in November 1, 1858. A proclamation was issued by Queen Victoria. It was read at the Durbar by Lord Canning, who was the last Governor General and the first Viceroy of India.

questions.Question: In which region did Birsa Munda operate against the British?
questions.solution: Solution:		Birsa Munda was a great tribal leader belonging to the Munda Adivasi, the movement operate against Britishin Chhota Nagpur (Jharkhand) region.

questions.Question: The single biggest item of British capital investment in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The single biggest item of British capital investment in India was Railways.

questions.Question: Which of the Act made the governor of Bengal as Governor General of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Governor-General of Bengal was made Governor-General of India through the Charter Act of 1833.

questions.Question: British Crown assumed sovereignty over Indian from the East Indian Company in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The government of India Act (1858) also known as the act for Good Government of India transferred the power to the British crown from East India company.

questions.Question: Who was the Viceroy at the time of Quit India Movement?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Linlithgow (1936 – 1944) was the viceroy of India during Quit India Movement. The Quit India Movement (also known as the August Movement) was a civil disobedience movement launched by Mahatma Gandhi on August 8,1942 in Mumbai for complete independence

questions.Question: Sir Thomas Roe came to India with a letter from the British Monarch
questions.solution: Solution:		This event also started the process of transforming the British East India Company from a group of merchants, to an organization with military force. In 1614, King James I of England sent a diplomat, Sir Thomas Roe, to visit the Mughal emperor, Jahangir, and negotiate a trade treaty.

questions.Question: Subsidiary Alliance was introduced by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Subsidiary Alliance System was "Non-Intervention Policy" used by Lord Wellesley who was the Governor-General (1798-1805) to establish British Empire in India. According to this system, every ruler in India had to accept to pay a subsidy to the British for the maintenance of British army.

questions.Question: The policy of Doctrine of lapse was introduced by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The doctrine of lapse was an annexation policy applied by the British East India Company in India until 1858. The policy is most commonly associated with Lord Dalhousie, who was the Governor General of the East India Company in India between 1848 and 1856.

questions.Question: Who put on the statute book two obnoxious measures the Vernacular press Act and the Indian Arms Act
questions.solution: Solution:		Lytton put on the statute book two obnoxious measures— the vernacular press Act and Indian Arms Act. Lytton' s unpopular acts provoked a great storm of opposition in the country and led to the organisation of various political associations for carrying an anti-Government propaganda in the country.

questions.Question: The Indian Civil Service Act was passed during the Viceroyalty of
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Canning (1858–62): The Indian Councils Act of 1862 was passed, which proved to be a landmark in the constitutional history of India.

questions.Question: The Ancient Monuments Preservation Act was passed during the viceroyalty of
questions.solution: Solution:		One of the most remarkable acts passed during the times of Lord Curzon was the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act of 1904. This act made any injury to the protected monuments an offence punishable under the law.

questions.Question: Diu was the colony of the __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Daman and Diu were once part of a combined union territory along with Goa (a Konkani-speaking region), before Goa became a state in 1987. The use of Portuguese, which was the territory's official language during the colonial period, is in decline and relegated to home use.

questions.Question: According to the terms of the treaty of Srirangapattanam, . . . . . . was ceded to the British
questions.solution: Solution:		According to the terms of the treaty of Srirangapattanam, Malabar was ceded to the British.

questions.Question: The Treaty between Ranjit Singh and the British was signed at
questions.solution: Solution:		Treaty of Amritsar, (April 25, 1809), pact concluded between Charles T. Metcalfe, representing the British East India Company, and Ranjit Singh, head of the Sikh kingdom of Punjab. The British wanted a defensive treaty against the French and control of Punjab to the Sutlej River.

questions.Question: When the East India Company came into existence, England was ruled by the__________
questions.solution: Solution:		When the East India Company came into existence, England was ruled by the Stuarts.

questions.Question: Indian Mutiny began in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian Rebellion of 1857 is also called the Indian Mutiny, the Sepoy Mutiny, North India's First War of Independence or North India's first struggle for independence. It began on 10 May 1857 at Meerut, as a mutiny of sepoys of the British East India Company's army.

questions.Question: Robert Clive, the Governor General of the __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Major-General Robert Clive, 1st Baron Clive, KB, FRS, also known as Clive of India, Commander-in-Chief of British India, was a British officer and privateer who established the military and political supremacy of the East India Company in Bengal.

questions.Question: During their rule the British persuaded or forced cultivators in Bengal to grow__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Britisher invested in agriculture to fulfil the demand of raw materials required for industries in Britain. So, British persuaded or forced cultivator in Bengal to grow Jute (it also known as golden fibre).

questions.Question: In 1614 Sir Thomas Roe was instructed by __________ to visit the court of Jahangir, the Mughal emperor of India
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1614 Sir Thomas Roe was instructed by James I to visit the court of Jahangir, the Moghul emperor of Hindustan to arrange a commercial treaty and to secure for the East India Company sites for commercial agencies. Sir Thomas was successful, and though the Great Moghul Jahangir was contemptuous of the presents sent him by James I, he sent him a remarkably polite letter.

questions.Question: When were Morley-Minto reforms taken place?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian Councils Act 1909, commonly known as the Morley-Minto Reforms (or as the Minto-Morley Reforms), was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom that brought about a limited increase in the involvement of Indians in the governance of British India.

questions.Question: The writers of the East India Company had their training in the college at __________ in England
questions.solution: Solution:		The writers of the East India Company had their training in the college at Haileybury in England.

questions.Question: Gandhiji's famous Quit India movement call to the British was given in
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhiji launched Quit India Movement on 8th August 1942 in Bombay session of congress. It is also known as August revolutoion.

questions.Question: Lord __________ is regarded to have been the father of local self-government in India
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Ripon is known as Father of Local Self Government in India. This was not enacted by any act, it was a resolution that was passed in 1882.

questions.Question: Which war lord is also known as 'little corporal'
questions.solution: Solution:		Napoleon Bonaparte war lord is also known as 'little corporal'.

questions.Question: Who among of the following was the Viceroy of India when Indian University Act, 1904 was passed?
questions.solution: Solution:		During the time period of Indian University act,1904 Lord Curzon was the Viceroy of India.

questions.Question: When the Simon Commission visited India the Viceroy was
questions.solution: Solution:		Simon Commission had visited India on April 3, 1926 Lord Irwin was appointed 30th Viceroy and Governor-General of India. In 1927, British government appointed a commission under the chairmanship of Sir John Simon.

questions.Question: Who was the Viceroy when the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre took place?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Chelmsford was the Viceroy of India when Jallianwala Bagh Massacre took place on 13 April 1919.

questions.Question: Seringapatnam was the capital of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1767 Maratha Peshwa Madhavrao defeated both Hyder Ali and Tipu Sultan and entered Srirangapatna, the capital of Mysore.

questions.Question:
Consider the following on the chronology of appointment of Viceroys
I. Reading
II. Irwin
III. Wellingdon
IV. Linlithgow
questions.solution: Solution:		The following on the chronology of appointment of Viceroys were Reading, Irwin, Wellingdon and Linlithgow.

questions.Question: Which of the following act was the revision of Vernacular Act?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Press Act of 1910 was legislation promulgated in British India imposing strict censorship on all kinds of publications. The measure was brought into effect to curtail the influence of Indian vernacular and English language in promoting support for what was considered radical Indian nationalism.

questions.Question: Who among the following initiated reforms among Muslims?
questions.solution: Solution:		The most important movement for the spread of modern education and social reform among Muslims was started by Syed Ahmad Khan (1817-1898). The leadership of the League was taken over by Sir Muhammad Iqbal, who in 1930 first put forward the demand for a separate Muslim state in India. The "Two-Nation Theory", the belief that Hindus and Muslims were two different nations who could not live in one country, gained popularity among Muslims.

questions.Question: __________formed the Arya Mahila Samaj in Pune?
questions.solution: Solution:		After Medhvi's death (1882), Ramabai moved to Pune where she founded Arya Mahila Samaj (Arya Women's Society). The purpose of the society was to promote the cause of women's education and deliverance from the oppression of child marriage.

questions.Question: The Arya Samaj is against
questions.solution: Solution:		Arya samaj was founded by Swami Dayananda Saraswati, in 1875 they opposed the rituals andidol-worship. Members of the Arya Samaj believe in one God and reject the worship of idols.

questions.Question: Which of the following are the paths chosen by Ramakrishna Paramahamsa towards salvation
questions.optionB: Belief in one single god monotheism
questions.optionC: Vedas and Upanishads are the only way to salvation
questions.solution: Solution:		Renunciation, meditation and devotion are the paths chosen by Ramakrishna Paramahamsa towards salvation.

questions.Question: Who among the following British Officials suppressed the Revolt of Jhansi?
questions.solution: Solution:		British Officials Hugh Rose suppressed the Revolt of Jhansi.

questions.Question: Who was the governor-general during the Revolt of 1857?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Canning served as Governor General of India from 1856 to 1862. During his tenure, the Government of India Act, 1858 was passed which created the office of Viceroy to be held by the same person who was Governor General of India. Thus, Lord Canning also served as first Viceroy of India.

questions.Question: Gurudevan participated in the anniversary of the Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam held at Palluruthy in__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Gurudevan participated in the anniversary of the Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam held at Palluruthy in 1927. It was a splendid meeting which demonstrated the sincere, devout faith of the people in Gurudevan. T. K. Madhavan was one of the chief architects of this meeting.

questions.Question: Which of the following is called "Magna Carta of English Education in India"?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Wood's Despatch is known as the Magna Carta of Indian Education. It was the Act of 1854, which was passed by the British.The despatch was presented by the Secretary of State, Sir Charles Wood, to the directors of the East India Company (as there was Company's rule at that time).

questions.Question: Who of the following leaders is not associated with the Brahmo Samaj?
questions.solution: Solution:		Atmaram Pandurang or Atmaram Pandurang Turkhadekar was an Indian physician and social reformer who founded the Prarthana Samaj and was one of the two Indian co-founders of the Bombay Natural History Society.

questions.Question: Henry Vivian Derozio started young Bengal movement with the inspiration of which revolutionary ideas?
questions.solution: Solution:		Henry Vivian Derozio started young Bengal movement with the inspiration of French revolution.

questions.Question: Swami Dayanand Saraswati established the Arya Samaj in 1875 at
questions.solution: Solution:		Swami Dayanand established the Arya Samaj on April 7, 1875 in Bombay, with 10 principles that are beautifully based purely on God, soul and nature. The organisation brought about immense changes in the religious perceptions of Indians.

questions.Question: Which of the following reformer was associated with Prarthana Samaj?
questions.solution: Solution:		Atmaram Pandurang or Atmaram Pandurang Turkhadekar (or just Turkhad in English publications) (1823-1898) was an Indian physician and social reformer who founded the Prarthana Samaj and was one of the two Indian co-founders (the other being Sakharam Arjun) of the Bombay Natural History Society.

questions.Question: Raja Ram Mohan Roy was the founder of the__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Ram Mohan Roy. Raja Ram Mohan Roy (22 May 1772 – 27 September 1833) was one of the founders of the Brahmo Sabha, the precursor of the Brahmo Samaj, a socio-religious reform movement in the Indian subcontinent.

questions.Question: The original name of Swami Dayananda Saraswati was
questions.solution: Solution:		His original name was Mul Shankar because he was born in Dhanu Rashi and Mul Nakshatra. His father was Karshanji Lalji Kapadi, and his mother was Amrutbai.

questions.Question: What was the original name of Dayananda Saraswati?
questions.solution: Solution:		His original name was Mul Shankar because he was born in Dhanu Rashi and Mul Nakshatra. His father was Karshanji Lalji Kapadi, and his mother was Amrutbai.

questions.Question: Sir Huge Rose described whom as 'the best and bravest military leader of the rebel'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Huge Rose described Rani Laxmi Bai as 'the best and bravest military leader of the rebel'.

questions.Question: Which of the following reform is the legislative contribution of Raja Rammohan Roy?
questions.optionC: Reduction of export duties on Indian goods
questions.optionD: Abolition of east India company's trading rights
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Rammohan Roy supported women's rights. He was known for his efforts to abolish Sati Pratha (Hindu funeral practice in which widows were compelled to sacrifice themselves with their husband's pyre) and child marriage. Due to his unending efforts, Sati was declared illegal in 1829.

questions.Question: Who advocated the concept of one caste, one religion and one God for all?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sri Narayana Guru preached the doctrine of 'One caste, One religion, One God.' Its worth note that one of his athiest disciples, Sahadaran Ayyapan, changed into 'no religion, no caste and no God for mankind.

questions.Question: Who was the prominent leader in Lucknow during the Revolt of 1857?
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian Mutiny of 1857. During the Indian Mutiny, from 1857 to 1858, Begum Hazrat Mahal's band of supporters, led by Raja Jailal Singh, rebelled against the forces of the British; later, they seized control of Lucknow and she declared her son, Birjis Qadra, as the ruler (Wali) of Oudh.

questions.Question: Charles wood's despatch deals with which of the following issues?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Charles Wood, the President of the Board of Control, had an important effect on spreading English learning and female education in India.

questions.Question: When was Brahmo Samaj split?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1866, Keshub Chandra Sen organised the more radical "Brahmo Samaj of India" with overtones of Christianity.

questions.Question: Where was Narayana Guru born?
questions.solution: Solution:		Narayana Guru (ca. 1854 – 20 September 1928), was a social reformer of India. He was born into a family of the Ezhava caste in an era when people from such communities, which were regarded as Avarna, faced much injustice in the caste-ridden society of Kerala.

questions.Question: In __________, a man named Raja Ram Mohan Roy founded an organization called 'Brahma Samaj'
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Ram Mohan Roy was the founder of the Brahmo Samaj at Kolkata in 1828. His efforts actually led to the resumption of the ethical principles of the Vedanta school of philosophy. He co-founded the Calcutta Unitarian Society. The title 'Raja' was bestowed upon him by the Mughal Emperor, Akbar II.

questions.Question: Which of the following leader associated with Barout in Uttar Pradesh during 1857 revolts?
questions.solution: Solution:		The leader associated with Barout in Uttar Pradesh during 1857 revolts was Shah Mal.

questions.Question: The Prarthana Samaj had been established by
questions.solution: Solution:		Prarthana Samaj, or "Prayer Society" in Sanskrit, was a movement for religious and social reform in Bombay based on earlier reform movements. Prarthana Samaj was founded by Atmaram Pandurang in 1867 when Kesab Chandra sen visited Maharashtra, with an aim to make people believe in one God and worship only one God.

questions.Question: Who is the author of the book "The First Indian War of Independence- 1857-59"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Karl Marx is the author of the book "The First Indian War of Independence- 1857-59".

questions.Question: Paramahamsa Mandali primarily aimed at breaking caste rules was founded in which of the following places
questions.solution: Solution:		It was the first socio-religious organization of Maharashtra. Founded in 1849 Maharashtra, the founders of these mandli believed in one god. They were primarily interested in breaking caste rules. At their meetings food cooked by lower caste people was taken by the members.

questions.Question: Raja Ram Mohan Roy was born on May 22, 1772 in village Radhanagar in the District of Hooghly in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Rammohan Roy was born on May 22, 1772, in a Brahmin family in the village of Radhanagar near Krishnanagar in Hooghly district (Bengal Presidency).

questions.Question: Raja Ram Mohan Roy was given the title 'Raja' by the__________
