questions.solution: Solution:		In 1828, he launched Brahmo Sabha with Devendranath Tagore. By 1828, he had become a well known figure in India. In 1830, he had gone to England as an envoy of the Mughal Emperor, Akbar Shah II, who invested him with the title of Raja to the court of King William IV.

questions.Question: Who is the author of the book "Satyarth Prakash"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Satyarth Prakash ("The Light of Meaning of the Truth" or The Light of Truth) is a 1875 book written originally in Hindi by Maharishi Dayanand Saraswati, a renowned religious and social reformer and the founder of Arya Samaj. It is considered one of his major scholarly works.

questions.Question: Satyashodhak Samaj was founded by whom?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jyotibha Phule was the founder of Satyashodhak Samar in Pune 1873, the Purpose of this samaj was to liberate the Shudra Untouchable castes from exploitation and oppression.

questions.Question: Faraizi Movement which aimed at removing social reforms in muslims started in which of the following regions?
questions.solution: Solution:		Shariatullah founded the Faraizi movement which was a religious reform movement in the 19th century for Bengali Muslims. The term Faraizi was taken from fard which means standing for compulsory and mandatory duties ordained by Allah. It started in East Bengal.

questions.Question: Which among the following names is not associated with the theosophical society?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak, born as Keshav Gangadhar Tilak, was an Indian nationalist, teacher, lawyer and an independence activist. He was the first leader of the Indian Independence Movement. The British colonial authorities called him "The father of the Indian unrest."

questions.Question: Year of the Battle of Plassey is __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Plassey was a major battle that took place on 23 June 1757 at Palashi, Bengal. It was an important British East India Company victory over the Nawab of Bengal and his French allies.

questions.Question: Year of the Battle of Buxar is__________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Buxar was fought on 22 October 1764 between the forces under the command of the British East India Company, led by Hector Munro, and the combined armies of Mir Qasim, Nawab of Bengal till 1763; the Nawab of Awadh; and the Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II.

questions.Question: Hyder Ali was the ruler of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Hyder Ali , Haidarali (c. 1720 – 7 December 1782) was the Sultan and de facto ruler of the Kingdom of Mysore in southern India.

questions.Question: Maharishi Dayanand Saraswati was an important Hindu religious scholar, reformer, and founder of the __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Dayananda Sarasvati, original name Mula Sankara, (born 1824, Tankara, Gujarat, India—died October 30, 1883, Ajmer, Rajputana), Hindu ascetic and social reformer who was the founder (1875) of the Arya Samaj (Society of Aryans [Nobles]), a Hindu reform movement advocating a return to the temporal and spiritual authority.

questions.Question: Where was the Devadasi System prevailed in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Devadasi system is a religious practice in south India mostly in Karnataka and Telangana, and partly in Andhra Pradesh.

questions.Question: The Bengal Regulation Act of 1829 dealt with which of the following issues primarily
questions.solution: Solution:		The Bengal Sati Regulation which banned the Sati practice in all jurisdictions of British India was passed on December 4, 1829 by the then Governor-General Lord William Bentinck. The regulation described the practice of Sati as revolting to the feelings of human nature.

questions.Question: Who among the following is the head of theosophical society in India
questions.solution: Solution:		Annie Besant (1847–1933), second President of The Theosophical Society from 1907 to 1933, was described as a ‘Diamond Soul’, for she had many brilliant facets to her character.She was an outstanding orator of her time, a champion of human freedom, educationist, philanthropist, and author with more than three hundred books and pamphlets to her credit.

questions.Question:
Justice movement was started by?
I. C. N. Mudaliar
II. T. M. Nair
III. P. Tyagaraja
questions.solution: Solution:		The Justice Party, officially the South Indian Liberal Federation, was a political party in the Madras Presidency of British India. It was established in on November 20, 1916 in Victoria Memorial Hall in Madras by T. M. Nair and P. Theagaraya Chetty as a result of a series of non-Brahmin conferences and meetings in the presidency.

questions.Question: In 1883 Dayananda was invited by the Maharaja of __________ to stay at his palace
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1883, the Maharaja of Jodhpur Swami, Jaswant Singh II, invited Dayananda to stay at his palace.

questions.Question: Who was the founder of Satyashodhak Samaj?
questions.solution: Solution:		On 24 September 1873, Phule formed Satyashodhak Samaj to focus on rights of depressed groups such as women, the Shudra, and the Dalit.

questions.Question: The actual name of Dayanand Saraawati, the founder of the Arya Samaj was
questions.solution: Solution:		The actual name of Dayanand Saraawati, the founder of the Arya Samaj was Mula Shankar.

questions.Question: Who is called the "Lokhitwadi"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Hari Deshmukh (18 February 1823 – 9 October 1892) was an Indian activist, thinker, social reformer and writer from Maharashtra. His original surname was Shidhaye. Because of 'Vatan' (right of Tax collection) that the family had received,the family was later called Deshmukh.

questions.Question: Raja Rammohan Roy organised a historic agitation against the
questions.optionC: Degrading position of women in society
questions.solution: Solution:		Ram Mohan Roy launched an attack on Sati that "aroused such anger that for awhile his life was in danger".

questions.Question: The Arya Samaj Movement had been started by
questions.solution: Solution:		Arya Samaj, (Sanskrit: "Society of Nobles") vigorous reform movement of modern Hinduism, founded in 1875 by Dayananda Sarasvati, whose aim was to reestablish the Vedas, the earliest Hindu scriptures, as revealed truth.

questions.Question: Raja Ram Mohan Roy was the founder of
questions.solution: Solution:		Raj Ram Mohan Roy founded Bramho Sabha in August 1828, it was later renamed as Brahmo Samaj. It aimed at purifying Hinduism and preaching 'monotheism' on the basis of reason and the Vedas and Upanishads.

questions.Question: Who founded the 'All India Harijan Samaj' in 1932?
questions.solution: Solution:		Harijan Sevak Sangh is a non-profit organisation founded by Mahatma Gandhi in 1932 to eradicate untouchability in India, working for Harijan or Dalit people and upliftment of scheduled castes of India.

questions.Question: __________ a notable disciple of Sree Narayana Guru introduced Guru's visions and ideals to the western world
questions.solution: Solution:		Nataraja Guru was a notable disciple of Sree Narayana Guru introduced Guru's visions and ideals to the western world.

questions.Question: The founder of the 'Brahmo Samaj' was
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Rammohan Roy founded brahmo samaj in Calcutta on 20 August 1828. It was more of a reformist movement of Hinduism which later got divided into adi brahmo samaj and sadharan brahmo samaj. Raja Ram Mohan Roy, one of the few 19th century reformers of Hindu society.

questions.Question: Tipu was defeated in the __________ Anglo-Maratha war by the British
questions.solution: Solution:		The British's diplomacy, conspiracy and intrigues against Tipu succeeded after the Third Anglo Mysore war which was ended by the Treaty of Srirangapatnam on March 22, 1792.

questions.Question: The fourth __________War was of short duration and decisive and ended with Tipu's death on May 4, 1799
questions.solution: Solution:		The Fourth Anglo–Mysore War was a conflict in South India between the Kingdom of Mysore against the British East India Company and the Hyderabad Deccan in 1798–99. This was the final conflict of the four Anglo–Mysore Wars. The British captured the capital of Mysore. The ruler Tipu Sultan was killed in the battle.

questions.Question: Shree Narayana Guru was a great socio-religious reformer of
questions.solution: Solution:		Narayana Guru (ca. 1854 – 20 September 1928), was a social reformer of India. He was born into a family of the Ezhava caste in an era when people from such communities, which were regarded as Avarna, faced much injustice in the caste-ridden society of Kerala.

questions.Question: Who founded the Sri Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam (SNDP) was founded in 1903 with the guidance and blessings of Sree Narayana Guru.

questions.Question: Who wrote the book 'A Gift to monotheists'?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1809, Raja Ram Mohan Roy wrote 'Gift to Monotheists' in which he put forward the Idea that people must worship a single God.

questions.Question: Sri Narayana Guru was born into an __________ family.
questions.solution: Solution:		Narayana Guru (ca. 1854 – 20 September 1928), was a social reformer of India. He was born into a family of the Ezhava caste in an era when people from such communities, which were regarded as Avarna, faced much injustice in the caste-ridden society of Kerala.
